{{Infobox organization | alt = | caption = | logo = Finance Watch Logo.jpg | motto = "Making finance serve society" | predecessor = | successor = | formation = April 2011 | extinction = | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] | status = | purpose = Promoting sound [[financial regulation]] | headquarters = {{flag|Belgium}}, [[Brussels]] | coords = | language = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]] | leader_title = Secretary General | leader_name = Benoît Lallemand | leader_title2 = Chair | leader_name2 = Rainer Lenz | leader_name3 = | leader_title3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = | remarks = | name = Finance Watch | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | map2 = | abbreviation = | location = | region_served = [[European Union]] | membership = | general = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [http://www.finance-watch.org www.finance-watch.org] }}
'''Finance Watch''' is a European non-governmental organization that conducts research and advocacy on [[financial regulation]]. Based in [[Brussels]], the organization focuses on financial regulation in the [[European Union]] and its member states.
Finance Watch was founded in 2011 by members of the [[European Parliament]] as a counterbalance to the financial lobby.<ref>[http://www.presseurop.eu/en/content/article/1542771-finance-watch-lobby-break-lobbies "Finance Watch – a lobby to break the lobbies"]. [[Der Tagesspiegel]] (English translation). 23 February 2012. Retrieved 1 March 2013.</ref> Its mission is "to strengthen the voice of society in the reform of financial regulation by conducting advocacy and presenting public interest arguments to lawmakers and the public as a counterweight to the private interest lobbying of the financial industry".<ref>[http://www.world-governance.org/spip.php?site124/ "Finance Watch"]. Listing on FnWG. Retrieved 1 March 2013.</ref>
==Background==
Finance Watch was founded on 30 June 2011 as a consequence of a petition initiated in June 2010 by 22 <ref>[http://finance-watch.org/press/press-releases/344-signatories/ "Signatories"]. Finance Watch website. Retrieved 7 March 2013</ref> members of the European Parliament, including members of all major political groups ([[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (European Parliament group)|ALDE]], [[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|EPP]], [[Greens-EFA]], [[GUE/NGL]], and [[S&D]]). This call for action was signed by another 140 elected officials from across Europe, and led to an exploratory project funded by the initiators, which in turn resulted in the founding General Assembly on 30 June 2011. [[Ieke van den Burg]], a former [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]], was appointed Chair of the Board of Directors and Thierry Philipponnat, a former banker and [[Amnesty International]] executive in France, became the Secretary General. In January 2017, Benoît Lallemand became Secretary General.
==Activities== The organization's research team analyses financial regulation and formulates policy recommendations. Its views are then communicated to policymakers by its advocacy team, who also cooperate with member organizations who share the same views, and to the wider public by its communication team. Examples of dossiers that Finance Watch deals with are capital requirements for banks (the [[Basel III]] agreement), banking structure (the [[Liikanen report|Liikanen Consultation]]), [[high-frequency trading]], food and resource speculation, and protection of retail investors. Finance Watch also organizes conferences about financial regulation issues, where different stakeholders of the financial sector interact in public.
==Structure and financing== Finance Watch is an international association under Belgian law<ref>[http://finance-watch.org/about-us/ "About us"]. Finance Watch website. Retrieved 7 March 2013</ref> ([[AISBL]]), and has two types of members: individuals and civil society organizations. The latter include [[Consumer protection|consumer groups]], [[trade unions]], [[housing associations]], [[Environmentalism|environmental NGOs]], [[International development|development NGOs]] and others. Each member has an equal vote at the organization’s general assembly. To become a member, both individuals and civil society organizations need to prove to the organization’s Committee of Transparency and Independence that they are independent from the financial industry. Individual members also need to qualify for membership by showing they have relevant experience and expertise. The members convene at least once a year for a General Assembly. During the year, the General Assembly is represented by the Board of Directors. The Board comprises eight Directors including six elected by and from the General Assembly (four Member organisations and two individual Members) and two independent Directors (“external personalities”).
Members of the Finance Watch board of directors as of June 2017:<ref>[http://finance-watch.org/about-us/governance-and-funding "Governance and Funding"]. Finance Watch website. Retrieved 14 March 2018</ref> * Chair: Prof. Dr. Rainer Lenz (Professor for International Finance, [[:de:Fachhochschule Bielefeld|Fachhochschule Bielefeld]]) * Vice-chair: Morten Clausen, [[UNI Europa]] * Fran Boait, [[Positive Money]] * Grégoire Niaudet, [[Secours Catholique]] * Rainer Geiger, Attorney-at-law * Andrea Baranes, Fondazione Banca Etica
Board Directors from outside the Membership (“external personalities”): * Marc Roche (author, financial journalist) * Professor Eric De Keuleneer (professor of economic regulation and banking at the Solvay School of the Université Libre de Bruxelles)
The organization’s budget has as its main sources project funding from the [[European Union]] and grants from several charitable foundations: Adessium Foundation, Fondation pour le progrès de l’homme, [[:de:Friedrich-Ebert-Stiftung|Friedrich-Ebert-Stiftung]], Better Markets, Open Society Initiative for Europe, as well as individual donations and members’ fees and contributions.
==Principles== The declared mission of Finance Watch is “to strengthen the voice of society in the reform of financial regulation by conducting advocacy and presenting public interest arguments to lawmakers and the public as a counterweight to the private interest lobbying of the financial industry”.
The organization states it follows six principles<ref>[http://finance-watch.org/about-us/ "About us"]. Finance Watch website. Retrieved 7 March 2013</ref> in the pursuit of this mission:
# The role of the financial industry (allocating capital, managing risk and providing financial services) has strong public interest implications. # The primary role of finance is to allocate capital to productive use. # Finance must serve the real economy, not the inverse. # Banks are legitimate in pursuing profits to ensure their sustainability, but profits should not harm public interest. # Credit risk should not be transferred to society at large. # The real economy needs to have access to capital and financial services, in a sustainable, equitable and transparent manner.
==See also== * [[Bank regulation]] * [[Financial regulation]] * [[Lobbying#European Union|Lobbying in the European Union]]

[[Anna de Noailles]] (grandniece) |allegiance = {{flag|Wallachia|1834}} |branch = |serviceyears = 1851–1856 |rank = General |commands = [[Wallachian military forces|Wallachian militia]] |battles = [[Crimean War]] }} '''George Barbu Știrbei''' or '''Știrbeiŭ''', also known as '''Gheorghe''', '''Georgie''', or '''Iorgu Știrbei''' ([[Francization|Francized]] ''Georges Stirbey''; April 1, 1828 – August 15, 1925), was a [[Wallachia]]n-born [[Romania]]n aristocrat and politician who served as the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] from July 15, 1866 until February 21, 1867. He was the eldest son of [[Barbu Dimitrie Știrbei]], [[List of rulers of Wallachia|Prince of Wallachia]], and the nephew of his rival, [[Gheorghe Bibescu]]; his younger siblings included the landowner and industrialist [[Alexandru B. Știrbei]]. Educated in France, he returned to Wallachia during his father's princely mandate, as a ''[[Begzada|Beizadea]]'' and aspiring politician. Fleeing his country during the [[Crimean War]], he served the [[Second French Empire|French Empire]] before returning home to become Wallachian Minister of War and ''[[Spatharios]]''. He is remembered for reforming the [[Wallachian military forces|Wallachian militia]] during the remainder of Prince Barbu's term. Știrbei remained a legislator of Wallachia and then of the [[United Principalities]]. He was however strongly opposed to the Principalities' first ''[[Domnitor]]'', [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza]], reemerging by 1860 as a charismatic leader of the conservative opposition. His involvement in political scandals and electoral intrigues led to his brief arrest that same year, but Cuza was ultimately toppled in 1866. Following this, Știrbei abandoned his own bid for the throne to serve ''Domnitor'' [[Carol I of Romania|Carol of Hohenzollern]]. As Foreign Minister, he helped secure recognition for the United Principalities, and made diplomatic overtures toward [[Austria-Hungary]]. Failing in his attempt to become [[Prime Minister of Romania]], he was disappointed with the ''Domnitor'', leaving politics altogether. Știrbei divided the second half of his life between homes in Paris and [[Bécon-les-Bruyères]], and was [[French nationality law|naturalized French]]. In this period, he was a collector and patron of the arts, noted as [[Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux]]'s last-ever sponsor. He was also married to the actress and sculptor [[Gustave Haller|Valérie Simonin]], adopting her daughters [[Consuelo Fould|Consuelo]] and [[Georges Achille Fould]]—whom he educated artistically. His parallel work was as a cultural journalist, and, late in his life, as the posthumous editor of [[Jean-Jacques Weiss]] and as a memoirist. His controversial dealings with Carpeaux, the status of his inheritance, and his paternity disputes remained at the center of public attention long after his death. ==Biography== ===Origins and early life=== Știrbei was born in [[Bucharest]], the Wallachian capital, on April 1, 1828, a date he himself gave against records which have 1834;Badea-Păun, p. 108 other sources claim 1832.Lucreția Angheluță, Salomeea Rotaru, Liana Miclescu, Marilena Apostolescu, Marina Vazaca, ''Bibliografia românească modernă (1831–1918). Vol. IV: R–Z'', p. 500. Bucharest: [[Editura științifică și enciclopedică]], 1996. {{ISBN|973-27-0501-9}}Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 240 His paternal origins were in the Bibescu family, which had its roots in the petty [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar nobility]] of [[Oltenia]]: a yeoman Bibul, living before 1700, was the family patriarch.Iorga (1910), pp. 9–10 The clan went through a rapid social climb after the fall of the [[Phanariote]]s and the foundation of a ''[[Regulamentul Organic]]'' regime. As a protege of Prince [[Grigore IV Ghica]] in the 1820s, George's grandfather Dumitrachi married Ecaterina, a member of the [[Văcărescu family]], and made friends with her tutor, ''[[Vornic]]'' Barbu C. Știrbei. He was a godfather to Dumitrachi's first-born, Barbu Bibescu, whom he adopted, before dying in 1813; Barbu was therefore the only one known as Știrbei among the three Bibescu brothers.Iorga (1910), pp. 9–13. See also Hêrjeu, p. 162; Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, pp. 137–138, 258; Papazoglu & Speteanu, pp. 182, 313{{ro icon}} Alexandra Șerban, [https://web.archive.org/web/20170405140639/http://adevarul.ro/cultura/istorie/serial-boieri-mari-episodul-7-renascutneamul-Stirbey-propria-cenusa-barbu-Stirbey-mai-abil-om-umbra-regeluiferdinand-1_58b135e05ab6550cb8cb96a3/index.html "Serial. Boieri mari, Episodul 7: Cum a renăscut neamul Știrbey din propria cenușă. Barbu Știrbey, cel mai abil om din umbra regelui Ferdinand"], in ''[[Adevărul]]'', February 25, 2017 On his mother [[Elisabeta Știrbey|Elisabeta]]'s side, George descended from the [[Cantacuzino family]], specifically its branch in [[Moldavia]].Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 240; Iorga (1910), p. 31; Mucenic, pp. 73–74 When his son was born, Barbu Bibescu-Știrbei was merely a ''[[Clucer]]'', trailing behind his more ambitious brother Gheorghe;Iorga (1910), pp. 15–17 his climb was moreover interrupted by the [[Russian Empire]], with its [[Russo-Turkish War (1828–1829)|invasion of Wallachia]]. It resumed when he was imposed by Consul Peter I. Rikman into the cabinet of Prince [[Alexandru II Ghica]].Hêrjeu, p. 88 The liberal-minded and [[Westernization|Westernizing]] [[Pavel Kiselyov]] become governor of the two [[Danubian Principalities]], also forcing Știrbei's appointment to government offices.Iorga (1910), pp. 15–32 This service prompted the establishment to regard the Bibescu–Știrbeis as intolerable upstarts—or "Oltenian horse-breeders", in the reported sayings of [[Alecu Filipescu-Vulpea]].Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, pp. 137–138, 258 Other critics jokingly referred to the brothers as the "equine dynasty".Chirică, p. 357 During those years, Barbu fathered six more children by Elisabeta: sons [[Alexandru B. Știrbei|Alexandru]] and Dimitrie, daughters Fenereta, Alina, Elisabeta, and Elena.Mucenic, p. 74 When George turned 12 in 1840, his father dispatched him to the [[July Monarchy|Kingdom of France]], where he enlisted at the Bollin school, then at [[Lycée Louis-le-Grand]]. During his time at Louis-le-Grand, young Știrbei met and befriended the future writer-politician [[Jean-Jacques Weiss]], becoming his admirer and, later, his biographer and editor.Badea-Păun, pp. 107–108 Taking his ''[[Baccalauréat]]'' in August 1847, he studied in parallel at the Administrative School, [[Collège de France]], and the [[Paris Law Faculty]]. His graduation from the latter came in August 1850, when he published with [[Firmin Didot]] his thesis ''De Condictione indebite ou Des obligations qui se forment sans contrat''.Badea-Păun, p. 108 He witnessed the [[French Revolution of 1848]], and in later years emphasized its positive qualities in disputes with the more conservative politicians.Catargiu, pp. 268–269 This period of Știrbei's life also overlapped with a [[Wallachian Revolution of 1848|Wallachian Revolution]], which toppled his uncle Bibescu from the throne. Having conceded the [[Wallachian princely election, 1842|1842 election]] to his brother,Hêrjeu, pp. 99–100; Iorga, ''Istoria'', pp. 38–39, 67; Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 141; Papazoglu & Speteanu, pp. 169–170 Barbu Știrbei accepted government office, but maintained his independence. He had been sidelined by the time of the revolt, keeping silent during its outbreak.Iorga (1910), pp. 31–32, 50; Papazoglu & Speteanu, p. 178 However, as noted by his son, he privately resented it as an experiment in socialism.Chiper, pp. 199, 205–206 Following interventions by Russia and the [[Ottoman Empire]], Barbu Știrbei was made Prince and George became the ''[[Begzada|Beizadea]]''. Returning to Bucharest, he was incorporated as a Major into the [[Wallachian military forces]] and joined the Prince on official duties, including on his 1851 visit to [[Telega, Prahova|Telega]]; he was dispatched on official trips to [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Sibiu|Hermannstadt]], and [[Istanbul]].Iorga (1910), pp. 95–96, 133–134, 149–150, 164, 175, 191. See also Filitti, p. 70 Noted as a "great lover of theater and invaluable supporter of the actors", "especially fond" of the comedian [[Costache Caragiale]], he was present with his father for the inauguration of Caragiale's [[National Theatre Bucharest|Bucharest Theater]] (late 1852).N. Săvulescu, "Costache Caragiale", in ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]'', Nr. 2/1939, p. 378 In 1853 he joined his father's government as ''[[Logothete]]'' of the Justice Ministry.Badea-Păun, p. 108 The cabinet also included [[Alexandru Plagino]], who was brothers-in-law with the ''Beizadea''; later, his brothers-in-law included [[Ion Emanuel Florescu]].Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, pp. 74, 215, 241, 282; Maciu, p. 62; Iorga (1910), pp. 36, 49–50, 53, 82, 158, 166–167; Mucenic, p. 74 Of his sisters, Elena, married count Leo Larisch von Mönnich from [[Cieszyn Silesia]];Filitti, pp. 70, 72–74; Iorga (1910), p. 158; Mucenic, p. 74 in 1855, she gave birth to his son [[Count Georg Larisch of Moennich, Baron of Ellgoth and Karwin|Georg]], later husband of [[Countess Marie Larisch von Moennich|the Baroness Wallersee]].Veronika Matroszová, ''Rod Larisch-Mönnichů na Karvinsku'', pp. 10–11. Karviná: Státní okresní archiv, 1999. {{ISBN|80-86388-00-X}} ===War Minister=== A new Russian intervention came in summer 1853, during the escalation ahead of the [[Crimean War]]. At the time, ''Beizadea'' George was a Colonel attached to the General Staff.Luminița Gavra, "Restituiri. Statul major princiar al oștirii (1830–1865)", in ''Document. Buletinul Arhivelor Militare'', Nr. 1/2010, pp. 27–28 Alongside his father, he paid homage to [[Mikhail Dmitrievich Gorchakov]], an effective surrender.Iorga (1910), p. 152 He was eventually chased out of the country by the unfolding events (as were his younger brothers),"On lit dans le ''Wanderer'', de Vienne", in ''[[La Presse (French newspaper)|La Presse]]'', December 3, 1853, p. 2 and returned to Paris, where he applied for service in the [[French Army]]. Attached as a foreigner,"Nécrologie" in ''[[Le Temps (Paris)|Le Temps]]'', August 15, 1925, p. 4 he was stationed with the [[Versailles]] cavalry, and became [[Pierre Chrétien Korte]]'s ''[[aide de camp]]''. He spent the war negotiating with the [[Second French Empire]] and the Ottomans on behalf of his father, carefully balancing the interests of both powers.Badea-Păun, pp. 108–109 Russia's defeat restored his father to the throne, allowing Știrbei to be decommissioned and to return home; Wallachia and Moldavia had by then been placed under international supervision, ending ''Regulamentul Organic''. The new tutelage of the country involved not only the Ottomans and the Russians, but also France, the [[Austrian Empire]], [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain]], the [[Kingdom of Prussia]], and [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Piedmont-Sardinia]]. From Bucharest, George Știrbei left on new diplomatic tours, visiting Moldavia and approaching its [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince]], [[Grigore Alexandru Ghica]]; he also had contacts with Austria through [[Johann Baptist Coronini-Cronberg|Count Coronini]]. He presented the latter with a paper, ''Resumé de la situation administrative de Valachie'', which became useful for the Western powers in evaluating the course of Wallachian affairs.Badea-Păun, p. 109 ''Beizadea'' Știrbei was eventually sent to France with orders to complete his military education there.Badea-Păun, p. 109; Iorga (1910), p. 179 He is known to have taken courses at both the [[Prussian Military Academy]] and the [[École spéciale militaire de Saint-Cyr|Military School of Saint-Cyr]], following which he became a Wallachian general and Minister of War (''[[Spatharios]]'').Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 240 This position allowed him influence over the political and social life. His art collection probably dates back to this period, when painter [[Theodor Aman]], whom the Știrbeis elevated to the rank of ''[[Pitar (rank)|Pitar]]'', sent him one of his canvasses as thanks.Badea-Păun, p. 112 Possibly pressed on by the Moldavian precedent, from December 1855 the ''Beizadea'' and fellow minister Plagino also recommended to Prince Barbu that he liberate Wallachia's [[Slavery in Romania|Romani slaves]].[[Gheorghe Sion]], ''Suvenire contimporane'', p. 53. Bucharest: [[Editura Minerva]], 1915. {{OCLC|7270251}} {{multiple image|direction=vertical|total_width=300 |image1=Știrbei family coat of arms.svg|caption1=Știrbei family arms|width1=300|height1=240 |image2=Alex. - Eraldică (Știrbei), Ghimpele, 31 ian 1867.png|caption2=Parody Știrbei arms, mocking the family's conservatism, in ''[[Ghimpele]]'' (January 1867). Showing instruments of repression, with a [[Cossacks|Cossack]] and an [[Ottoman Army (1861–1922)|Ottoman soldier]] for [[supporter]]s. [[Crest (heraldry)|In crest]], the [[Amaranthus retroflexus|redroot pigweed]] (''știr'') is a pun on the family name|width2=300|height2=180 }} As noted by his subordinate [[Dimitrie Papazoglu]], his reformist stance "won him affection from the entire army."Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 240; Papazoglu & Speteanu, pp. 178–179 His work also included teaching history to cadets enlisted at Wallachia's Military School.Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, pp. 73–75 In 1855, he traveled to [[Czernowitz]], where he paid homage to [[Emperor of Austria|Emperor]] [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Franz Joseph]].Filitti, p. 70 At the time, the ''Beizadea'' approached France's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Development (France)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]], [[Édouard Drouyn de Lhuys]], asking him to provide training for Wallachian militias in the event of war with the Ottomans;Badea-Păun, p. 109 he also obtained the recall of a hostile consul, Eugène Poujade.Iorga (1910), p. 183 Through his son, Prince Barbu also communicated his plans for establishing the "[[United Principalities]]" of Wallachia, Moldavia, and the [[Budjak]], with perpetual neutrality and full independence, to guard the [[mouths of the Danube]] against Russian encroachment. These plans also provided for the election to the unified throne of a foreign prince, unconnected to the boyardom.Iorga (1910), pp. 179–181 Attending the [[Congress of Paris (1856)|Paris Peace Conference]], the ''Beizadea'' resigned himself to the discovery that his father's mandate would not be renewed, and from that point on demanded that a foreign dynasty be placed on Wallachia's throne.Badea-Păun, p. 109 The Știrbeis also began lobbying for the construction of a railway from [[Brașov|Kronstadt]] to [[Oltenița]]. If built, it would have been Wallachia's first.Filitti, p. 79 Appointed ''[[Kaymakam|Caimacam]]'' in July 1856, [[Alexandru II Ghica]] immediately ordered State Secretary Plagino and ''Spatharios'' Știrbei to be stripped of their offices, and announced a formal investigation of the deposed regime, which caused an uproar among the Știrbeists.Maciu, p. 62 Unpopular with the boyars, and faced with their passive resistance, Ghica sought to reconcile with the moderate wing of the [[National Party (Romania)|National Party]], a loose group which advocated union.Maciu, p. 64 After this period of uncertainty, his father won a seat as deputy to the [[ad-hoc Divan]] in the [[Wallachian legislative election, 1857|September 1857 race]]. Both father and son took a reserved stance on the unionist issue, favoring good relations with the Ottoman Empire, which did not approve of the National Party.Iorga (1910), pp. 90–92 Following Ghica's demotion and the reshuffle of 1858, the Știrbeis controlled one of the three new ''Caimacami'', [[Ioan Manu]].Chirică, pp. 352–353, 357 ===Conservative leadership=== The Știrbeist project was damaged by the [[Wallachian Elective Assembly, 1859|election of January 1859]], in which both Bibescu brothers stood as candidates in [[Dolj County]].Gherghe, pp. 128–130, 161, 173–174; Hêrjeu, pp. 199–200; Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, pp. 239–240 The ''Beizadea'' also ran at Dolj's landowners college, in what was reported as a dirty race, complete with "machinations and base intrigues."Gherghe, pp. 173–174 As reported by ''[[Steaua Dunării|Steoa Dunărei]]'', he also took a seat in [[Romanați County]].Chirică, p. 356 A set of circumstances, utilized to its advantage by the National Party, resulted in the election to the throne of a Moldavian, [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza]], as ''[[Domnitor]]'' of both countries—now officially the "United Principalities". His father's ambition of reaching the same result from a more conservative basis was frustrated on January 23, when his own candidacy for the throne was rejected by the deputies.Chirică, pp. 357–359; Iorga, ''Istoria'', pp. 339–342 After his confirmation to the newly-formed Legislative Assembly, ''Beizadea'' Știrbei stood on the its hard right: he and Florescu proposed an illiberal press law, drawing protests from their fellow deputy, the journalist [[Cezar Bolliac]].Vasile Novac, "Activitatea politică a argeşenilor și mușcelenilor reflectată în paginile ziarului ''Românul'' în perioada august 1857 – iunie 1859", in ''Argessis. Studii și Comunicări, Seria Istorie'', Vol. X, 2001, p. 247 A wider conflict soon erupted between the Cuzas and the Știrbeis. Already in July 1859, while seemingly vacationing at [[Le Mont-Dore (France)|Mont-Dore-les-Bains]], ''Beizadea'' Știrbei attacked Cuza in a protest paper addressed to the foreign powers, alleging that the new regime equated anarchy.Badea-Păun, p. 109. See also Iorga (1910), p. 192 The consolidated opposition, headed by [[Barbu Catargiu]] and [[Constantin N. Brăiloiu]], wanted him to lead their Conservative Committee, but Știrbei dropped out and Plagino was considered instead.Vlad, pp. 4–5 During that legislature, he and Catargiu, who served as the [[Ministry of Public Finance (Romania)|Minister of Finance]], had extensive disagreements over budgetary matters and economic policies.Catargiu, pp. 93–95, 109–110, 155 However, according to a note in the ''[[Gazzetta Ufficiale]]'', he was the "natural leader" of a "conservative party, comprising for the most supporters of the former princes Stirbey and Bibesco {{sic}}"."Parte non ufficiale. Principati Riuniti", in ''[[Gazzetta Ufficiale]]'', No. 68/1860, p. 3 Similarly, historian [[Nicolae Iorga]] describes the conservative faction as a "party of the pretenders", uniting George Barbu with Bibescu's heirs.Iorga, ''Istoria'', p. 371 Eventually, Știrbei joined the Assembly in the [[Wallachian legislative election, 1860|1860 election]], taking the majority vote at [[Craiova]]. This race was also mired in controversy, after the authorities alleged that he had bribed the electorate.Catargiu, pp. 183–186 In March, he joined the committee which was to present Cuza with the Assembly's stances, but he resigned over disagreements with his colleagues.Catargiu, pp. 171–172 During the ramified scandal, his alleged direct threats against Cuza resulted in his arrest."Correo estanjero", in ''La Discusión. Diário Democrático'', April 4, 1860, p. 3Badea-Păun, p. 109; Catargiu, pp. 183–186; Iorga (1910), p. 192 He was charged with high treason and, reportedly, "Romanians [felt] passionate about the prisoner, asking that he stand trial." The breach of his [[parliamentary immunity]] degenerated into a national embarrassment, prompting the collective resignation of [[Ion Ghica]]'s Wallachian cabinet.Iorga (1910), p. 192 He retook his seat in the [[Wallachian legislative election, 1861|1861 race]]. This came shortly after violent riots in Craiova, which, Știrbei argued, called for a parliamentary inquiry.Catargiu, pp. 212–215 Carried by an anti-Cuza majority opposed in particular to [[Land reform in Romania|land reform]], this legislature elected him Vice President, seconding Catargiu.Catargiu, pp. 213, 237; Hêrjeu, p. 205 According to various sources, he was also the President of that body. An Ottoman diplomat, [[Gregory Aristarchis|Aristarchi Bey]], recounted in June 1861 that "the prince Stirbey" and other "leading boyars" were fostering "agitation in favor of a foreign prince"; this move, he suspected, had Russian backing.[[Barbara Jelavich]], "The Ottoman Empire, the Great Powers and the Legislative and Administrative Union of the Principalities", in [[Keith Hitchins]] (ed.), ''Romanian Studies. Vol. 2, 1971—1972'', p. 69. Leiden: [[Brill Publishers]], 1973. {{ISBN|90-04-03639-3}} Together, Știrbei, Alexandru C. Moruzi and [[Manolache Costache Epureanu]] pushed the Assembly into a deadlock, filibustering over Cuza's attempt to introduce a [[copyhold]] (''embatic''), set aside for landless peasants and supplied from the [[Secularization of monastic estates in Romania|monastery land reserve]].L. Botezan, "Problema agrara în dezbaterile parlamentare din Romînia în anul 1862", in ''Studia Universitatis Babeș-Bolyai. Historia'', Vol. IV, Issue 1, 1961, pp. 133–134 During those moths, he drew close to the conservative club formed by [[Apostol Arsache]], maintaining only loose contacts with the Catargiu faction—they differed on foreign policy issues, with Știrbei favoring an anti-Ottoman stance that Catargiu thought excessive.Vlad, pp. 7–8, 13 In July, Știrbei and Catargiu, who was by then the [[Prime Minister of Romania]], reviewed with alarm a meeting of the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|left-wing liberals]] on Filaret Hill, which had demanded increased political representation.Catargiu, pp. 266–271; Chiper, p. 202 Știrbei was described as a covert reactionary by the liberal doyen, [[C. A. Rosetti]], but he protested against the label; a polemic ensued.[[C. A. Rosetti]], "Domnuluĭ Georgie Știrbeĭ. Arhon Spătar", in ''[[Românul|Românulŭ]]'', October 8, 1861, pp. 891–892 Nevertheless, over the following months, Știrbei sponsored Rosetti's daily newspaper ''[[Românul]]'', which began advocating for Bibescu to replace Cuza.V. Mihordea, "Recenzii. Vasile Netea, ''C. A. Rosetti''", in ''Studii. Revistă de Istorie'', Nr. 5/1971, p. 1064 In June 1862, jointly with Rosetti and [[Ion Brătianu]], he stepped down from the Assembly to protest Cuza's policies."Donaufürstenthümer", in ''[[Laibacher Zeitung]]'', No. 140/1862, p. 559 Over the autumn months, he toured European capitals to obtain support for the conservative projects.Iorga, ''Istoria'', p. 375 In January of the following year, with conservatives recovering ground after Catargiu's assassination and other setbacks,Hêrjeu, pp. 210–221; Ungureanu, pp. 501–502 Știrbei signed his name to a letter of protest against Cuza's authoritarianism.Badea-Păun, p. 110 In April, he publicized his [[tax resistance]] and litigation with the authorities of [[Piața Amzei|Amzei suburb]], Bucharest."Revista politica. Domnuluĭ împlinitoriŭ alŭ comuniĭ (suburbiea) Amd̦a", in ''[[Românul|Românulŭ]]'', April 14, 1863, p. 1 Știrbei was subsequently a noted player in the "monstrous coalition", grouping left-liberals and "White" conservatives against Cuza and his centrist government.Tanoviceanu, pp. 14–15; Ungureanu, p. 501 In September, he and D. Ghica were star defenders at Rosetti's own trial for sedition. Appearing alongside Brătianu and [[Anastasie Panu]], Știrbei now spoke about press freedom as being vital for civic education."Curți și tribunalurĭ. Curtea Apelativă Criminale. Audința de la 10 Septemvrie", in ''[[Românul|Romănulŭ]]'', September 14, 1863, pp. 1–4 With Cuza taking more radical positions on land reform, Știrbei also revised his stance. Alongside a bipartisan committee (comprising Rosetti, Brătianu, Panu, Ion Ghica, [[Anton I. Arion]], [[Grigore Arghiropol]] and [[Nicolae Golescu]]), he now supported the sale of state land to the landless."Liberalii și țĕranii", in ''[[Voința Națională]]'', March 22 (April 3), 1892, p. 1 ===Under Carol=== In January 1863, Știrbei signed his name to a letter of protest which openly defied Cuza's agenda.Tanoviceanu, p. 14 Cuza's response to the resistance was an effective coup in May 1864. Eventually, he was himself toppled by the "monstrous coalition" in early 1866—a secretive palace coup in which Știrbei allegedly had a prominent role.Lică, "Diplomația d. ministru de esterne", in ''[[Ghimpele]]'', Nr. 9/1866, pp. 34–35 Following the [[Romanian general election, April 1866|election of April 1866]], Știrbei was sent to the unified [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]], which was debating the [[1866 Constitution of Romania|new Constitution]]. In that context, he adopted a [[Classical liberalism|classical liberal]] stance, explaining that both his party and the liberals could agree on the restoration of "true freedom".[[Nicolae Filipescu]], "Conservatism și liberalism", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', March 15 (27), 1886, p. 1 Despite reintroducing such pluralism, the regime change had left uncertain the continuation of Moldo–Wallachian federalism. In that context, Știrbei became one of the Romanian diplomats tasked with obtaining an international settlement recognizing continued union under a foreign ''Domnitor''. However, as reported by his supervisor [[Ion Bălăceanu]], Știrbei also tried to promote his own bid for the throne, which was received with ridicule.{{ro icon}} Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120804110334/http://www.romlit.ro/ghislain_de_diesbach_despre_anul_1866 "Ghislain de Diesbach despre anul 1866"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 45/2006 His father also entertained the notion that either George or one of his brothers would be selected.Iorga (1910), p. 193 Eventually, Știrbei recognized the results of the [[Romanian prince referendum, 1866|April plebiscite]] and communicated to the Prussian prince [[Carol I of Romania|Carol of Hohenzollern]], that Romanians wanted him as their ''Domnitor''. In September, his father, who was living his final years in [[Nice]], made a show of his loyalty by visiting Carol in Bucharest, pledging his and his sons' "industrious and faithful" support.Badea-Păun, p. 110. See also Iorga (1910), pp. 193–194 [[File:Duc d'Avaray, Comte de Bourbon-Busset, Ligier de Saint-Pierre, de Barberey, Prince Stirbey, Baron de Hauteclocque.jpg|thumb|270px|Știrbei (middle) with scions of French nobility, ca. 1860–1870]] From July 15, Știrbei had joined Ghica's national cabinet as [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]], endeavoring to ensure Ottoman recognition for a continued union under Carol. He and the ''Domnitor'' went to Istanbul for the ''[[firman]]'', which was granted to them by [[Abdülaziz]]. Carol signaled his refusal of direct vassalage by making Știrbei read the document, which signaled to Abdülaziz that he considered himself an equal.Badea-Păun, pp. 110–111. See also Iorga, ''Correspondance'', p. viii Știrbei also took some of the first steps in bringing Romania closer to [[Austria-Hungary]], which remained a staple of the conservative approach to foreign politics. He began talks with the [[Friedrich Ferdinand von Beust|Count von Beust]] regarding the exchange of consuls, [[extradition]] procedures, and connecting [[Rail transport in Romania|Romania's railway grid]] with the [[Imperial Royal Privileged Austrian State Railway Company|StEG]].Iorga, ''Correspondance'', pp. ix–x; Lucia Tafta, "Relațiile economice româno-franceze: aranjamentul comercial din noiembrie 1876", in ''Muzeul Național'', Vol. XII, 2000, p. 124 The ''Beizadea'' joined the 60-man conservative caucus in the Assembly, and, after the [[Romanian general election, November 1866|election of November 1866]], was recognized as a factional leader, alongside a fellow ''Beizadea'', [[Dimitrie Ghica]].Dan Moroianu, "Dezbateri parlamentare și patimi politice între 1866–1867", in ''Buridava'', Vol. VI, 2008, p. 135 The political realignment made him an adversary of the liberal camp. Its magazine, ''[[Ghimpele]]'', claimed that Știrbei was a comical man, "stuffed on princely might and pride", whose activity as minister amounted to "continuously advising the empires" on how to handle Romania. Știrbei was reconfirmed as deputy for Dolj and Craiova in the [[Romanian general election, 1867|December 1867 election]], this time without controversy."Romania", in ''Albina'', Nr. 7/1868, p. 2 The ''Domnitor'', who found him to be a competent diplomat, also considered him for his Prime Minister. The latter proposal, endorsed by the French, was vetoed by [[Karl Anton, Prince of Hohenzollern|Karl Anton of Hohenzollern]], who feared that Știrbei had not renounced his bid for the throne.Badea-Păun, p. 111 Reportedly, this greatly disappointed the candidate, contributing to his decision to quit politics and the country altogetherBadea-Păun, p. 111—although, according to other accounts, he cited reasons of health.P. Boutet, "Nouvelles diplomatiques et internationales", in ''Le Mémorial Diplomatique'', No. 18/1870, p. 205 As noted in 1880 by a friend, the art historian [[Ernest Chesneau]], Știrbei sensed a need for "independence".Chesneau, p. 212 Știrbei was residing in Nice by February 1868, when he attended a gala for the [[European Squadron]], alongside [[Alfred Le Roux]], [[Ludwig II of Bavaria]], and [[Robert I, Duke of Parma|the Duke of Parma]]."Epitome of News. Banquet", in ''[[County Observer and Monmouthshire Central Advertiser]]'', February 8, 1868, p. 6 He still resented the liberals' approach to foreign policy, and, late in 1868, traveled to [[Pest, Hungary|Pest]], [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen|Hungary]], where he was received by the [[Prime Minister of Hungary|Minister-President]], [[Gyula Andrássy]]. Știrbei claimed that the liberals would allow Romania to be invaded by Russia, with Andrássy assuring him that Austria-Hungary would respond militarily, without herself annexing the former Principalities.André Lorant, ''Le compromis austro-hongrois et l'opinion publique française en 1867'', pp. 183–184. Geneva: Librairie Droz, 1971. {{ISBN|978-2-600-03965-9}}. See also Iorga, ''Correspondance'', pp. vii–viii During the final years of the Empire, Știrbei served [[Napoleon III]] as a diplomat, and was made by him a Commander of the [[Legion of Honor]].Chesneau, p. 212 After his departure, the family's political role in the new [[Kingdom of Romania]] was fulfilled by his brother Alexandru, who served as chairman of the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]] and had several ministerial positions.[[Z. Ornea]], ''Junimea și junimismul'', Vol. I, pp. 277, 280, 294, 311, 314. Bucharest: [[Editura Minerva]], 1998. {{ISBN|973-21-0562-3}} ===Bécon withdrawal=== From 1869, ''Beizadea'' George based himself in Paris, purchasing an apartment on [[Boulevard Haussmann]],Badea-Păun, pp. 111 and, in 1871, also an [[Empire style|Empire-style]] ''[[château]]'' in [[Bécon-les-Bruyères]]. The latter had been a temporary home by [[Adolphe Thiers]], and then an [[Orsini family|Orsini]] residence; heavily damaged by the [[Paris Commune]], it was restored and enlarged by its new owner.{{fr icon}} Mylène Sultan, [http://www.lexpress.fr/informations/les-metamorphoses-de-deux-jumelles_725831.html "Les métamorphoses de deux jumelles"], in ''[[L'Express]]'', December 4, 2008Badea-Păun, pp. 111–112. See also Chesneau, p. 213 Settling in France for good, he forfeited his inheritance of the Știrbei Palace on [[Calea Victoriei]], which went to his brothers, alongside the [[Buftea]] estates.Mucenic, pp. 74–75 Instead, he took his parents' residence in Nice and most of Barbu's French assets. The issue, contested between him and his siblings, was settled at the [[Court of Cassation (France)|Court of Cassation]] in 1873. This landmark case imposed on him to share the villa with the other inheritors, with special criteria for calculating the [[inheritance tax]]."Art 19,304. Étranger.—Partage.—Biens français et étrangers.—Attribution des biens français à l'un des copartageants.—Droit de soulte.—Partage testamentaire antérieur, non suivi d'effet", in ''Journal de l'Enregistrement et des Domaines'', No. 2703, December 11, 1873, pp. 551–556 At the time, Știrbei was suing the [[administration of Paris]] for damages to his ''château'', taking [[Jules Favre]] as his lawyer."Informations", in ''Journal de Loiret'', August 13, 1873, p. 2 In 1882, as Paris auctioned off the ruins of [[Tuileries Palace]], also destroyed by the Commune, Știrbei purchased the fence, which became part of Bécon complex.[[G. Lenotre]], ''Paris révolutionnaire'', p. 101. Paris: [[Firmin Didot]], 1895. {{OCLC|919952493}}; Bertrand Tillier, ''La Commune de Paris, révolution sans images? Politique et représentations dans la France républicaine (1871–1914)'', p. 360. Seyssel: Champ Vallon, 2004. {{ISBN|2-87673-390-0}} By 1878, Știrbei was a trustee of Le Temps, a [[life insurance]] provider founded by the Alfred Blanche of the [[Conseil d'État (France)|Conseil d'État]]."Assurances", in ''Annuaire-almanach du Commerce, de l'Industrie, de la Magistrature et de l'Administration'', Vol. 82, 1879, p. 685 His other sources of income included journalism, with opinion pieces that he signed with the pen name "James Caterly",Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 240; Mucenic, p. 74 and with articles in ''[[Journal des Débats]]''. As such, he was immersing himself in French cultural life. According to [[Georges Duval (journalist)|Georges Duval]], the "excellent prince" Știrbei "discreetly rescued the unfortunate, just as he was providing for the talented ones."[[Georges Duval (journalist)|Georges Duval]], ''Mémoires d'un parisien. Première période"'', p. 287. Paris: [[Groupe Flammarion|Flammarion]], [ca. 1913]. {{OCLC|697992494}} During the cultural purge that followed the proclamation of a [[Third French Republic]], Știrbei protected and sponsored sculptor [[Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux]], the aging [[Bonapartist]],Badea-Păun, pp. 112–113 purchasing his various works. In 1875, when the Prince took Carpeaux with him to Nice, painter [[Bruno Chérier]] noted a change for the better: "A fairy and her magic wand could not have pulled it off better in transforming our poor Carpeaux." The two, he recalled, lived in "princely luxury".Guillot, p. 32 Chesneau calls Știrbei a "grand lord by birth and character", who welcomed Carpeaux with "charming familiarity",Chesneau, pp. 211–212 while [[Dugald Sutherland MacColl|D. S. MacColl]] credits him with having "rescued [Carpeaux] from a [[Inferno (Dante)|Dantesque]] misery of disease and squalor."[[Dugald Sutherland MacColl|D. S. MacColl]], "The Centenary of Carpeaux", in ''[[The Burlington Magazine]]'', Vol. 49, No. 282, September 1926, p. 146 In August 1875, when Carpeaux was made Grand Officer of the Legion of Honor, Știrbei was the first to bring him the news, at the church in [[Courbevoie]].[[Loÿs Delteil]], "Carpeaux", in ''Le Peintre Graveur Illustré (XIXe et XXe Siècles)'', Vol. 6 (Rude—Barye—Carpeaux—Rodin), 1910, [n. p.] The artist died a few weeks later at Bécon, "consoled by the touching care of his princely host." Controversially, Știrbei had purchased Carpeaux's drawings (including his study after the cadaver of Victor Liet)Guillot, pp. 21, 43 and his seal of authenticity, which technically allowed him to pass [[plaster cast]] as the originals; for several years, he battled in court with the Carpeaux estate over ownership of these items, ultimately relinquishing the seal.Badea-Păun, pp. 112–113 Before donating the drawings, Știrbei released them as an album, published using [[photoengraving]].Chesneau, p. 189 Carpeaux's tomb was another issue of contention: the Prince had ordered the body to be buried in Courbevoie, giving it a lavish funeral. The widow, who was kept absent from the ceremony, sued and won, taking the remains to [[Valenciennes]].Guillot, p. 42 [[File:Pavillon des Indes - éclairage nocturne.jpg|thumb|340px|[[Caspar Purdon Clarke]]'s Indian pavilion, set up by Știrbei in [[Bécon-les-Bruyères]] ([[Courbevoie]])]] Știrbei was also the patron of [[Rosa Bonheur]][[Theodore Stanton]], "The Religion of Rosa Bonheur", in ''[[The Open Court (journal)|The Open Court]]'', Issue 12/1910, pp. 747–748 and, from 1888, an organizer of the [[Auguste Feyen-Perrin]] collectors' committee."Exposition des œuvres de Feyen-Perrin", in ''La Lorraine Artiste'', No. 48/1888, p. 191 He built up the rest of his art collection with samples from other artists, notably [[Pierre Puvis de Chavannes]], [[Giulio Bergonzoli]], [[Emilio Zocchi]], and [[Gustave Haller|Valérie Simonin]].Badea-Păun, pp. 112, 114 The latter, originally an actress, was married to the playwright [[Gustave-Eugène Fould]] (and was as such the daughter-in-law of Bonapartist [[Achille Fould]]). Știrbei had been a confidant of her husband, who gave his daughter [[Georges Achille Fould|Georges Achille]] a male name in honor of Știrbei.Zafar Masud, [https://www.dawn.com/news/1339721 "Art History: The Art of Architecture"], in ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'', June 18, 2017 Following Gustave's death in 1884, Valérie remained the Prince's close friend, so much so that in 1888 Știrbei adopted both Georges Achille and her other daughter, [[Consuelo Fould]].Badea-Păun, p. 114 From 1885, Știrbei applied for [[French nationality law|naturalization as a French citizen]],Badea-Păun, p. 108 which he obtained in 1888.Lăcusteanu & Crutzescu, p. 240 In 1895, he married Simonin. He took personal care of his adoptive daughters' training in art, allowing them to study with [[Léon Comerre]] and [[Ferdinand Roybet]].Badea-Păun, pp. 114–115 He also bought [[British Raj|India]] and [[Union between Sweden and Norway|Sweden–Norway]]'s pavilions from the [[Exposition Universelle (1878)|1878 World's Fair]] (respectively designed by [[Caspar Purdon Clarke]] and [[Henrik Thrap-Meyer]]), which became their respective studios.{{fr icon}} [http://www.leparisien.fr/espace-premium/hauts-de-seine-92/la-nouvelle-vie-du-pavillon-des-indes-05-05-2015-4745527.php "Hauts-de-Seine. La nouvelle vie du Pavillon des Indes"], in ''[[Le Parisien]]'', May 5, 2015Badea-Păun, pp. 114–115 ===Final decades=== In March 1887, rumors spread that Știrbei intended to replace [[Alexander of Battenberg]] on the [[Principality of Bulgaria|Bulgarian throne]]. According to the ''[[Moskovskiye Vedomosti]]'', he was supported in this by Britain."Edición de la Noche. Últimos telegramas", in ''La Iberia. Diario Liberal'', April 11, 1887, p. 2 Știrbei dismissed such stories, insisting that he had "no intention of reentering the political scene"."Ultime informațiuni", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', March 26 (April 7), 1887, p. 3 During that period of his life, although isolated, Știrbei still entertained Romanian guests, including, in 1888, the journalist [[Alexandru Ciurcu]].[[Alexandru Ciurcu]], "În cestiunea Expozițiunei din 1889", in ''Gazeta Săténului'', Nr. 12/1888, p. 187 Following his brother Alexandru's illness and death in early 1895,Mucenic, pp. 75–76 George also continued to have links with his Romanian family. In 1901, he and his cousin [[Alexandru Bibescu]] helped organize the Paris wedding between Dimitrie Știrbei's daughter, Martha, and Hans von Blome.Félix, "Le Monde et la Ville. Salons", in ''[[Le Figaro]]'', November 18, 1901, p. 2 By then, his large family included numerous figures of importance in politics and literature. Alexandru's children included [[Barbu Știrbey]], the "White Prince", and his brother George, who expanded their father's estate. The "White Prince" in particular reclaimed the family's political role, briefly serving as Prime Minister in 1927. He was famous as the lover of [[List of Romanian consorts|Queen]] [[Marie of Romania]], and alleged father of [[Princess Ileana of Romania|Princess Ileana]]. Barbu's sister [[Eliza Brătianu|Eliza]] was the wife of two other Prime Ministers, [[Alexandru Marghiloman]] and [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]]. Their sisters, who died young, married into the elite: one was the mother of [[George Cretzianu]], and the other the wife of [[Radu R. Rosetti]].[[Radu R. Rosetti]], ''Mărturisiri, I'', pp. 92, 126–127, 191, 194–195. Bucharest: [[Convorbiri Literare]], 1933 The Prince also had pilot [[Marina Știrbei]] for a niece, and, on the Bibescu side, nephews [[George Valentin Bibescu]], the aviation pioneer,{{ro icon}} Constantin Ciopraga, [https://web.archive.org/web/20170902224036/http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/CIOPaug8.html "Anna principesă Brâncoveanu contesă de Noailles"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', August 2008 and [[Antoine Bibesco]], who also lived in France and was famous for his friendship with novelist [[Marcel Proust]].{{ro icon}} Simona Lazăr, [https://web.archive.org/web/20170702142046/http://jurnalul.ro/special-jurnalul/reportaje/printul-alexandru-bibescu-un-sonetist-francez-572252.html "Prințul Alexandru Bibescu, un sonetist francez"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', March 18, 2011 A French grandniece, [[Anna de Noailles]], was celebrated for her literary contributions, especially after 1902. From 1891 to 1902, Știrbei edited a posthumous edition of Weiss' complete works at [[Calmann-Lévy]], followed in 1910 by his monograph ''J.-J. Weiss, conférencier, chroniqueur de théâtre, journaliste''.Badea-Păun, p. 108 His own one-act comedy, ''La légende de Saint Déodat'', came out at [[Firmin Didot]] in 1905, with illustrations by [[Maurice Leloir]]. In 1906, Prince George welcomed to Paris the Romanian student [[Eugen Lovinescu]], directing his own research on J.-J. Weiss.Badea-Păun, pp. 107–108 At the time, as "James Caterly", he published the monograph ''Les Roumains'' (1908), which Lovinescu would translate and publish in Romania in 1909 or 1910.Badea-Păun, p. 108; Filitti, p. 70; Iorga (1910), p. 78 Știrbei's new protege was reserved in his overall opinion of the prince, writing that his Paris home resembled an old "boyar mansion", replete with ''[[objets d'art]]'' from the Orient. These, Lovinescu believed, were there to show that Știrbei missed his Wallachia.Badea-Păun, pp. 107–108 According to Știrbei's own words, he lived "surrounded by memories, by his books, in quiet isolation".Badea-Păun, pp. 111–112 From the 1880s onward, he had slowly divided his art objects were between the [[Louvre]], the [[École des Beaux-Arts]], and the [[Musée des Beaux-Arts d'Angers|Angers]] and [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Valenciennes|Valenciennes Museums]]; others preserved at their original location in Bécon.Badea-Păun, pp. 112–115; Chesneau, p. 189; Guillot, pp. 21, 43 He made the news again in August 1910, when one of his most trusted servants stole his wife's jewelry, worth 18,000 [[French franc]]s, from her apartment on Boulevard de Courcelles."A travers Paris. La perle des valets de chambre", in ''[[Le Matin (France)|Le Matin]]'', August 5, 1910, p. 5 In 1916, at the height of World War I, Știrbei printed his complete works, including memoirs, as ''Feuilles d'automne et feuilles d'hiver''.Badea-Păun, p. 111; Chiper, p. 206; Iorga, ''Correspondance'', p. viii He was a widower from July 1919, when the aged Princess Valérie died at [[Pontaillac]]."Nécrologie" in ''[[Le Gaulois]]'', July 3, 1919, p. 2; "Nouvelles diverses", in ''[[Le Petit Journal (newspaper)|Le Petit Journal]]'', July 3, 1919, p. 3 Știrbei himself died a nonagenarian on the morning of August 15, 1925. His funeral service was held with military honors at the Catholic church of Saint-Charles-de-Monceau, and his burial took place at [[Père Lachaise Cemetery]].Serigny, "Le Monde & la Ville. Deuil", in ''[[Le Figaro]]'', August 18, 1925, p. 2; Valfleury, "Nécrologie" in ''[[Le Gaulois]]'', August 18, 1925, p. 2 In 1926–1928, his daughters were taken to court by the elderly Austrian tenor Georg Schütte Harmsen, who claimed to have been Știrbei's son by a chambermaid. Schütte, who showed records of his Orthodox baptism,"Tribunaux. Autour de la succession du prince Stirbey", in ''L'Homme Libre'', January 12, 1927, p. 3 received a positive verdict in primary court, but died "of joy" upon receiving the news.{{pt icon}} [http://memoria.bn.br/pdf/025909/per025909_1928_00045.pdf "Alegria que mata"], in ''[[Revista da Semana]]'', Nr. 45/1928, p. 6 The Carpeaux controversy was prolonged into the 1930s and beyond by the sculptor's daughter Louise Clémentel, who repeated allegations made about Știrbei in her ''La verité sur l'oeuvre et la vie de Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux''.Badea-Păun, p. 113 In 1928, the Știrbei estate was reportedly worth more than 100 million [[Shilling (British coin)|shilling]]. From this total, Consuelo assigned a special fund to the ''[[Institut de France]]'', which grants an annual Știrbei award.Badea-Păun, p. 113 She and Georges Achille inherited most of the assets, including the pavilions. The sisters had conflicting visions: Consuelo, who died in 1927, bequeathed her pavilion to host a memorial museum for Roybet; twenty years later, the municipality of Courbevoie confiscated the land for its own city museum.Badea-Păun, p. 115 The core buildings of the ''château'' were razed in conjunction with the extension of [[La Défense]], although in the end nothing was built to replace them. The former Swedish pavilion is home to a Roybet museum, which also has art by the Fould–Știrbei sisters. In 2013, the Indian pavilion was restored and, since 2015, has been a studio for [[Artist-in-residence|sculptors-in-residence]]. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *Gabriel Badea-Păun, "Gheorghe Știrbey, un diplomat pasionat de artă", in ''Muzeul Național'', Vol. XX, 2008, pp. 108–115. *[[Barbu Catargiu]], ''Discursuri parlamentare. 1859–1862 iunie 8''. {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Baron | name = Guy Ullens | image = Guy Ullens.jpg | alt = Portrait picture in quarter-profile of Guy Ullens | caption = Ullens at the 2014 [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art|UCCA]] exhibition | birth_name = Guy François Edouard Marie Ullens de Schooten Whettnall | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1935|01|31}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], USA | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Belgian | other_names = | occupation = Businessman, art collector, philanthropist | years_active = | known_for = {{plainlist| * [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art]] * [[Ullens School]]}} | net_worth = {{profit}} '''€250–330 [[million]]''' in 2012<ref name="hln2012" /> | spouse = {{plainlist| * Micheline Franckx (married 1955–1999) * [[Myriam Ullens|Myriam Lechien]] (1999–present) }} | children = 4 }}
Baron '''Guy François Edouard Marie Ullens de Schooten Whettnall''' (born 31 January 1935) is a Belgian [[art collector]], [[philanthropist]], and former businessperson.
Following his business career, he has with his wife, [[Myriam Ullens]], established the Guy & Myriam Ullens Foundation, known for the [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art]] in [[Beijing]], China, and for founding the [[Ullens School]] in [[Lalitpur District, Nepal|Lalitpur]], Nepal.
== Early life == Guy Ullens was born in [[San Francisco]], [[California]] as the third child to Baron Jean Marie Joseph Anne Mathilde Alphonse Ullens de Schooten Whettnall (1897–1950), a Belgian [[diplomat]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Western Machinery and Steel World ... |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QcEiAQAAMAAJ |volume=37 |year=1946 |pages=118– |quote=... Jean Ullens de Schooten. former Belgian Consul to the Port of San Francisco ...}}</ref> and a member of the [[Nobility|noble family]] {{Interlanguage link multi|Ullens|nl}} of the [[Southern Netherlands]]. His mother was ethnographic photographer, writer, and [[Royal Geographical Society]] fellow, Baroness Marie Thérèse Pauline Francis Ullens de Schooten Whettnall ''née'' Wittouck (1905–89), of the Belgium noble family {{Interlanguage link multi|Wittouck|nl}}, a daughter of distilling and sugar magnate {{Interlanguage link multi|Félix Wittouck|fr}}, who together with his brothers {{Interlanguage link multi|Frantz Wittouck|fr|lt=Franz}} and [[Paul Wittouck]] owned the [[Sugar refinery of Tienen]].<ref name="archnet">{{cite web |url=http://archnet.org/authorities/1910 |title=Marie-Thérèse Ullens de Schooten - Archnet |publisher= |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~mus00019 |title=The Marie-Thérèse, Baroness Ullens de Schooten Collections at Harvard University: original ethnographic sound recordings, radio transmissions, and film soundtracks, ca. 1951-1972 |publisher=Harvard University |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
The family moved to [[Oslo]], Norway shortly after Guy was born, where Jean Ullens took up the diplomatic position of acting [[Envoy (title)|Minister]] for Belgium.<ref>{{cite book |title=Weekly Commercial News |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OPMKAQAAIAAJ |volume=89-90 |year=1935 |pages=163– |quote=Jean Ullens de Schooten, consul general for Belgium at San Francisco during the past three years, will leave for home next Saturday preparatory to assuming the position of acting [[Envoy (title)|Minister]] for Belgium at Oslo, Norway. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Schooten and three children, the youngest of which, a son, was born here about one month ago.}}</ref> Over the course of [[World War II]], the family was confined to Berlin,<ref name="(baroness)1989">{{cite book |author=Marie Thérèse Ullens de Schooten (baroness) |title=In perspective |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6n8dAQAAMAAJ |date=1 April 1989 |publisher=United Writers |isbn=978-1-85200-018-9 |pages=41–}}</ref> and later lived in [[India]], [[Pakistan]], and [[Iran]].<ref name="archnet" />
== Education & career == After a degree in law from the [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)|Catholic University of Louvain]], Belgium in 1958,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archives.lesoir.be/guy-ullens-de-schooten_t-20071029-00DJ1Y.html |last=Berkenbaum |first=Philippe |title=L'acteur : Guy Ullens de Schooten |work=Le Soir |date=29 October 2007 |accessdate=21 July 2016|language=French}}</ref> Ullens obtained an MBA at [[Stanford University]] in 1960.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Yatsko |first=Pamela |date=February 2008 |title=Stanford Smarts in China's Art Marts |url=https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/sites/gsb/files/2008February.pdf |magazine=Stanford Business |volume=76 |issue=2 |location= |publisher=[[Stanford University]] |access-date=21 July 2016}}</ref> He started{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Eurocan in [[Mechelen]], Belgium, a company that specialized in the manufacture of metal packagings for preserved foods and beverages.<ref>{{cite book |title=Belgium, Economic and Commercial Information |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=50A-AQAAIAAJ |publisher=Belgian Foreign Trade Office |pages=28– |quote=Eurocan specializes in the manufacture of metal packagings for preserved foods, soups, pet foods and beverages. The company, which is now 25 years old, is one of ...}}</ref>
In 1973, he joined the management of the family company R. T. Holding, a conglomerate in food industries,<ref name="GrunertTraill2012">{{cite book |author1=Klaus Günter Grunert |author2=Bruce Traill |title=Products and Process Innovation in the Food Industry |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HETuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA176 |date=6 December 2012 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=978-1-4613-1133-1 |pages=176–}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Milling and Baking News |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J5wnAQAAMAAJ |series=10-18 |volume=67 |date=May 1988 |publisher=Sosland Pub. |pages=108–}}</ref> and played as [[CEO]] a central role in the company's expansion into Asia.<ref name="WhitesideWilson2012">{{cite book |author1=R. M. Whiteside |author2=A. Wilson |author3=S. E. Hörnig |title=Major Companies of Europe 1990/91: Volume 1 Major Companies of the Continental Europe Economic Community |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M5nuCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA46 |date=6 December 2012 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=978-94-009-0797-3 |pages=46–}}</ref> In 1989, the ''[[Sugar refinery of Tienen|Raffinerie Tirlemontoise]]'' was sold to German company [[Südzucker]] in a €1 billion deal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tijd.be/algemeen/algemeen/Guy_Ullens_Wij_weten_niet_wat_er_gebeurt.5024173-534.art?highlight=ageas |title=Guy Ullens: Wij weten niet wat er gebeurt |work=Tijd.be |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1989/Germany-s-Suedzucker-AG-To-Acquire-Belgian-Sugar-Refinery/id-89757effc7b31fa59a68abd6403dd8ad |title=Germany's Suedzucker AG To Acquire Belgian Sugar Refinery |publisher=AP |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://derijkstebelgen.be/nieuws/de-suikerzoete-miljarden-van-guy-ullens/ |last=Verduyn |first=Ludwig |title=De suikerzoete miljarden van Guy Ullens |work=De Rijkste Belgen |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=Dutch}}</ref>

Weight Watchers is owned by Artal Group, a private company based in Luxembourg.}}</ref> Artal Group subsequently earned US$3.8 billion by selling stocks while retaining a 52% majority stake in Weight Watchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nathanvardi/2012/09/04/the-mystery-man-behind-weight-watchers-and-the-private-equity-deal-of-the-century/#742b8bd72e5c |title=The Mystery Man Behind Weight Watchers And The Private Equity Deal Of The Century |date=4 September 2012 |work=Forbes |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> Guy Ullens told ''[[Forbes]]'' in 2012, that the initial US$224 million direct investment in Weight Watchers had returned US$5.2 billion to Artal Group.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mo.be/nieuws/belastingen-afslanken-luxemburg |first=Kristof |last=Clerix |title=Belastingen afslanken via Luxemburg |work=MO* |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=Dutch}}</ref>
== Philanthropic projects == In 2000, Guy Ullens retired from business to devote himself to philanthropic projects with his wife, Myriam Ullens.<ref name="BernierBernier2008">{{cite book |author1=Georges Bernier |author2=Rosamond Bernier |title=L'Oeil |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ohLsAAAAMAAJ |series=598-601 |year=2008 |pages=13– |quote=2000 Guy se retire de la scène commerciale et se consacre avec son épouse à des activités humanitaires et ...}}</ref>
In 2002 they set up the Guy & Myriam Ullens Foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moneyhouse.ch/en/u/fondation_guy_et_myriam_ullens_CH-621.7.006.691-3.htm |title=Fondation Guy et Myriam Ullens, Orsières – trade register data and business information |publisher=}}</ref> One of the first purposes of the Foundation was to sponsor and organize exhibitions of Chinese art, and to lend pieces to museums and cultural centres around the world.<ref>{{cite book |title=Art and AsiaPacific |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xZHrAAAAMAAJ |volume=3 |year=2008 |publisher=Fine Arts Press |pages=164–}}</ref>
Guy and Myriam Ullens helped children in Nepal by establishing orphanages and two intensive care centres for children with malnutrition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://global-citizen.com/aristocratic-style/ |title=Aristocratic Style – Global Citizen |date=29 March 2015 |publisher=}}</ref> They also set up the [[Ullens School]] Kathmandu, partnering with the Bank Street College of Education to train Nepalese teachers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/printedition/news/2014-11-28/teach-the-children-well.html |title=Teach the children well |publisher=}}</ref> The [[Ullens School]] Kathmandu is the only school in Nepal to be IB certified.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nepalitimes.com/~nepalitimes/news.php?id=16134#.V2lNUZOLTEZ |title="There is no reason why Nepal can't prosper"- Nepali Times |publisher=}}</ref>
When Myriam Ullens was diagnosed with cancer in 2003,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/mimi-ullens-foundations-if-only-for-a-second-2014-10?r=US&IR=T |title=This Heartwarming Cancer Charity Promo Won 9 Of The Ad World's Most Prestigious Awards |publisher=}}</ref> Guy Ullens took over the development of the Nepal project.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oW_f-qpvitQ |title=Speech by Baron Guy Ullens |first= |last=Ullens School |date=30 November 2014 |publisher= |via=YouTube}}</ref>
== Art collection == In the early 1980s,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303376904579137621408186780|last=Lane |first=Mary M. |title=Guy Ullens de Schooten Speaks on Asian Art |date=19 October 2013|work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> Ullens initiated a collection of Chinese art that is one of the worlds largest and by 2007 included nearly 1,700 pieces.<ref>{{cite book |title=Art and AsiaPacific |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_zc0AQAAIAAJ |series=53-56 |year=2007 |publisher=Fine Arts Press |pages=83– |quote=The center's staff will have access to the Ullens' collection of approximately 1,700 pieces of Chinese art, including 200 ... the Ullens Center as well as other philanthropic activities, including the Happy House Foundation for children in Nepal.}}</ref><ref name="Thompson2014">{{cite book |author=Don Thompson |title=The Supermodel and the Brillo Box: Back Stories and Peculiar Economics from the World of Contemporary Art |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sTBkAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA220 |date=27 May 2014 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |isbn=978-1-137-46413-2 |pages=220– |quote=Baron Guy Ullens is the son of a Belgian diplomat; his wealth came from the food industry. In 1984 Ullens and his wife Myriam began to collect Chinese contemporary art in depth. They assembled what was probably one of the two best private ...}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/myriam-and-guy-ullens/ |title=Myriam and Guy Ullens – ARTnews |publisher=}}</ref> The Ullens Collection is managed by the Guy and Myriam Ullens Foundation.<ref name="Elzen2010">{{cite book |author=Sus Van Elzen |title=Dragon and rose garden |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=spIYAQAAMAAJ |date=31 May 2010 |publisher=Modern Chinese Art Foundation |quote=However, the Center will regularly hold exhibitions that will include works from the Ullens collection. ... The Guy and Myriam Ullens Foundation, which owns the art collection and founded UCCA, will probably manage to keep this considerable ...}}</ref>
In 2007, the Foundation established the [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art]] (UCCA) in the [[Dashanzi]] district of Beijing.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/26/arts/design/26ulle.html |title=A Belgian Couple Will Give Beijing a New Home for Contemporary Art |work=The New York Times |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latribune.fr/journal/edition-du-1710/manager-droit/286704/passionnes-d-art-contemporain-chinois-guy-et-myriam-ullens-.html|last=Youssi |first=Yasmine |title=Passionnés d'art contemporain chinois, Guy et Myriam Ullens ...|work=[[La Tribune]] |date=17 October 2009 |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=French}}</ref> In order to establish UCCA, Ullens sold off his collection of [[J. M. W. Turner]] [[watercolour]] paintings for £10.76 million at a [[Sotheby's]] auction in [[London]] in July 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1556558/Turner-watercolours-sold-for-a-painful-10m.html |title=Turner watercolours sold for a 'painful' £10m |date=5 July 2007 |work=Telegraph.co.uk |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="RobertsonChong2008">{{cite book |author1=Iain Alexander Robertson |author2=Derrick Chong |title=The Art Business |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UTDaBLJDOeoC&pg=PA86 |year=2008 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0-415-39157-3 |pages=86– |quote=Others, like Belgium-born, Baron Guy Ullens – sponsor of China's first ever Pavilion at the 2005 Venice Biennale, auctioned fourteen Turner watercolours, at Sotheby's London in July 2007, to realize his dream of the Ullens Center for the Arts ...}}</ref> UCCA was the first not-for-profit art centre in China dedicated to contemporary art.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/our-future-the-guy-and-myriam-ullens-foundation-collection |title=Our Future: The Guy and Myriam Ullens Foundation Collection – e-flux |publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.internationaleonline.org/research/decolonising_practices/33_institutional_fever_in_china |title=Institutional Fever in China |publisher=}}</ref>
In a Sotheby's [[Hong Kong]] auction in April 2011,<ref>{{cite book |title=The Ullens Collection - The Nascence of Avant Garde China: auction, Hong Kong, Pacific Place, Sunday 3 Avril 2011 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_k6pjwEACAAJ |year=2011 |publisher=Sotheby's}}</ref> exclusively featuring 106 works from the Ullens Collection,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/123083/behind-the-ullens-collections-planned-167-sale-at-sothebys |last=O'Dea |first=Madelaine |title=Behind the Ullens Collection's Planned $16.7 Sale at Sotheby's Hong Kong |work=Artinfo |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> [[Zhang Xiaogang]]'s 1988 [[triptych]] oil work ''Forever Lasting Love'', of half-naked figures in an arid landscape suffused with mystical symbols, sold for HK$79 million (US$10.1 million), a record auction price for a contemporary artwork from China, in Hong Kong.<ref>[http://www.rthk.org.hk/rthk/news/englishnews/news.htm?main&20110404&56&745861 Record price paid for contemporary art], RTHK News, 4 April 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12954871 Triptych by Chinese artist Zhang Xiaogang sets record], BBC News, 4 April 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2011/04/04/ullens-collection-sets-a-chinese-art-auction-record/ |title=Ullens Collection Sets a Chinese Art Auction Record |work=WSJ |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
In October 2013, Sotheby's Hong Kong at the Asian Contemporary 40th Anniversary Sale, Ullens put up for sale [[Chen Yifei]]'s political realist work ''Red Flag 1'' (1971), and ''The Last Supper'' (2001) by contemporary Chinese artist [[Zeng Fanzhi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://artdaily.com/news/64766/Sotheby-s-to-offer-two-masterpieces-from-the-Collection-of-Guy-and-Myriam-Ullens-de-Schooten |title=Sotheby's to offer two masterpieces from the Collection of Guy and Myriam Ullens de Schooten |publisher= |accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> ''The Last Supper'' was sold for US$23.3 million, setting a new record for contemporary Asian artwork.<ref>{{cite news |title=Zeng’s ‘Last Supper’ Sells for Record $23.3 Million at Sotheby’s Auction |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2013/10/07/zengs-last-supper-sells-for-record-23-3-million-at-sothebys-auction/ |publisher=WSJ.com |date=7 October 2013}}</ref>
In 2016, Ullens, now in his 80s, announced that he was looking to hand over the UCCA and would sell his art collection at auction.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/1984232/top-chinese-art-contemporary-collector-guy-ullens-hand-over-ucca |title=Top Chinese art contemporary collector Guy Ullens to hand over UCCA museum, sell works |date=1 July 2016 |work=South China Morning Post |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://culturebox.francetvinfo.fr/expositions/peinture/le-collectionneur-guy-ullens-vend-son-musee-d-art-contemporain-de-pekin-242323 |title=Le collectionneur Guy Ullens vend son musée d'art contemporain de Pékin |date=1 July 2016 |work=Culturebox |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lalibre.be/culture/arts/guy-ullens-va-vendre-son-centre-d-art-de-pekin-5776ad8435705701fd93c14a |title=Guy Ullens va vendre son centre d’art de Pékin |publisher= |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arteconomy24.ilsole24ore.com/news/news.php?id=1559&t=ucca-guy-ullens-cerca-un-compratore |title=UCCA; Guy Ullens cerca un compratore - News ArtEconomy24 |work=ArtEconomy - Il Sole 24 ORE |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/guy-ullens-sell-chinese-art-collection-536321|last=Boucher |first=Brian |title=Guy and Myriam Ullens Seek New Owner for UCCA|work=Artnet News |date=30 June 2016 |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-what-will-guy-ullens-s-sale-of-the-ucca-mean-for-the-museum-s-future|last=Arnold |first=Frances |title=What Will Guy Ullens’s Sale of the UCCA Mean for the Museum’s Future?|date=1 July 2016|work=[[Artsy]] |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
On the 11th of February 2017, the [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art]] received the 2016 Global Fine Art Awards for Best Contemporary / Postwar / SoloArtist “Rauschenberg in China”.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artforum.com/news/id=66560|title=Winners of 2016 Global Fine Art Awards Revealed|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucca.org.cn/en/exhibition/robert-rauschenberg-2/|title=Rauschenberg in China - UCCA|date=11 December 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalfineartawards.org/wp/index.php/2016-award-winners/|title=2016 Award Winners ‹ Global Fine Art Awards|website=globalfineartawards.org}}</ref>
== Personal life == Ullens married Micheline Franckx (1932–2015) in 1955. They had four children, and divorced in 1999.
In 1999, Ullens married [[Myriam Ullens|Myriam "Mimi" Lechien]] (born 1952), a Belgian entrepreneur.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://madame.lefigaro.fr/style/myriam-ullens-dame-de-coeur-060114-636960 |title=Myriam Ullens, la dame de cœur |date=6 January 2014 |work=Madame Figaro |accessdate=20 July 2016 |language=French}}</ref>
Ullens is a [[yachtsman]], and owns the 170 ft (51.77 m) long [[flybridge]] aluminium [[sloop]] ''Red Dragon II'' with [[interior design]] by French architect [[Jean-Michel Wilmotte]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Yachting |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51ANij63VVQC&pg=PA156 |date=March 2008 |pages=156–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boatinternational.com/luxury-yacht-life/lifestyle/superyacht-owner-myriam-ullens-opens-first-london-fashion-store--26087 |title=Superyacht owner Myriam Ullens opens first London fashion store |work=Boat International |accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> Build by [[Alloy Yachts]] in New Zealand in 2007 and commissioned in 2008,<ref>{{cite book |title=Yachting |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=12HlXPBCA2sC&pg=PA88 |date=June 2008 |pages=88–}}</ref> the yacht was put up for sale for US$28 million in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boatinternational.com/yachts/editorial-features/new-zealand-built-yachts-for-sale-six-of-the-finest-specimens--1569 |title=New Zealand-built yachts for sale: six of the finest specimens |work=Boat International |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
Ullens lives in [[Verbier]] in south-western [[Switzerland]] in the canton of [[Valais]], where he has been a member of the [[Verbier Festival]] foundation,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lalibre.be/culture/arts/le-beau-reve-chinois-de-guy-ullens-51b894b8e4b0de6db9b03f2d |last=Duplat |first=Guy |title=Le beau rêve chinois de Guy Ullens |work=[[La Libre]] |date=16 August 2007 |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.7sur7.be/7s7/fr/1505/Monde/article/detail/1542293/2012/11/30/L-homme-le-plus-riche-de-Suisse.dhtml |title=L'homme le plus riche de Suisse |work=7s7 |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> and was, according to ''[[Het Laatste Nieuws]]'', worth an estimated €250–330 [[million]] in 2012.<ref name="hln2012">{{cite news |url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/960/Buitenland/article/detail/1542321/2012/11/30/Belgische-baron-op-lijst-van-300-rijksten-in-Zwitserland.dhtml |title=Belgische baron op lijst van 300 rijksten in Zwitserland |work=[[Het Laatste Nieuws]] |accessdate=21 July 2016 |language=Dutch}}</ref>
== Honours == Ullens was appointed Officer of the [[Legion of Honour]] on 4 June 2003,{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Commander of the Legion of Honor on 1 February 2010,{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} and Commander of the [[Order of Leopold II]] on 5 October 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.etaamb.be/nl/koninklijk-besluit_n2012015197.html |title=Koninklijk Besluit nationale orden leopoldsorde bij koninklijk besluit van 13 juli 2012 werden benoemd : commandeur de heer ferdinand carlos leopold de trazegnies granda, oud-minister van buitenlandse zaken van peru, bestuurder van het peruaans filiaal va ridder de heer |publisher= |accessdate=19 July 2016 |language=Dutch}}</ref>
