[http://www.goal.com/en/news/12/spain/2013/05/01/3945400/cruyff-the-man-behind-barcelonas-success-says-guardiola "Cruyff the man behind Barcelona's success, says Guardiola"], Goal.com, 1 May 2013. ==Early life== {{Quote box|width=32%|align=right|quote=I was born shortly after the war, though, and was taught not to just accept anything.|source=—Cruyff said in a documentary on TV3 channel (2015).{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2892/transfer-zone/2015/01/21/8158842/cruyff-i-nearly-joined-real-madrid |author=Coerts, Stefan |title=''Cruyff: I nearly joined Real Madrid'' |publisher=Goal.com |date=21 January 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015 }}}} Hendrik Johannes "Johan" Cruijff was born on 25 April 1947 in [[Amsterdam]], on a street five minutes away from [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]]'s stadium, his first football club. Johan was the second son of Hermanus Cornelis Cruijff and Petronella Bernarda Draaijer, from a humble, working-class background in east Amsterdam. Cruyff, encouraged by his influential football-loving father and his close proximity in Akkerstraat to the De Meer Stadium, played football with his schoolmates and older brother, Henny, whenever he could, and idolised the prolific Dutch dribbler, [[Faas Wilkes]]. In 1959, Cruyff's father died from a heart attack. His father's death had a major impact on his mentality. As Cruyff recalled, in celebration of his 50th birthday, "My father died when I was just 12 and he was 45. From that day the feeling crept stronger over me that I would die at the same age and, when I had serious heart problems when I reached 45, I thought: 'This is it.' Only medical science, which was not available to help my father, kept me alive."{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12327032.display/ |title=Cruyff the positive thinker looks ahead to new lease of football life |publisher=Herald Scotland (www.heraldscotland.com) |date=26 April 1997 |accessdate=26 September 2016 }} Viewing a potential football career as a way of paying tribute to his father, the death inspired the strong-willed Cruyff, who also frequently visited the burial site at Oosterbegraafplaats.{{cite web|url=http://www.benefoot.net/johan-cruijff-a-mortal-with-the-potential-of-a-superman/ |author=Ramesh, Priya |title=''Johan Cruijff: A mortal with the potential of a superman'' |publisher=Benefoot.net |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=9 April 2016 }} His mother began working at Ajax as a cleaner, deciding that she could no longer carry on at the grocer without her husband, and in the future, this made Cruyff near-obsessed with financial security but also gave him an appreciation for player aids. His mother soon met her second husband, Henk Angel, a field hand at Ajax who proved a key influence in Cruyff's life.{{cite web|url=http://backpagefootball.com/johan-cruyff-the-total-voetballer/26050/ |author=Kelly, Ciaran |title=''Johan Cruyff: The Total Voetballer'' |publisher=Back Page Football |date=14 September 2011 |accessdate=20 October 2015 }} ==Playing career== ===Club career=== ====Ajax and the golden era of Total Football==== [[File:Feyenoord tegen Ajax 1-0. Nummer 26 Israel in duel met Cruyff.jpg|thumb|right|Cruyff was instrumental in Ajax's dominance of [[European football]] in the early 1970s. He played for Ajax from 1957 to 1973 and 1981 to 1983 (seen here in 1967 against Feyenoord).]] Cruyff joined the Ajax youth system on his tenth birthday. Cruyff and his friends would frequent a "playground" in their neighbourhood and Ajax youth coach Jany van der Veen, who lived close by, noticed Cruyff's talent and decided to offer him a place at Ajax without a formal trial. He showed talent both on the [[pitcher's mound]] and behind the plate, as a [[catcher (baseball)|catcher]], before having to leave [[Ajax HVA|the club's baseball section]] at age 15 to focus on football.[http://afootballreport.com/post/11609198668/when-the-beautiful-game-met-americas-national-pastime "When The Beautiful Game Met America's National Pastime"]. Football Report. Retrieved 12 May 2014[http://www1.skysports.com/other-sports/news/13873/6312071/i-love-football-cruyff "I love football... Cruyff"]. Sky Sports. Retrieved 12 May 2014 He made his first team debut on 15 November 1964 in the [[Eredivisie]], against [[FC Groningen|GVAV]], scoring the only goal for Ajax in a 3–1 defeat. That year, Ajax finished in their lowest position since the establishment of professional football, in 13th.{{cite web |url=http://www.eredivisie.nl/history/1964–1965.html |title=Historie eredivisie competitie 1964–1965 |access-date=14 September 2016}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}. eredivisie.nl Cruyff really started to make an impression in the 1965–66 season and established himself as a regular first team player after scoring two goals against [[AFC DWS|DWS]] in the Olympic stadium on 24 October 1965 in a 2–0 victory. In the seven games that winter, he scored eight times and in March 1966 scored the first three goals in a league game against Telstar in a 6–2 win. Four days later, in a cup game against [[BV Veendam|Veendam]] in a 7–0 win, he scored four goals. In total that season, Cruyff scored 25 goals in 23 games, and Ajax won the league championship. [[File:Ajax tegen Liverpool 5-1, Johan Cruyff in duel.jpg|thumb|left|Cruyff playing for Ajax taking on [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] defender [[Tommy Smith (footballer, born 1945)|Tommy Smith]] in a European Cup game in December 1966]] In the [[1966–67 Eredivisie|1966–67 season]], Ajax again won the league championship, and also won the [[KNVB Cup]], for Cruyff's first "double". Cruyff ended the season as the leading goalscorer in the Eredivisie with 33. Cruyff won the league for the third successive year in the [[1967–68 Eredivisie|1967–68 season]]. He was also named Dutch footballer of the year for the second successive time, a feat he repeated in 1969. On 28 May 1969, Cruyff played in his first [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] final against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], but the Italians won 4–1. In the [[1969–70 Eredivisie|1969–70 season]], Cruyff won his second league and cup "double"; at the beginning of the [[1970–71 Eredivisie|1970–71 season]], he suffered a groin injury. He made his comeback on 30 October 1970 against [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]], and rather than wear his usual number 9, which was in use by [[Gerrie Mühren]], he instead used number 14. Ajax won 1–0. Although it was very uncommon in those days for the starters of a game not to play with numbers 1 to 11, from that moment onwards, Cruyff wore number 14, even with the [[Netherlands national football team|Dutch national team]]. There was a documentary on Cruyff, ''Nummer 14 Johan Cruyff''{{cite web|url=http://imdb.com/title/tt0070462|title=Nummer 14 Johan Cruyff|work=IMDb.com|accessdate= 18 March 2007}} and in the Netherlands there is a magazine by [[Voetbal International]], ''Nummer 14''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nummer14.nl|title=Nummer 14|work=Nummer14.com|accessdate=18 March 2007}} {{Quote box|width=32%|align=right|quote=Johan Cruyff's miracles in Amsterdam were many. He and his coach [[Rinus Michels]] (a sort of John the Baptist figure) raised Ajax from obscurity. More important, they invented a new way of playing. Cruyff became the greatest exponent and teacher of 'totaalvoetbal' [Total Football]. His vision of perfect movement and harmony on the field was rooted in the same sublime ordering of space that one sees in the pictures of [[Vermeer]] or church painter [[Pieter Jansz Saenredam]]. It was the music of the spheres on grass.|source=—[[David Winner (author)|David Winner]], the author of ''[[Brilliant Orange: The Neurotic Genius of Dutch Football]]''[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/apr/29/barcelona-gospel-of-guardiola ""Barcelona and the gospel of Guardiola (29 April 2012)""]. The Guardian; retrieved 12 June 2014}} In a league game against [[AZ Alkmaar|AZ '67]] on 29 November 1970, Cruyff scored six goals in an 8–1 victory. After winning a replayed KNVB Cup final against [[Sparta Rotterdam]] by a score of 2–1, Ajax won in Europe for the first time. On 2 June 1971, in London, Ajax won the European Cup by defeating [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] 2–0. He signed a seven-year contract at Ajax. At the end of the season, he was named the Dutch and [[European Footballer of the Year]] for 1971. In 1972, Ajax won a second European Cup, beating [[Inter Milan]] 2–0 in the final, with Cruyff scoring both goals. This victory prompted Dutch newspapers to announce the demise of the Italian style of defensive football in the face of [[Total Football]]. ''Soccer: The Ultimate Encyclopaedia'' says, "Single-handed, Cruyff not only pulled Internazionale of Italy apart in the 1972 European Cup Final, but scored both goals in Ajax's 2–0 win."[http://www.ifhof.com/hof/cruyff.asp "Johan Cruyff – Hall of Fame"]. International Football Hall of Fame. Retrieved 16 May 2014 Cruyff also scored in the 3–2 victory over [[ADO Den Haag]] in the KNVB Cup final. In the league, Cruyff was the top scorer with 25 goals as Ajax became champions. Ajax won the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]], beating Argentina's [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] 1–1 in the first game followed by 3–0, and then in January 1973, they won the [[European Super Cup]] by beating [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] 3–1 away and 3–2 in Amsterdam. Cruyff's only own goal came on 20 August 1972 against [[FC Amsterdam]]. A week later, against [[Go Ahead Eagles]] in a 6–0 win, Cruyff scored four times for Ajax. The [[1972–73 Eredivisie|1972–73 season]] was concluded with another league championship victory and a third successive European Cup with a 1–0 win over [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] in the final, with the ''Encyclopedia'' stating Cruyff "inspired one of the greatest 20-minute spells of football ever seen". ====Barcelona and the first La Liga title in 14 years==== {{Quote box|width=32%|align=left|quote=When players like [Gareth] [[Gareth Bale|Bale]] and [Cristiano] [[Cristiano Ronaldo|Ronaldo]] are worth around €100 million, Johan [Cruyff] would go in the billions!|source=—[[Franz Beckenbauer]], in an interview with ''[[Bild.de]]'' (September 2014) about Cruyff's transfer value in the early 1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.bild.de/sport/fussball/franz-beckenbauer/cruyff-barcelona-immer-groesser-als-bayern-37721032.bild.html |author=Feindt, Henning |title=Franz Beckenbauer & Johan Cruyff: Der FC Barcelona wird immer größer als der FC Bayern sein |publisher=[[Bild|Bild.de]] |quote=[[Franz Beckenbauer]]: "Wenn Spieler wie Bale oder Ronaldo um die 100 Millionen wert sind, würde es bei Johan in die Milliarden gehen!" [Original in German] |date=19 September 2014 |accessdate=29 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/15/german-football/2014/09/19/5118003/beckenbauer-if-bale-and-ronaldo-are-worth-100m-cruyff-would |author=Tooth, John-Paul |title=Beckenbauer: If Bale and Ronaldo are worth €100m, Cruyff would be worth billions |publisher=Goal.com |date= 19 September 2014 |accessdate=29 September 2016 }}}} [[File:Cruijff met de beker van de derde prijs, Bestanddeelnr 928-0928.jpg|thumb|upright|Cruyff played for [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] from 1973–1978]] In mid-1973, Cruyff was sold to [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] for 6 million [[Dutch gulden|guilders]] (approx. US$2 million, c. 1973) in a [[World football transfer record|world record transfer fee]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23903470 "The history of the world transfer record"]. BBC News. Retrieved 1 May 2014 On 19 August 1973, he played his last match for Ajax where they defeated FC Amsterdam 6–1, the second match of the 1973–74 season. Cruyff endeared himself to the Barcelona fans when he chose a Catalan name, Jordi, for his son. He helped the club win [[La Liga]] for the first time since 1960, defeating their [[El Clásico|deadliest rivals]] [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] 5–0 at their home of the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium|Santiago Bernabéu]]. Thousands of Barcelona fans who watched the match on television poured out of their homes to join in street celebrations.Jimmy Burns (2011). "Barça: A People's Passion". Bloomsbury Publishing, A ''[[New York Times]]'' journalist wrote that Cruyff had done more for the spirit of the [[Catalonia|Catalan]] people in 90 minutes than many politicians in years of struggle. Football historian Jimmy Burns stated, "with Cruyff, the team felt they couldn’t lose". He gave them speed, flexibility and a sense of themselves. In 1974 Cruyff was crowned European Footballer of the Year. During his time at Barcelona, Cruyff scored one of his most famous goals, "The 'Phantom' Goal".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2mme7xdbTeE |title=Cruyff: A Legend |publisher=YouTube |accessdate= 20 April 2010}} In a game against [[Atlético Madrid]], Cruyff leapt into the air, twisted his body so he was facing away from the goal, and kicked the ball past [[Miguel Reina]] in the Atlético goal with his right heel (the ball was at about neck height and had already travelled wide of the far post). The goal was featured in the documentary ''{{lang|es|En un momento dado}}'', in which fans of Cruyff attempted to recreate that moment. The goal has been dubbed ''{{lang|es|Le but impossible de Cruyff}}'' (Cruyff's impossible goal).Heinz Duthel. "FC Barcelona-Barça: Futbol Club Barcelona. Barça o Blaugrana" p.120 In 1978, Barcelona defeated [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]] 3–1, to win the [[1978 Copa del Rey Final|Copa del Rey]]. Cruyff played two games with [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] in 1975 during the Paris tournament. He had only agreed because he was a fan of designer [[Daniel Hechter]], who was then president of PSG.{{cite web|url=http://www.sport-vintage.com/Library/team%20french/PSG/Johan%20Cruyff%20au%20PSG%20%2C%20avec%20Jean%20Pierre%20Dogliani%20et%20Just%20Fontaine%201975.JPG |title=JPG image |accessdate=23 April 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716121127/http://www.sport-vintage.com/Library/team%20french/PSG/Johan%20Cruyff%20au%20PSG%20%2C%20avec%20Jean%20Pierre%20Dogliani%20et%20Just%20Fontaine%201975.JPG |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}. sport-vintage.com[http://24.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_m68w4idXk21ru2ag8o1_400.jpg JPG image]. tumblr.com; accessed 24 October 2015. ====Brief retirement and spells in the United States==== Cruyff nearly retired in 1978. But after losing most of his money in a series of ill-advised investments — including, to the merriment of the Dutch press, a pig farm — that were counseled by a scam artist who had possibly seduced his wife, Cruyff and his family came to the United States.{{cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_uk/article/johan-cruyff39s-complicated-legacy-uk-translation |author=Schaerlaeckens, Leander |title=Johan Cruyff's Complicated Legacy |publisher=VICE Sports |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }} As he recalled, "I had lost millions in pig-farming and that was the reason I decided to become a footballer again." Cruyff insisted that his decision to resume his playing career in the United States was pivotal in his career. "It was wrong, a mistake, to quit playing at 31 with the unique talent I possessed", and adding that "Starting from zero in America, many miles away from my past, was one of the best decisions I made. There I learned how to develop my uncontrolled ambitions, to think as a coach and about sponsorship." At the age of 32, Cruyff signed a lucrative deal with the [[Los Angeles Aztecs]] of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] (NASL). He had previously been rumoured to be joining the [[New York Cosmos (1971–85)|New York Cosmos]] but the deal did not materialize; he played a few exhibition games for the Cosmos. He stayed at the Aztecs for only one season, and was voted [[NASL Most Valuable Player Award|NASL Player of the Year]]. The following season, he moved to play for the [[Washington Diplomats]]. He played the whole 1980 campaign for the Diplomats, even as the team was facing dire financial trouble. In May 1981, Cruyff played as a guest player for Milan in a tournament, but was injured. As a result, he missed the beginning of the 1981 NASL soccer season, which ultimately led to Cruyff choosing to leave the team. Cruyff also loathed playing on artificial surfaces, which were common in the NASL at the time. ====Return to Spain with Levante==== In January 1981, Cruyff played three friendly matches for [[FC Dordrecht]]. Also in January 1981, manager [[Jock Wallace, Jr.|Jock Wallace]] of English club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] made an attempt to sign Cruyff, and despite negotiations lasting three weeks, in which Cruyff expressed his desire to play for the club, a deal could not be reached. Cruyff instead chose to sign with Spanish [[Segunda División]] side [[Levante UD|Levante]].{{cite news|title=Just how close were Leicester City to signing Dutch master Johan Cruyff?|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Just-close-Leicester-City-signing-Dutch-master-Johan-Cruyff/story-12048983-detail/story.html|publisher=www.leicestermercury.co.uk|date=23 October 2009|accessdate=27 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201321/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Just-close-Leicester-City-signing-Dutch-master-Johan-Cruyff/story-12048983-detail/story.html|archivedate=29 October 2013}} In March 1981, Cruyff took the field for the first time for Levante. Injuries and disagreements with the administration of the club, however, blighted his spell in the Segunda División, and he only made ten appearances, scoring two goals. Having failed to secure promotion to the first division, a contract with Levante fell through. ====Second spell at Ajax==== [[File:Johan Cruijff met Japanse fans.jpg|thumb|Johan Cruyff with Japanese fans in 1982]] After his spell in the U.S. and a short-lived stay in Spain, Cruyff returned to play in his homeland, rejoining Ajax on 30 November 1980 as "technical advisor" to trainer [[Leo Beenhakker]], Ajax being eighth in the league table at the time after 13 games played. After 34 games, however, Ajax finished the [[1980–81 Eredivisie|1980–81 season]] in second. In December 1981, Cruyff signed a contract extension with Ajax.Scott Murray, Rowan Walker (2008). "Day of the Match: A History of Football in 365 Days". p. 271. Pan Macmillan, 2008 In the [[1981–82 Eredivisie|1981–82]] and [[1982–83 Eredivisie|1982–83]] seasons, Ajax, along with Cruyff, became league champions. In 1982–83, Ajax won the Dutch Cup (KNVB-Beker). In 1982, he scored a famous goal against [[Helmond Sport]]. While playing for Ajax, Cruyff scored a penalty the same way [[Rik Coppens]] had done it 25 years earlier.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/oct/26/theknowledge.sport|title=Who took the first two-man penalty?|date=26 October 2005|work=The Guardian|accessdate=26 March 2010|location=London, UK|first=James|last=Dart}}{{cite web|url=http://sportscene.excite.co.uk/brazilians-recreate-cruyff-penalty-to-show-pires-and-henry-how-its-done-N2328.html|title=Brazilians recreate Cruyff penalty to show Pires and Henry how it's done|publisher=Excite|date=30 March 2008|accessdate=28 October 2013}} He put the ball down as for a routine penalty kick, but instead of shooting at goal, Cruyff nudged the ball sideways to teammate [[Jesper Olsen]], who in return passed it back to Cruyff to tap the ball into the empty net, as Otto Versfeld, the Helmond goalkeeper, looked on. [[File:Feyenoord tegen PEC, met afscheid Johan Cruyff ; Johan Cruyff op de schouders van Wijnstekers en Brand.jpg|thumb|left|Cruyff's farewell at Feyenoord]] ====Final season at Feyenoord and retirement==== At the end of the 1982–83 season, Ajax decided not to offer Cruyff a new contract. This angered Cruyff, who responded by signing for Ajax's archrivals [[Feyenoord]].{{cite web|url=http://cruyff.com/asp/eng/werkenleven.asp?page=speler-fey|title=Playing for Feyenoord|work=Cruyff.com|accessdate=28 October 2013}} Cruyff's season at Feyenoord was a successful one in which the club won the Eredivisie for the first time in a decade, part of a [[1983–84 Eredivisie|league]] and [[1983–84 KNVB Cup|KNVB Cup]] double. The team's success was due to the performances of Cruyff along with [[Ruud Gullit]] and [[Peter Houtman]].Mik Schots (2013). "Feyenoord-Ajax: gezworen vijanden". Singel Uitgeverijen Despite his relatively advanced age, Cruyff played all league matches that season except for one. Because of his performance on the field, he was voted as Dutch Footballer of the Year for the fifth time. At the end of the season, the veteran announced his final retirement. He ended his Eredivisie playing career on 13 May 1984 with a goal against [[PEC Zwolle]]. Cruyff played his last game in Saudi Arabia against [[Al-Ahli SC (Jeddah)|Al-Ahli]], bringing Feyenoord back into the game with a goal and an assist.{{cite web|url=http://fm.manutd.nl/de-echte-afscheidswedstrijd-van-cruijff|title=De echte afscheidswedstrijd van Cruijff|publisher=Football United|date=20 July 2009|language=Dutch}}{{clear}} ===International career=== [[File:Oefeninterland Nederland tegen Argentinië 4-1; nr. 6, 7 Cruyff, kop.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Cruyff as captain of the Netherlands prior to a game at the 1974 World Cup]] As a Dutch international, Cruyff played 48 [[Cap (sport)|matches]], scoring 33 goals.{{cite news|title=The total footballer|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/football/features/newsid_3301000/3301407.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 July 2014}} The national team never lost a match in which Cruyff scored. On 7 September 1966, he made his official debut for the Netherlands in the [[UEFA Euro 1968]] [[UEFA Euro 1968 qualifying|qualifier]] against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], scoring in the 2–2 draw. In his second match, a friendly against [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]], Cruyff was the first Dutch international to receive a [[Misconduct (football)|red card]]. The [[Royal Dutch Football Association]] (KNVB) banned him from Ajax games but not internationals.David Winner (2012). "Brilliant Orange: The Neurotic Genius of Dutch Football". A&C Black Accusations of Cruyff's "aloofness" were not rebuffed by his habit of wearing a shirt with only two black stripes along the sleeves, as opposed to [[Adidas]]' usual design feature of three, worn by all the other Dutch players. Cruyff had a separate sponsorship deal with [[Puma SE|Puma]].{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/may/30/theknowledge.sport | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Scott | last1=Murray | first2=Sean | last2=Ingle | title=A tale of strips, stripes and strops | date=30 May 2001}} From 1970 onwards, he wore the number 14 jersey for the Netherlands, setting a trend for wearing shirt numbers outside the usual starting line-up numbers of 1 to 11. ====1974 FIFA World Cup==== Cruyff led the Netherlands to a runners-up medal in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 World Cup]] and was named [[Golden Ball (FIFA)|player of the tournament]]. Thanks to his team's mastery of Total Football, they coasted all the way to the final, knocking out [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] (4–0), [[East Germany national football team|East Germany]] (2–0) and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] (2–0) along the way. Cruyff scored twice against Argentina in one of his team's most dominating performances, then he scored the second goal against Brazil to knock out the defending champions. The Netherlands faced hosts [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] in the final. Cruyff kicked off and the ball was passed around the ''Oranje'' team 15 times before returning to Cruyff, who then went on a run past [[Berti Vogts]] and ended when he was fouled by [[Uli Hoeneß]] inside the box. Teammate [[Johan Neeskens]] scored from the spot kick to give the Netherlands a 1–0 lead and the Germans had not yet touched the ball. During the latter half of the final, his influence was stifled by the effective marking of Vogts, while [[Franz Beckenbauer]], Uli Hoeneß and [[Wolfgang Overath]] dominated the midfield as West Germany came back to win 2–1.{{cite web|url=http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/p/pwc/1974.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070320083442/http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/p/pwc/1974.html|archivedate=20 March 2007|title=Germany 1974|publisher=FIFAWorldCup.yahoo.com|accessdate=28 October 2013}} [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-N0716-0314, Fußball-WM, BRD - Niederlande 2-1.jpg|thumb|right|Cruyff in the box during the [[1974 FIFA World Cup Final|1974 World Cup Final]], just before he was fouled for a penalty]] In an interview published in the 50th anniversary issue of ''[[World Soccer (magazine)|World Soccer]]'' magazine, the captain of the Brazilian team that won the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970 World Cup]], [[Carlos Alberto Torres|Carlos Alberto]], went on to say, "The only team I've seen that did things differently was Holland at the 1974 World Cup in Germany. Since then everything looks more or less the same to me.... Their 'carousel' style of play was amazing to watch and marvellous for the game."{{cite web|url=http://www.tomwfootball.com/2010/10/15/tactics-were-holland-1974-the-last-true-innovators|title=Tactics: Were Holland 1974 the last true innovators?|publisher=Football Further|date=14 July 2010|accessdate=18 October 2010}} With regards to role models, Brazilian football manager and former player [[Telê Santana]] has mentioned in one interview that he had no idols, though, "My greatest satisfaction would be to manage a team such as 1974 Holland. It was a team where you could pick [Johan] Cruyff and place him on the right wing. If I had to put him in the left-wing, he would still play [the same]. I could choose Neeskens, who played both to the right and to the left of the midfield. Thus, everyone played in any position."{{cite web|title=Memória Roda Viva (video clip and full written interview to TV Cultura)|url=http://www.rodaviva.fapesp.br/materia/160/entrevistados/tele_santana_1992.htm|accessdate=21 June 2010|date=22 June 1992|publisher=Fapesp|language=Portuguese}} ====After 1974==== Cruyff retired from international football in October 1977, having helped the national team qualify for the upcoming World Cup. Without him, the Netherlands finished runners-up in the World Cup again. Initially, the reason given for missing the [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978 World Cup]] were political reasons given [[National Reorganization Process|a military dictatorship was in power]] in Argentina at that time. In 2008, Cruyff stated to the journalist Antoni Bassas in [[Catalunya Ràdio]] that he and his family were subject to a kidnap attempt in Barcelona a year before the tournament, and that this had caused his retirement. "To play a World Cup you have to be 200% okay, there are moments when there are other values in life."{{cite news|url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2273925,00.html|work=The Guardian|title=Kidnappers made Cruyff miss World Cup|date=16 April 2008|accessdate=26 March 2010|location=London, UK|first=Paul|last=Doyle}} ==Coaching career== ===Entry into management with Ajax=== [[File:Training Ajax, Cruijff (r) en algemeen directeur Arie van Eijden tijdens perscon, Bestanddeelnr 934-1215.jpg|thumb|left|Cruyff as manager of Ajax in 1987]] After retiring from playing, Cruyff followed in the footsteps of his mentor [[Rinus Michels]], coaching a young Ajax side to victory in the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]] in [[1987 European Cup Winners' Cup Final|1987]] (1–0). In May and June 1985, Cruyff returned to Ajax again. In the [[1985–86 Eredivisie|1985–86 season]], the league title was lost to [[Jan Reker]]'s PSV, despite Ajax having a goal difference of +85 (120 goals for, 35 goals against). In the 1985–86 and [[1986–87 Eredivisie|1986–87]] seasons, Ajax won the KNVB Cup. {{Quote box|width=32%|align=right|quote=If you look at the greatest players in history, most of them couldn’t coach. If you look at the greatest coaches in history, most of them were not great players. Johan Cruyff did both – and in such an exhilarating style.|source=—Former Dutch international [[Johan Neeskens]][https://www.fifa.com/news/y=2016/m=3/news=farewell-to-football-s-thriller-incomparable-2772199.html ""Farewell to football's thriller incomparable (24 March 2016)""]. FIFA.com; retrieved 10 June 2016}} It was during this period as manager that Cruyff was able to implement his favoured team formation—three mobile [[Defender (association football)|defenders]]; plus one more covering space – becoming, in effect, a [[Midfielder|defensive midfielder]] (from [[Frank Rijkaard|Rijkaard]], [[Danny Blind|Blind]], [[Sonny Silooy|Silooy]], [[Frank Verlaat|Verlaat]], [[Peter Larsson (footballer, born 1961)|Larsson]], [[Ronald Spelbos|Spelbos]]), two "controlling" midfielders (from Rijkaard, [[Arnold Scholten|Scholten]], [[Aron Winter|Winter]], [[Jan Wouters|Wouters]], [[Arnold Mühren|Mühren]], [[Rob Witschge|Witschge]]) with responsibilities to feed the attack-minded players, one [[Forward (association football)|second striker]] ([[John Bosman|Bosman]], Scholten), two touchline-hugging [[Winger (football)|wingers]] (from [[Dennis Bergkamp|Bergkamp]], [[John van't Schip|van't Schip]], [[Rob de Wit (footballer)|De Wit]], [[Richard Witschge|Witschge]]) and one versatile centre forward (from [[Marco van Basten|Van Basten]], [[Henny Meijer|Meijer]], Bosman). So successful was this system that Ajax won the [[1995 UEFA Champions League Final|Champions League in 1995]] playing Cruyff's system – a tribute to Cruyff's legacy as Ajax coach. ===Return to Barcelona as manager=== [[File:La Masia (Can Planas) (Barcelona) - 1.jpg|thumb|left|Main façade of old [[La Masia]], the name of FC Barcelona's football training facilities and often used to generically describe the Barcelona [[youth academy]]. La Masia academy was the brainchild of Cruyff.]] After having appeared for the club as a player, Cruyff returned to Barcelona for the [[1988–89 FC Barcelona season|1988–89 season]], this time to take up his new role as coach of the first team. Before returning to Barcelona, however, Cruyff had already built up plenty of experience as a coach/manager. In the Netherlands, he was strongly praised for the attacking flair he imposed on his sides and also for his commendable work as talent spotter, discovering, for example Marco van Basten and Dennis Bergkamp. With Barça, Cruyff started work with a completely remodelled side after the previous season's scandal, known as the "Hesperia Mutiny". His second in command was [[Carles Rexach]], who had already been at the club for a year. Cruyff immediately had his Barça charges playing his attractive brand of football and the results did not take long in coming. But, this did not just happen with the first team, the youth teams also displayed that same attacking style, something that made it easier for reserve players to make the switch to first team football.{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/club/history/card/johan-cruyff-1988-96 |title=FC Barcelona: Johan Cruyff (1988–96) |publisher=FCBarcelona.com |accessdate=9 September 2016 }} As [[Sid Lowe]] noted, when Cruyff took over as manager, Barcelona of the late 1980s "were a club in debt and in crisis. Results were bad, performances were worse, the atmosphere terrible and attendances down, while even the relationship between the [[President of FC Barcelona|president of the club]] [[Josep Lluís Núñez]] and the [[President of the Generalitat de Catalunya|president of the Spanish autonomous community]] they represented, [[Jordi Pujol]], had deteriorated. It did not work immediately but he [Cruyff] recovered the identity he had embodied as a player. He took risks, and rewards followed." At Barça, Cruyff brought in players such as [[Pep Guardiola]], [[José Mari Bakero]], [[Txiki Begiristain]], [[Ion Andoni Goikoetxea|Andoni Goikoetxea]], [[Ronald Koeman]], [[Michael Laudrup]], [[Romário]], [[Gheorghe Hagi]] and [[Hristo Stoichkov]]. With Cruyff, Barça experienced a glorious era. In the space of five years (1989–1994), he led the club to four European finals (two [[European Cup Winners' Cup]] finals and two European Cup/UEFA Champions League finals). Cruyff's track record includes one European Cup, four Liga championships, one Cup Winners' Cup, one Copa del Rey and four Supercopa de España.{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/club/history/card/1988-the-return-of-johan-cruyff |title=FC Barcelona: 1988. The Return of Johan Cruyff, A New Management Model |publisher=FCBarcelona.com |accessdate=9 September 2016 }} Under Cruyff, Barça's "[[FC Barcelona#Dream Team|Dream Team]]" won four La Liga titles in a row (1991–1994), and beat [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]] in both the [[1989 European Cup Winners' Cup Final|1989 European Cup Winners' Cup final]] and the [[1992 European Cup Final|1992 European Cup final]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]]. On 10 May 1989, goals from Salinas and López Rekarte led Barcelona to a 2–0 victory against Sampdoria. Over 25,000 supporters travelled to Switzerland to support the team. Cruyff's new Barça took home the club's third Cup Winners' Cup. The European Cup dream became a reality on 20 May 1992 at Wembley in London, when Barça beat Sampdoria. Cruyff's last instruction to his players before they stepped onto the pitch was "''Salid y disfrutad''" (Spanish for "Go out and enjoy it" or "Go out there and enjoy yourselves").{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/club/history/card/1988-1996-the-era-of-the-dream-team |title=FC Barcelona: 1988–1996. The era of the 'Dream Team' |publisher=FCBarcelona.com |accessdate=9 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/why-cruyff-matters |author= Murray, Andrew |title=Johan Cruyff was one of football's greatest trailblazers on and off pitch |work=FourFourTwo.com |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 August 2016 }} The match went to extra time after a scoreless draw. In the 111th minute, Ronald Koeman's brilliant free kick clinched Barça's first European Cup victory. Twenty-five thousand supporters accompanied the team to Wembley, while one million turned out on the streets of Barcelona to welcome the European champions home. Victories under Cruyff include a 5–0 La Liga win over Real Madrid in ''El Clásico'' at the Camp Nou, as well as a 4–0 win against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the Champions League.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/9004492/Strikers-trademark-goals-the-Thierry-Henry-control-and-place-the-Romario-toe-poke-and-more.html "Strikers' trademark goals: the Thierry Henry control-and-place, the Romario toe-poke and more"]. ''The Daily Telegraph'' (London). Retrieved 27 March 2016[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/champions-league/8541598/Manchester-United-v-Barcelona-six-of-their-best-showdowns.html "Manchester United v Barcelona: six of their best showdowns"]. ''The Daily Telegraph'' (London). Retrieved 27 March 2016 Barcelona won a Copa del Rey in [[1989–90 Copa del Rey|1990]], the European Super Cup in [[1992 European Super Cup|1992]] and three [[Supercopa de España]], as well as finishing runner-up to Manchester United and Milan in two European finals.{{cite news|title=Barcelona v Milan revisited: The night in 1994 the Dream died|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2012/mar/28/barcelona-milan-champions-league-1994|work=The Guardian|date=15 March 2015}} The legacy that Cruyff gave Barcelona, however, was about more than just [[List of FC Barcelona records and statistics|trophies and records]], as he gave Barça a winning mentality and footballing identity/ideology that runs through the club till this day. As Barcelona manager, he laid systemic foundations for a prominent school of football: "Barçajax school" or "Barça-Ajax school", as it has been termed by many. The predominant style of play, now known as ''[[tiki-taka]]'' or ''[[tiqui-taca]]'', had been transferred and improved from Ajax to Barça. It was that which has sustained Barcelona since the days of [[Vic Buckingham]], Rinus Michels and Cruyff (as player) in the early 1970s: they were the ideas of Ajax; Total Football, a predominant belief in [[Ball possession|possession-oriented]] football with an attack-minded [[Formation (association football)#3.E2.80.934.E2.80.933|3–4–3]]/[[formation (association football)#4–3–3|4–3–3]] [[formation (association football)|team formation]], rooted in a high offside line, pressing and the interchange of players on the field. When Cruyff became Barcelona's manager in 1988, he reinforced this footballing philosophy.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/dec/22/devil-and-jose-mourinho |author=[[Jonathan Wilson (writer)|Wilson, Jonathan]] |title=The devil and José Mourinho |work=The Guardian |date=22 December 2015 |accessdate=22 July 2016 }} He was also responsible for introducing "rondos" (a circle of players pass the ball to each other, while one in the centre tries to catch it) into the team's training sessions. About Cruyff's lasting influence on Barça's [[youth academy]] ''[[La Masia]]'', [[Guillem Balagué]] noted, "Cruyff demanded changes at the academy and La Masía began regularly producing the players he wanted as well as providing the kids with a sound education, dual ambitions of the Dutch coach and the club. "The player who has come through La Masía has something different from the rest, it's a plus that only comes from having competed in a Barcelona shirt from the time you were a child", says Guardiola. He is talking not only about the understanding of the game and their ability, but about human qualities. The players who go through La Masía are taught to behave with civility and humility. The theory being that, not only is it pleasant to be unassuming, but also if you are humble, you are capable of learning – and the capacity to learn is the capacity to improve. If you aren't capable of learning you won't improve. Since his arrival, Johan had tried and succeeded in convincing the club to train all the junior teams in the same way as the first eleven – and to favour talent over physique."[[Guillem Balagué|Balagué, Guillem]] (2013). ''Pep Guardiola: Another Way of Winning. The Biography'' (Orion Publishing Group, {{ISBN|978-1409129462}}) Cruyff used to smoke 20 [[cigarette]]s a day prior to undergoing double heart bypass surgery in 1991 while he was the coach of Barcelona, after which he gave up smoking. He also led the anti-smoking campaign developed by the Health Department of the Catalan autonomous government. Cruyff juggled a cigarette pack 16 times in an anti-tobacco video sponsored by the Catalan Department of Health.{{cite book|title=The Global Art of Soccer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H2T0ZD5S86QC|date=2006|publisher=CusiBoy Publishing|isbn=978-0-9776688-0-9}} With 11 trophies, Cruyff was Barcelona's most successful manager, but has since been surpassed by his former player Pep Guardiola, who achieved 15. Cruyff was also the club's longest-serving manager. In his final two seasons, however, he failed to win any trophies, falling-out with chairman Josep Lluís Núñez, who ultimately sacked him as Barcelona coach.[http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/how-johan-cruyff-reinvented-modern-football-barcelona#CPGeYMEFgHwelzsP.99 "How Johan Cruyff reinvented modern football at Barcelona"], ''FourFourTwo.com''; retrieved 24 October 2015. While still at Barcelona, Cruyff was in negotiations with the KNVB to manage the national team for the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]] finals, but talks broke off at the last minute.{{cite web |url=http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/p/cp/ned/cruyff.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314235850/http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/p/cp/ned/cruyff.html |archivedate=14 March 2007 |title=Profile on FIFAWorldCup.yahoo.com |accessdate=28 October 2013}} ===Catalonia national team=== [[File:Cruyff Catalunya 2013.jpg|thumb|Cruyff with the [[Catalonia national football team|Catalonia national team]] in January 2013]] As well as representing Catalonia on the pitch in 1976, Cruyff also managed the [[Catalonia national football team|Catalonia national team]] from 2009 to 2013, leading the team to a victory over [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in his debut match.{{cite web|url=http://www.punditarena.com/football/european-football/ehallissey/catalonia-greatest-team-youve-never-seen/ |author=Hallissey, Eoin |title=Catalonia – The Greatest Team You've Never Seen |publisher=Pundit Arena |date=29 July 2014 |accessdate=29 July 2016 }} On 2 November 2009, Cruyff was named as manager of the Catalonia national team. It was his first managing job for 13 years.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8338289.stm|title=Cruyff will coach Catalonia team|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 November 2009|accessdate=28 October 2013}} On 22 December 2009, they played a friendly game against Argentina, which ended in a Catalonia win, 4–2 at Camp Nou. On 28 December 2010, Catalonia played a friendly against [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]] winning 4–0 at [[Estadi Olímpic Lluís Companys]].[http://www.laprensa.hn/Deportes/Ediciones/2010/12/28/Noticias/Cataluna-le-paso-por-encima-a-Honduras "Catalonia defeats Honduras"]. La Prensa.hn (Honduran national newspaper). 29 December 2010. On 30 December 2011, Catalonia played [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] in a goalless draw at the Lluís Companys.[http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/deportes/catalunya-empata-con-tunez-ante-mas-36000-espectadores-1296261.htm "Catalonia draws with Tunisia"]. El Periódico de Catalunya (Catalionian newspaper) 31 December 2011. In their last game under Cruyff, on 2 January 2013, Catalonia drew with Nigeria at the [[Estadi Cornellà-El Prat|Cornellà-El Prat]], 1–1.{{cite web|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/deportes/catalunya-empata-nigeria-despedida-cruyff-2285524|title=Catalunya empata con Nigeria en la despedida de Cruyff.|publisher=ElPeriodico.com|date=2 January 2013|accessdate=2 January 2013}} ==Other football-related activities== ===As a technical advisor=== ====Unofficial advisor to Barcelona president Joan Laporta==== {{quote|I chose Frank Rijkaard, [[Txiki Begiristain]] and Pep Guardiola because Johan told me to.|Joan Laporta, in an interview (March 2017){{cite web|url=http://en.as.com/en/2017/03/16/football/1489668098_953494.html |title=Laporta: Next Barcelona coach must follow Cruyff's philosophy |publisher=[[Diario AS|AS.com]] |date=16 March 2017 |accessdate=26 May 2017 }}}} Later in his reign as Barcelona manager, Cruyff suffered a heart attack and was advised to quit coaching by his doctors. He left in 1996, and never took another top job, but his influence did not end there. Though he vowed never to coach again, he remained a vocal football critic and analyst. Cruyff's open support helped candidate [[Joan Laporta]] to victory in Barcelona's presidential elections. He continued to be an adviser for him, although he held no official post at Barcelona.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1717/editorial/2011/11/26/2774421/jose-mourinho-at-barcelona-how-the-real-madrid-coach-almost |publisher=Goal.com |author=Hayward, Ben |title=Jose Mourinho at Barcelona – how the Real Madrid coach almost ended up back at Camp Nou |date=26 November 2011 |accessdate=26 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/sport/football/article1682001.ece |author=Hawkey, Ian |title=Cruyff: Visionary who showed us Spain's got talent |publisher=The Sunday Times (thesundaytimes.co.uk) |quote=As Joan Laporta, the president of Barcelona who appointed Rijkaard and Guardiola, recalled: "It was Johan who recommended Frank as coach and who told me that Pep was ready to manage the first team." Cruyff did not need to be on Barcelona's payroll to shape the fortunes of the club. |date=27 March 2016 |accessdate=27 July 2016 }} Back in an advisory capacity alongside Joan Laporta, he recommended the appointment of Frank Rijkaard in 2003. Again Barca was successful, winning back-to-back league titles and another Champions League crown in 2006. After two relatively disappointing campaigns, Laporta survived a censure motion and an overhaul was needed. In summer 2008, Rijkaard left the club and even though [[José Mourinho]] was pushing for the job at Camp Nou, Cruyff chose Pep Guardiola. Many were quick to point to Guardiola's lack of coaching experience, but Cruyff said, "The biggest test for a coach at a team like Barça is the strength to make decisions and the ability to talk to the press, because they don't help and you have to manage that. After that, it's easy for those who know football. But there aren't many who know."{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/1956/europe/2016/03/24/21659412/how-cruyff-changed-the-modern-game |author=Hayward, Ben |title=How Cruyff changed the modern game |publisher=Goal.com |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016 }} On 26 March 2010, Cruyff was named honorary president of Barcelona in recognition of his contributions to the club as both a player and manager.{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/web/english/noticies/club/temporada09-10/03/26/n100326110082.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120730165648/http://www.fcbarcelona.com/web/english/noticies/club/temporada09-10/03/26/n100326110082.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 July 2012|title=Johan Cruyff named Honorary President|publisher=FC Barcelona|accessdate=26 March 2007|date=26 March 2007}} In July 2010, however, he was stripped of this title by new president [[Sandro Rosell]].{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=807580&sec=europe&cc=5739|title=Cruyff unimpressed by Barça 'circus'|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=10 July 2010|accessdate=11 July 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jul/02/johan-cruyff-barcelona-president|title=Johan Cruyff stripped of Barcelona honorary president title|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=10 July 2010|accessdate=11 July 2010|location=London, UK}} ====Return to Ajax as technical director==== On 20 February 2008, in the wake of a major research on the ten-year-mismanagement, it was announced that Cruyff would be the new [[Director of football|technical director]] at his boyhood club Ajax, his fourth stint with the Amsterdam club.{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/european_football/article3406177.ece|title=Johan Cruyff answers distress call from the club where legend was created|accessdate=29 February 2008|date=21 February 2008|work=The Times|first=Kaveh|last=Solhekol|location=London, UK}} Cruyff announced in March that he was pulling out of his planned return to Ajax because of "professional difference of opinion" between him and Ajax's new manager, Marco van Basten. Van Basten said that Cruyff's plans were "going too fast", because he was "not so dissatisfied with how things are going now".{{cite web|url=http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/news/478560/cruyff-pulls-out-of-ajax-youth-revamp|title=Cruyff pulls out of planned Ajax youth revamp|accessdate=9 February 2012|date=7 March 2008|work=The world game, via AAP|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828163405/http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/news/478560/cruyff-pulls-out-of-ajax-youth-revamp#|archive-date=28 August 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}, published by Cruyff Foundation. On 11 February 2011, Cruyff returned to Ajax on an advisory basis after agreeing to become a member of one of three "sounding board groups".{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/johan-cruyff-returns-to-ajax-2211750.html|location=London, UK|work=The Independent|date=11 February 2011|title=Johan Cruyff returns to Ajax}} After presenting his plans to reform the club, in particular to rejuvenate the youth academy, the Ajax board of advisors and the CEO resigned on 30 March 2011.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/mar/30/ajax-johan-cruyff-football-resign |title=Ajax board of directors resign after disagreement with Johan Cruyff |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=25 October 2015}} On 6 June 2011, he was appointed to the new Ajax board of advisors to implent his reform plans.{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.nl/sport/2530578/davids-en-cruijff-in-nieuwe-raad-van-commissarissen-ajax.html |title=Davids en Cruijff in nieuwe raad van commissarissen Ajax |work=Nu.nl |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=25 October 2015}}{{cite news|title=Cruijff en Davids benoemd in bestuur Ajax|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2698/Sport/article/detail/2442224/2011/06/06/Cruijff-en-Davids-benoemd-in-bestuur-Ajax.dhtml|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=[[Volkskrant]]|date=6 June 2011}} The Ajax advisory board made a verbal agreement with [[Louis van Gaal]] to appoint him as the new CEO, without consulting Cruyff.{{cite web|agency=Associated Press|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/feb/07/louis-van-gaal-banned-ajax|title=Louis van Gaal banned from being appointed Ajax CEO|work=The Guardian|accessdate=25 October 2015}}{{cite news|last=Meijer|first=Maarten|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2703389/Louis-van-Gaal-vs-Johan-Cruyff-bitter-feud-started-Christmas-lunch.html|title=Louis van Gaal vs Johan Cruyff: bitter feud started at Christmas lunch|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=25 October 2015}} Cruyff, a fellow board member, took Ajax to court in an attempt to block the appointment.{{cite web|agency=Associated Press|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/dec/07/johan-cruyff-louis-van-gaal|title=Johan Cruyff in court to fight Ajax appointment of Louis van Gaal|work=The
