What Dutch football and Cruyff's generation has created is ‘let's be bold enough to play offensive football and let's defend it,’ no matter what happens. I think that is a very generous idea because it starts from the fact that you want to express yourselves and give pleasure to the people sitting in the stands. The only respect you can give to the people in the stands is, at least at the start, to give them some pleasure and transform our game into art." |date=31 March 2016 |accessdate=18 June 2016 }} and Jürgen Klinsmann. *'''[[Estadi Johan Cruyff]]''', FC Barcelona's under-construction stadium is to be named after Cruyff. *'''[[Johan Cruyff Arena]]''' (Dutch: Johan Cruijff Arena), previously known as the [[Amsterdam Arena]]. ===In popular culture=== In 2018, Cruyff was added as an icon to the Ultimate Team in [[EA Sports]]’ [[FIFA (video game series)|''FIFA'']] video game ''[[FIFA 19]]'', receiving a 94 rating.{{cite news |title=FIFA 19 Ultimate Team: What Icons are in the new game and how do you get them? |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/news/fifa-19-ultimate-team-what-icons-are-in-the-new-game-and-how/1qrv1f9kllmhd12ffdqdmfy91j |accessdate=12 September 2018 |publisher=''Goal''}} British sportswriter David Winner's 2000 book on Dutch football, ''Brilliant Orange'', mentions Cruyff frequently. In the book, Dutch football's ideas (in particular Cruyff's) effectively related to the use of space in [[Dutch art|Dutch painting]] and [[Dutch architecture]]. In 1976, the Italian-language [[documentary film]] ''Il profeta del gol'' was directed by Sandro Ciotti. The documentary narrates the successes of Johan Cruyff's football career in the 1970s. In 2004, the documentary film ''Johan Cruijff – En un momento dado'' ("''Johan Cruijff – At Any Given Moment''") was made by Ramon Gieling and charts the years Cruyff spent at Barcelona, the club where he had the most profound effect in both a footballing and cultural sense. In 2014, the Catalan-language documentary film ''L'últim partit: 40 anys de Johan Cruyff a Catalunya'' was directed by Jordi Marcos, celebrating 40 years since Johan Cruyff signed for Barcelona in August 1973. British rock band [[The Hours (band)|The Hours]] recorded a song called "Love You More" in 2007. In it lead singer [[Antony Genn]] described his partner as "Better than [[Elvis Presley|Elvis]] in his '68 comeback, Better than Cruyff in '74..", In an interview with German daily ''[[Sueddeutsche Zeitung]]'' in 2008, when [[German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] was discussing the upcoming Euro 2008, she praised Cruyff's performance at the 1974 World Cup: "Cruyff really impressed me. I think I wasn't the only one in Europe."{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/sport/interview-mit-angela-merkel-ballack-saechselt-wenigstens-noch-1.200643-2 |title= Interview mit Angela Merkel – "Ballack sächselt wenigstens noch" |publisher=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] (sueddeutsche.de) |quote=[[Angela Merkel]]: "Cruyff hat mich beeindruckt. Ich glaube, ich war auch nicht die Einzige in Europa." [Original in German] |date=17 May 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2016 }} Cruyff stood out at the 1974 World Cup in [[West Germany]] which Merkel watched from her then home country [[East Germany]].[http://www.dw.com/en/chancellor-leaves-cruyff-crush-behind-to-follow-germany/a-3395967 Chancellor Leaves Cruyff Crush Behind to Follow Germany (DW.com, 07.06.2008)] In February 2014, President of Israel [[Shimon Peres]], at his residence in [[Jerusalem]], welcomed Cruyff and praising [[Johan Cruyff Foundation|his foundation]]'s dedication to peace, "People remember very well that not only were you an outstanding football player but that you gave football a social content, you made it an educational process. You are a role model. Football is one of the great ways to make peace among people. When a player like you arrives in our country the eyes of the children light up—Jewish, Arab or Muslim."{{cite web |url=http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/israel/society/140223-peres-cheers-football-legend-s-peacemaking-assist |title=Peres cheers football legend's peacemaking assist |publisher=[[i24news|i24news.tv]] |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815121018/http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/israel/society/140223-peres-cheers-football-legend-s-peacemaking-assist# |archive-date=15 August 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In the Netherlands, and to some extent Spain, Cruyff is famous for his one-liners that usually hover between brilliant insight and the blatantly obvious. They are famous for their Amsterdam dialect and incorrect grammar, and often feature [[tautology (rhetoric)|tautologies]] and [[paradoxes]].Guus Middag and Kees van der Zwan, [http://www.cruyff.com/asp/ned/werkenleven.asp?page=fenomeen-cruyffanders-taalgebruik "Utopieën wie nooit gebeuren". De taal van Johan Cruijff] ("Utopias who never happen". The language of Johan Cruijff), Genootschap Onze Taal In Spain, his most famous statement is ''"En un momento dado"'' ("In any given moment"). The quote has been used for the title of a 2004 documentary about Cruyff's life: ''Johan Cruijff – En un momento dado''. In the Netherlands, his most famous one-liner is ''"Ieder nadeel heb z'n voordeel''" ("Every disadvantage has its advantage") and his way of expressing himself has been dubbed "[[Cruijffiaans]]". Cruyff rarely limited himself to a single line though, and in a comparison with the equally oracular but reserved football manager Rinus Michels, [[Kees Fens]] equated Cruyff's monologues to experimental prose, "without a subject, only an attempt to drop words in a sea of uncertainty (...) there is no full stop". He had a small hit (number 21 in the charts) in the Netherlands with "[[Oei Oei Oei (Dat Was Me Weer Een Loei)]]". Upon arriving in Barcelona, the Spanish branch of [[Polydor]] decided to release the single in Spain as well, where it was rather popular.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/aug/22/theknowledge.sport|title=Does Shay Given really carry holy water with him at every match?|work=The Guardian|date=22 August 2007|accessdate=26 March 2010|location=London, UK|first=James|last=Dart}} Cruyff suffered a [[heart attack]] (like his father who died of a heart attack when he was 12) in his early forties. He used to smoke 20 [[cigarettes]] a day prior to undergoing double heart bypass surgery in 1991 while he was the coach of Barcelona. Cruyff was forced to immediately give up [[smoking]], and he made an [[anti-smoking]] advertisement for the Catalan Department of Health. In the [[TV spot]], Cruyff is dressed like a manager in a long trench coat combined with collared shirt and [[necktie|tie]]. He juggled a [[cigarette pack]] 16 times – using feet, thighs, chest, shoulder, and head like holding up a [[ball (association football)|ball]] – before [[volley (football)|volleying]] it away. Throughout the commercial he speaks in Catalan about the dangers of smoking.Witzig, Richard (2006). ''The Global Art of Soccer''. (CusiBoy Publishing, {{ISBN|9780977668809}}), p. 123 In November 2003, Cruyff invoked legal proceedings against the publisher Tirion Uitgevers, over its photo book ''Johan Cruyff de Ajacied'' ("''Johan Cruijff the Ajax player''"), which used photographs by Guus de Jong. Cruyff was working on another book, also using De Jong's photographs, and claimed unsuccessfully that Tirion's book violated his [[trademark]] and [[portrait]] rights. In 2004, a public poll in the Netherlands to determine the greatest [[Dutch people|Dutchman]] ("''[[De Grootste Nederlander]]''") named Cruyff the 6th-greatest Dutchman of all time, with Cruyff finishing above [[Rembrandt]] (9th) and [[Vincent van Gogh]] (10th).[http://www.geschiedenis24.nl/speler.program.7055644.html "De Grootste Nederlander Deel 6: Johan Cruijff"]; retrieved 9 September 2014. In 2010, the [[asteroid]] ([[minor planet]]) ''[[:de:(14282) Cruijff|14282 Cruijff (2097 P-L)]]'' was named after him. The [[International Astronomical Union]] (IAU) officially ratified the naming of Cruijff on 23 September 2010. After [[Josef Bican]] and Ferenc Puskás, Cruyff is the third football player to have an asteroid named after him.[http://www.xs4all.nl/~carlkop/ecruijff.html JOHAN CRUIJFF CONTINUES TO PLAY FOOTBALL IN OUTER SPACE; Minor planet 14282 now named "Cruijff"], Xs4all.nl; retrieved 18 January 2013.[http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/628/other-top-stories/2010/09/23/2133073/asteroid-named-after-netherlands-barcelona-legend-johan Asteroid Named After Netherlands & Barcelona Legend Johan Cruyff]. Goal.com (23 September 2010); retrieved on 18 January 2013. ==Nicknames== There were many [[nicknames]] Cruyff had in the Netherlands and Spain, including "Jopie", "Nummer 14",{{cite web|url=https://www.rnw.org/archive/johan-cruijffs-14-lives |title= Johan Cruijff's 14 lives |publisher=RNW Media (Radio Netherlands Worldwide) |quote=Cruijff began his career at Ajax with the number 9. After a long injury, in 1970 he came back wearing the number 14, which he kept for the rest of his football career. When Cruijff turned 60, Ajax honoured him by deciding not to allow any other player to use the number 14 ever again. |accessdate=20 July 2016 }} "Het orakel van Betondorp" (the prophet of Betondorp), "El Salvador" (The Saviour), and "El Flaco" (The Skinny One). One of his best known nicknames was "El Salvador" or "The Saviour", a nickname he received during the 1973–74 season and again in 1988, when he helped terminate crisis eras in Barça's history.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/espn-fc-united-blog/68/post/2529129/johan-cruyff-influence-at-ajax-and-barcelona |author=Kuper, Simon |title=Johan Cruyff influence at Ajax and Barcelona |publisher=ESPN FC |quote=[[Simon Kuper]]: "In 1973, 1988 and 2003 he [Cruyff] came to save a struggling club seeking direction." |date=23 July 2015 |accessdate=23 July 2016 }} ==Outside football== ===Hobbies=== Outside football, Cruyff's favourite sport (and hobby) was [[golf]].{{cite web|url=https://www.thecourier.co.uk/news/111749/johan-cruyffs-goal-is-clear-at-dunhill-links-championship/ |title=Johan Cruyff's goal is clear at Dunhill Links Championship |publisher=The Courier (thecourier.co.uk) |date=4 September 2012 |accessdate=24 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/sport/scotlandinternational/7028823/Gordon-Strachans-superhero-tribute-to-legend-Johan-Cruyff.html |title=Gordon Strachan's 'superhero' tribute to legend Johan Cruyff |publisher= The Scottish Sun (thescottishsun.co.uk) |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/teams/st-mirren/when-johan-cruyff-came-to-paisley-1-4083277 |author=Halliday, Stephen |title= When Johan Cruyff came to Paisley |work=The Scotsman |date=27 March 2016 |accessdate=27 September 2016 }} In the 1970s, Cruyff loved to collect cars. In the Sandro Ciotti's documentary film ''Il Profeta del gol'' (1976), Cruyff said, "I like to drive for the 20 km that separate the training camp from my house, it relaxes me. I love the cars."{{cite web|url=http://www.nssmag.com/en/pills/8440/stile-johan-cruyff |title= Johan Cruyff's Style, New Sport Side |publisher=NssMagazine (NSSMag.com) |author=Abazia, Francesco |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=10 July 2016}} ===Business ventures=== In 1979, Cruyff was reaching the twilight of his career in Barcelona. He began to imagine creating a range of [[footwear]] himself to challenge the technical and luxury qualities of those on the market beforehand. After a few years of trying and failing to encourage big [[sportswear (fashion)|sportswear]] brands to take his idea seriously, after all this was quite an unusual ambition of a professional sportsman at the time. Eventually he combined with his close friend, Italian designer Emilio Lazzarini, and using his knowledge he set out to create a technical shoe which managed to balance functionality with elegance. Initially the range was filled with "luxury" indoor football shoes, but they quickly became used as a fashion shoe due to their attractive appearance. And so Cruyff Classics brand was born.{{cite web|url=https://www.cruyffclassics.com/en/historia |title=Cruyff Classics: history of the brand |publisher=Cruyff Classics official website |accessdate=2 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.worldofjohancruyff.com/cruyff-classics/ |title= Cruyff Classics |publisher= Johan Cruyff Management (worldofjohancruyff.com) |accessdate=2 July 2016 }} ===Writing=== Cruyff is the author/co-author of several books (in Dutch and Spanish) about his football career, in particular his principles and view about the football world. He also wrote his weekly columns for ''[[El Periódico de Catalunya|El Periódico]]'' (Barcelona-based newspaper) and ''[[De Telegraaf]]'' (Amsterdam-based newspaper).{{cite web|url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2016/03/25/dutch-newspapers-pay-tribute-to-football-legend-johan-cruijff/ |author=Pieters, Janene |title=Dutch newspapers pay tribute to football legend Johan Cruijff |publisher=NL Times (nltimes.nl) |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }} Cruyff was a [[multilingual]], as British football writer [[Brian Glanville]] described, "his intelligence off the field as well as on it was quite remarkable. How well I remember seeing Cruyff surrounded by journalists from all over the world in 1978 to whose questions he replied almost casually in a multiplicity of languages. Not only Dutch, but English, French, Spanish and German."{{cite web|url=http://www.sportstarlive.com/columns/kickingaround-brian-glanville/goodbye-mr-total-football/article8409301.ece |author=[[Brian Glanville|Glanville, Brian]] |title=Goodbye Mr. Total Football |publisher=Sportstarlive.com |date=15 June 2016 |accessdate=25 August 2016 }} ==Philanthropy== The [[Johan Cruyff Foundation]][http://www.cruyff-foundation.org Johan Cruyff Foundation], cruyff-foundation.org; accessed 25 October 2015. has provided over 200 Cruyff courts in 22 countries, including Israel, Malaysia, Japan, United States and Mexico, for children of all backgrounds to play street football together. [[UEFA]] praised the foundation for its positive effect on young people, and Cruyff received the UEFA Grassroots Award on the opening of the 100th court in late 2009.[http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=ned/news/newsid=1789173.html "Johan Cruyff celebrates his 65th birthday"], FIFA.com; retrieved 21 March 2015. In 1999, he founded the [[Johan Cruyff Institute]] with a program for 35 athletes as part of the Johan Cruyff University of Amsterdam and has since become a global network.{{cite web|title=Johan Cruyff Institute: About us|url=http://cruyffinstitute.org/en/about-us/|publisher=Cruyffinstitute.org|accessdate=25 October 2015}} ==Personality== {{Quote box|width=32%|align=right|quote=I haven't always been understood. As a footballer, as coach and also for what I did after all that. But OK, [[Rembrandt]] and [[Vincent van Gogh|Van Gogh]] weren't understood either. That's what you learn: people go on bothering you until you're a genius.|source=—Johan Cruyff in his ''My Turn: The Autobiography''Cruyff, Johan (Oct 2016). ''My Turn: The Autobiography'' (Pan Macmillan, {{ISBN|9781509813902}})}} Born in the heavily damaged [[Netherlands in World War II|post–World War II Netherlands]], Cruyff came from a humble background and lost his father as a child. This had a great influence on his future career and character. He was renowned for his strong [[personality]]. His character, both in and beyond the footballing world, was much described as the complicated combination of an idealist,{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/telesport/voetbal/20044900/__Johan_Cruijff__Rebel_en_idealist__.html |author=de Groot, Jaap |title= Johan Cruijff: Rebel en idealist |publisher=Telegraaf.nl |date=25 April 2012 |accessdate=25 August 2016 }} individualist, libertarian, collectivist, romantic, purist, pragmatist, rebel,{{cite web|url=http://www.newstalk.com/elko-born-on-cruyff-legacy |author=Born, Elko |title=How Cruyff became more of an "ultimate hero" to the Dutch than any artist, king or queen |publisher=Newstalk.com |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 August 2016 }} and even despot.{{cite web|url=http://www.iris-france.org/78968-johan-cruyff-genie-pop-et-despote-3-questions-a-cherif-ghemmour/ |author=Boniface, Pascal |title=Johan Cruyff – génie pop et despote » – 3 questions à Chérif Ghemmour |publisher=Iris-France.org (Institut de Relations Internationales et Stratégiques) |date=29 August 2016 |accessdate=19 September 2016 }} Dutch sportswriter [[Johan Derksen]], a close friend of Cruyff, once said of him, "Johan [Cruijff] is absolutely religious, though he never goes to church."{{cite web|url=http://www.cip.nl/nieuws/maart-2016/55508-johan-cruijf-van-god-heb-ik-een-hoop-kwaliteiten-gehad |title= Cruijf: Van God heb ik een hoop kwaliteiten gehad |publisher=CIP.nl (Christelijke Informatie Platform) |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }} In August 1973, Ajax players voted for [[Piet Keizer]] to be the team's captain in a secret ballot, ahead of Cruyff. And Cruyff decided his time in Amsterdam had come to an end. He joined Barcelona just weeks later, two years before the Spanish dictator [[Francisco Franco]] died, maintaining to the European press corps en route that he chose Barcelona over rivals Real Madrid because he could never join a club "[[Francoist Spain|associated with Franco]]".Fitzpatrick, Richard (2012). ''El Clásico: Barcelona v Real Madrid: Football's Greatest Rivalry''. (Bloomsbury Publishing) As he recalled in a documentary on TV3 channel, "I remember my move to Spain was quite controversial. (...) The president of Ajax wanted to sell me to Real Madrid, (...) Barcelona weren't at the same level as Madrid football wise, but it was a challenge to play for a Catalan club. Barcelona was more than a club."{{cite web|url=http://www.football-oranje.com/cruyff-almost-joined-real-madrid/ |author=Dhingra, Himanshu |title=''Cruyff: I almost joined Real Madrid'' |publisher=Football Oranje |date=21 January 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015 }} At the end of the 1982–83 season, Ajax decided not to offer Cruyff a new contract. This angered Cruyff and he responded by signing for [[De Klassieker|Ajax's archrivals]] Feyenoord. Cruyff's season at Feyenoord was a successful one in which the club won the Eredivisie for the first time in a decade, part of a league and KNVB Cup double. Cruyff's strong personality played a historical role in the eternal struggle between [[Puma SE|Puma]] and [[Adidas]], the two rival brands that were born from the political divisions between the two Dassler brothers. Cruyff was a big fan of [[Puma SE|Puma]]'s ''King'' boots and by 1974 had signed a sponsorship deal with German sportswear and equipment supplier. At the 1974 World Cup, Johan Cruyff was under contract with Puma in a deal that prohibited him from promoting other sports brands. As the tournament approached, Cruyff flatly refused to wear [[Adidas]]'s trademark three black stripes on his No. 14 jersey. The Netherlands national football association had little choice but to honor the wishes of their best player, and Dutch officials eventually persuaded Adidas to design a separate jersey just for Cruyff, with just two stripes running along the sleeves.{{cite web|url= http://www.puma-catchup.com/johan-cruyff-dont-want-to-wear-adidas/ |title=Johan Cruyff – don't want to wear ADIDAS |publisher=PUMA CATch up (puma-catchup.com) |date=4 November 2015 |accessdate=12 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/johan-cruyff-dead-why-cruyff-refused-to-wear-the-trademark-three-stripes-of-adidas-at-the-1974-world-a6950181.html |author=Orr, James |title=Why Cruyff refused to wear the trademark three stripes of Adidas at the 1974 World Cup |work=The Independent |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=12 July 2016 }} ===Jersey number 14=== [[File:Finale wereldkampioenschap voetbal 1974 in Munchen, West Duitsland tegen Nederland 2-1; Cruyff verlaat het veld.jpg|thumb|right|Cruyff wearing number 14, the number most identified with him.]] Until the 1990s, players did not have fixed numbering — except in some short competitions like the World Cup or European Championship where players were given a designated number. The starting players usually wore jerseys from 1 to 11 and the substitutes, from 12 to 16. Cruyff's usual number was 9. On 30 October 1970, Cruyff was coming back from a long-time injury to play Ajax's bitter rivals PSV. However, in the locker room before the match, teammate [[Gerrie Muhren]] couldn't find his jersey number 7. Cruyff offered his shirt to Muhren and went to the basket to pick another one at random. It happened to be the number 14. Ajax won 1–0 and Cruyff suggested they keep the same numbers to the following game — according to Muhren, on an interview to ''Voetbal International'', it was a form to challenge the Dutch Football Association.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/why-did-johan-cruyff-wear-number-14-a6950206.html |author=Sheen, Tom |title=Johan Cruyff: Why the Dutch master wore the famous number 14 shirt |publisher=Independent.co.uk |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017 }} From then on, Cruyff kept using the number 14 for Ajax and Netherlands national team when he was allowed to. In the [[1974 FIFA World Cup]], Netherlands' head coach Rinus Michels wanted his squad to wear numbers alphabetically. As Cruyff was the first player on roster, he would be number 1, but he refused and insisted to wear his lucky number 14. Forward Ruud Geels ended up with the No 1 shirt while goalkeeper [[Jan Jongbloed]] played as the number 8. Although the number 14 had become a trademark for Cruyff, he could be seen wearing his old number 9 on other occasions, like on most of his career for [[FC Barcelona]], because the league demanded starting players were numbered 1 to 11,{{cite web|url=http://www.sport-english.com/en/news/barca/why-did-the-late-great-johan-cruyff-wear-the-shirt-5004795 |author=Giraldo, Javier |title=Why did the late, great Johan Cruyff wear the No 14 shirt? |publisher=sport-english.com |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2017 }} or for Netherlands in the [[UEFA Euro 1976|1976 European Championship]]. In 2007, Ajax retired Cruyff’s number 14. ===Relations with others=== Cruyff had remained a highly controversial figure throughout his life. Cruyff's relationships with Ajax, Barça, and [[KNVB]] ([[Royal Dutch Football Association]]) were turbulent for some time, especially in his later years. Also, in his native Netherlands, there has been always a [[love-hate relationship]] between Cruyff and his fellow countrymen.{{cite web|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/johan-cruyff-icon |author=[[Simon Kuper|Kuper, Simon]] |title=Johan Cruyff: The player, the coach, the legacy. [Originally appeared in the July 2009 issue] |work=FourFourTwo |quote=Simon Kuper: "...he [Cruyff] loved money with the passion of a man who had grown up without it, (...) When Cruyff returned to Ajax in 1981, the Dutch were sceptical. The Calvinist Holland of the time distrusted anyone who thought he was special. Cruyff had never been popular at home, where he was known as ‘Nose’ or ‘The Moneywolf’. By now he was 34, with a broken body. Surely he was coming back for the money?" |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=18 July 2016 }} There was a long-standing feud between Cruyff and Louis van Gaal, though never confirmed publicly by both sides.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1717/editorial/2011/11/19/2763273/louis-van-gaal-johan-cruyff-clash-of-personalities-spells |author=Coerts, Stefan |title=Louis van Gaal & Johan Cruyff – Clash of personalities spells disaster for Ajax |publisher=Goal.com |date=19 November 2011 |accessdate=29 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2703389/Louis-van-Gaal-vs-Johan-Cruyff-bitter-feud-started-Christmas-lunch.html |author=Meijer, Maarten |title=Louis van Gaal vs Johan Cruyff: bitter feud started at Christmas lunch |work=Daily Mail |date=23 July 2014 |accessdate=23 September 2016 }} He also often criticised [[José Mourinho]] for his defensive-based coaching philosophy, stated, "José Mourinho is a negative coach. He only cares about the result and doesn't care much for good football." As [[David Winner (author)|David Winner]] notes, "Cruyff has had many enemies and critics over the years." He has been accused of being arrogant, greedy, intolerant, despotic, "too idealistic, too stubborn, insufficiently interested in defending and simply too difficult a personality. He loves an argument, and his conflict-model method of working can be bruising." And Winner concludes that, "With his belief in the "conflict model" – the idea that you got the best out of people by provoking fights and thereby raising levels of excitement and adrenaline – Cruyff made enemies almost as easily as he generated delight. Battles with club presidents and teammates led to ruptures, especially at Ajax and Barcelona, the two clubs that defined his career." ===Criticism=== Cruyff was also well known for his vocal [[criticism]] and uncompromising attitude. A [[perfectionism (psychology)|perfectionist]], he always had a strong opinion about things and was even loyal to his principles more than any thing else in the football world.{{cite web|url=http://www.newstalk.com/Johan-Cruyffs-views-on-the-2010-World-Cup-final-shows-how-much-he-valued-Total-Football |author=Kelly, Daniel |title=Johan Cruyff's views on the 2010 World Cup final shows how much he valued Total Football |publisher=Newstalk.com |date=26 March 2016 |accessdate=26 July 2016}} As an outspoken and critical visionary, he strongly criticized the Netherlands' style of play at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]]. "Who am I supporting? I am Dutch but I support the football that Spain is playing. [[Tiki-taka|Spain's style is the style of Barcelona]]... Spain, a replica of Barça, is the best publicity for football", Cruyff wrote in his weekly column for the Barcelona-based newspaper ''[[El Periódico de Catalunya|El Periodico]]'', prior to the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final|final match]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2890/world-cup-2010/2010/07/08/2016282/world-cup-2010-dutch-legend-johan-cruyff-views-spain-as |author=Malek, Cyrus C. |title=''World Cup 2010: Dutch legend Johan Cruyff views Spain as final favourites'' |publisher=Goal.com |date=8 July 2010 |accessdate=20 October 2015 }} Until the early 2010s, Barcelona had mounting debts, built up over the past few seasons, a situation that forced the club to push through an emergency bailout loan of €150 million. The [[Qatar Foundation]], run by [[Sheikha Mozah Bint Nasser Al Missned|Sheikha Mozah]], became the first shirt sponsor in Barcelona's 111-year history. The club had previously used [[UNICEF]]'s logo on the front of its shirts.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/12/spanish-football/2011/04/22/2452965/qatar-foundation-deal-may-have-kept-messi-at-barcelona-but |author=McLean, Andrew |title=Qatar Foundation deal may have kept Messi at Barcelona but Cruyff believes club has become vulgar |publisher=Goal.com |date=22 April 2011 |accessdate=22 July 2016 }} In 2011, incoming Barcelona president [[Sandro Rosell]] agreed the deal for a period of five seasons, with the club receiving €30 million each year, starting on 1 July 2011 and running until 30 June 2016, plus bonuses for trophies won that could total €5m.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1717/editorial/2011/09/05/2651299/more-than-just-a-logo-barcelona-fans-need-to-back-qatar |author=Hayward, Ben |title=More than just a logo – Barcelona fans need to back Qatar Foundation in order to stay ahead of Real Madrid |publisher= Goal.com |date=5 September 2011 |accessdate=5 August 2016 }} Writing in his ''[[El Periódico de Catalunya|El Periodico]]'' column, Cruyff slammed the deal, "We are a unique club in the world, no one has kept their jersey intact throughout their history, yet have remained as competitive as they come... We have sold this uniqueness for about six percent of our budget. I understand that we are currently losing more than we are earning. However, by selling the shirt it shows me that we are not being creative, and that we have become vulgar."{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/12/spanish-football/2010/12/13/2259034/barcelona-legend-johan-cruyff-criticises-clubs-shirt-sponsorship-|author=Macdonald, Paul |title= Barcelona Legend Johan Cruyff Criticises Club's Shirt Sponsorship Deal With Qatar Foundation |publisher=Goal.com |date=13 December 2010 |accessdate=13 July 2016 }} In an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s Donald McRae in 2014, Cruyff said about football's lost values and how money had eroded the game's purity, "Football is now all about money. There are problems with the values within the game. This is sad because football is the most beautiful game. We can play it in the street. We can play it everywhere. Everyone can play it whether you’re tall or small, fat or thin. But those values are being lost. We have to bring them back."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/26/johan-cruyff-1974-world-cup-donald-mcrae |author=McRae, Donald |title=Johan Cruyff: ‘Maybe we were the real winners in 1974. The world remembers our team more’ |work=The Guardian |date=26 March 2016 |accessdate=26 July 2016 }} ==Personal life== [[File:Johan Cruijff and Danny Coster 1968.jpg|thumb|left|Cruyff and Danny Coster getting married on 2 December 1968]] At the wedding of Ajax teammate [[Piet Keizer]], on 13 June 1967, Cruyff met his future wife, Diana Margaretha "Danny" Coster (b. 1949). They started dating, and on 2 December 1968, at the age of 21, he married Danny. Her father was Dutch businessman Cor Coster who also happened to be Cruyff's agent. He was also credited with engineering Cruyff's move to [[FC Barcelona]] in 1973. The marriage is said to have been [[Golden wedding|happy for almost 50 years]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/528411/hard-to-explain |title=Hard to explain |publisher=ESPN FC |last=Bouwes |first=Ernst |quote=Cruyff is a family man (...), one of the few professional players who married young and kept his marriage alive over all these years. He also managed to keep himself, his wife and children away from the wrong kind of tabloid headlines. His son [[Jordi Cruyff|Jordi]] has praised Johan as a very considerate and playful father and that his childhood was a very happy one, although his father was away quite often. So, for Johan Cruyff his family may have been even more important than his football career...|date=23 April 2008 |accessdate=20 August 2015}} Contrary to his well-known strong personality and superstar status, Cruyff led a relatively quiet private life beyond the world of football.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/johan-cruyff-the-balletic-genius-who-changed-football-a6951636.html |author=Herbert, Ian |title=Johan Cruyff: The balletic genius who changed football all over the world |publisher=Independent.co.uk |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 August 2016 }} A highly principled, strong-minded and devoted family man, Cruyff's football career, both as a player and as a manager, was considerably influenced by his family, in particular his wife Danny.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/528411/hard-to-explain |title=Hard to explain |publisher=ESPN FC |last=Bouwes |first=Ernst |quote=Then [[Carles Rexach]] published his book and also claimed that she [Danny] always had a big influence over his career. (...) She can also be blamed for [[Netherlands national football team|Holland]] missing out on the World Cup in 1970, and then probably winning it, why not, when Johan had to go on a trip to Milan with Danny to buy shoes for her shop in Amsterdam. He returned too late for the Dutch training camp before their decisive qualifier against Bulgaria and was subsequently dropped. A draw ended all hopes of a trip to Mexico. |date=23 April 2008 |accessdate=20 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/905938/ernst-bouwes-cruyff-rift-tearing-ajax-apart |title=Cruyff rift tearing Ajax apart |publisher=ESPN FC |last=Bouwes |first=Ernst |quote=Following his heart operation in 1991, Danny became stricter in controlling her man. He withdrew as [Netherlands] national coach for the 1994 World Cup in a cloud of arguments after an initial agreement. She probably forbade him to go as it was too dangerous for his health. Several times since, Cruyff has promised to commit to some responsibility, only to resign later with some half-hearted excuse. It's as if she told him to stop being foolish, but he did not dare to say so in public. Danny appears to be very well capable of handling Cruyff. |date=12 April 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2015}} He and Danny had three children together: Chantal (16 November 1970), Susila (27 January 1972), and [[Jordi Cruyff|Jordi]] (9 February 1974). The family has lived in [[Barcelona]] since 1973, with a six-year interruption from December 1981 to January 1988 when they lived in [[Vinkeveen]], The Netherlands.{{cite news|title='Grote Johan Cruijff-hype is in aantocht'|url=http://www.vi.nl/nieuws/grote-johan-cruijffhype-is-in-aantocht.htm|publisher=Voetbal International|date=25 October 2015}} In 1977, Cruyff announced his decision to retire from international football at the age of 30, despite still being lean and wiry, after helping the country qualify for the [[1978 World Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://thesefootballtimes.co/2015/12/01/in-celebration-of-hollands-underappreciated-1978-masters/ |author=Bland, Gareth |title=In celebration of Holland’s underappreciated 1978 masters |publisher=These Football Times (thesefootballtimes.co) |date=1 December 2015 |accessdate=31 August 2016 }} This move, shrouded in mystery and met with disbelief back in late 1977, was only finally stripped of its mystique in 2008, when Cruyff explained his decision in an interview with ''[[Catalunya Ràdio|Catalunya Radio]]''. It was while still living in Barcelona as a player in late 1977, Cruyff and his family became the victims of an armed attacker who forced his way into his flat in Barcelona.{{cite web|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/features/2016/04/johan-cruyff-x-14/ |title=14 things you may or may not know about Johan Cruijff |publisher=DutchNews.nl |quote=According to newspaper [http://www.ad.nl AD], the man, a labourer from Rotterdam, drove to Barcelona buying a sawn-off shot gun on the way. He forced Cruijff and his wife Danny to lie on the floor, bound Cruijff– who asked with admirable and typical sang-froid for the rope not to be tied too tightly because he’d just had an operation (which wasn’t true) – and held a gun to the footballer's head. Danny made a dash for the door and when her screams alerted neighbours the attacker fled, dropping his gun. After some fisticuffs with other residents he was handed over to the police and spent a couple of years in prison. Later Cruijff said the attempted kidnap was the reason he decided not to go to the World Cup in Argentina in 1978. |date=11 April 2016 |accessdate=20 July 2016 }} And the man who was then the ultimate football superstar was confronted with the choice between family values and a highly promising World Cup glory at the end of his international career. But for Cruyff, family comes first. In the interview with ''Catalunya Radio'', he said that the attempted kidnap was the reason he decided not to go to the World Cup in Argentina in 1978. As he recalled, "You should know that I had problems at the end of my career as a player here and I don't know if you know that someone [put] a rifle at my head and tied me up and tied up my wife in front of the children at our flat in Barcelona. The children were going to school accompanied by the police. The police slept in our house for three or four months. I was going to matches with a bodyguard. All these things change your point of view towards many things. There are moments in life in which there are other values. We wanted to stop this and be a little more sensible. It was the moment to leave football and I couldn't play in the World Cup after this."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/apr/17/newsstory.sport |author=Keeley, Graham |title=After 30 years, the truth behind Cruyff's World Cup absence |work= The Guardian |date=17 April 2008 |accessdate=27 July 2016 }} Cruyff named his third child after the patron saint of [[Catalonia]], St Jordi, commonly known in English as [[Saint George]] of Lydda. This was seen as a provocative gesture towards the then Spanish dictator General Franco, who had made all symbols of Catalan nationalism illegal. Cruyff had to fly his son back to the Netherlands to register his birth as the name "Jordi" had been banned by the Spanish authorities. Cruyff's decision to go to such great lengths to support Catalan nationalism is part of the reason he is a hero to Barcelona supporters and Catalan nationalists.{{cite book |last=Burns |first=Danny |title=Barca |year=2009 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|location=London|isbn=978-1408805787}} Jordi Cruyff has played for teams such as Barcelona (while father Johan was manager), Manchester United, [[Deportivo Alavés|Alavés]] and [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]]. His grandson, [[Jesjua Angoy-Cruyff|Jesjua Angoy]], plays at [[Dayton Dutch Lions]]. The younger Cruyff wears "Jordi" on his shirt to distinguish himself from his famous father, which also reflects the common Spanish practice of referring to players by given names alone or by nicknames. It is also related to the commercial claim of "name and fame" of his father to the name Cruyff/Cruijff. Pep Guardiola, Ronald Koeman, and Joan Laporta were among Cruyff's closest friends. Estelle Cruijff, a niece of Cruyff, was married to [[Ruud Gullit]] for 12 years (2000–2012).{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/2292/editorials/2012/08/02/3270714/the-good-life-ruud-gullit |author=Ghai, Rishabh |title=The Good Life: Ruud Gullit |publisher=Goal.com |date=2 August 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2016/01/177961/badr-haris-partner-estelle-cruyff-converts-to-islam/ |title=Badr Hari's Ex-Partner Estelle Cruyff Allegedly Converts to Islam |work=MoroccoWorldNews |date=23 January 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016 }} ==Political and religious views== Cruyff once described himself as "not religious" and criticized the practices of devoutly Catholic Spanish players: "In Spain all 22 players make the [[sign of the cross]] before a game; if it worked, every game would be a tie."{{cite web|title=Johan Cruijff Quotes|quote="I'm not religious, in Spain all 22 players cross themselves, if it works the game is always going to be a tie."|publisher=famousquotes.com|url=http://www.famousquotes.com/author/johan-cruijff|accessdate=9 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112085648/http://www.famousquotes.com/author/johan-cruijff/|archivedate=12 November 2013}} That widely quoted statement earned him a place on lists of the world's top [[atheist]] athletes. But in the 1990s, Cruyff told the Dutch Catholic radio station RKK/KRO that as a child he attended Sunday school, where he was taught about the Bible, and that while he didn’t go to church as an adult, he believed "there's something there."[http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/5009/Archief/article/detail/2692345/1999/11/25/Verlosser-Cruijff-gelooft-niet-maar-denkt-wel-dat-er-iets-is.dhtml 'Verlosser' Cruijff gelooft niet, maar denkt wel dat er iets is (Trouw.nl, 25/11/99)] The Dutch evangelical broadcaster EO posted an interview conducted before Cruyff's death with his friend [[Johan Derksen]], the editor-in-chief of ''[[Voetbal International]]'' magazine. "People don't know the real Johan Cruyff", Derksen said. "I have on occasion had beautiful conversations with him about faith, because we both went to the same kind of schools and learned about the Bible. And it stays with you."{{cite web|url=http://www.eo.nl/geloven/nieuws/item/video-johan-cruijff-was-absoluut-gelovig/ |title=‘Johan Cruijff was absoluut gelovig’, Johan Derksen over voetballegende Cruijff |publisher= EO.nl |quote=[[Johan Derksen]]: "Johan [Cruijff] is absoluut gelovig, al gaat hij nooit naar de kerk". [Original in Dutch] |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=2 July 2016 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.religionnews.com/2016/03/25/cruyff-soccer-savior-god-faith/ |author=[[Jerome Socolovsky|Socolovsky, Jerome]] |title=The death of soccer's 'savior' |publisher= Religion News Service |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=2 July 2016}} Cruyff is also said to have had an attachment to Jewish culture, having grown up in the Amsterdam municipal [[Betondorp]] populated by a sizeable Jewish community, and more prevalently because of his lifelong connections with [[AFC Ajax|Ajax Amsterdam]] – a football club with such strong Dutch Jewish influences that some have even dubbed it a "Jewish club".{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/arts/arts-features/102287/radio-review-ajax-jewish-club |author=Round, Simon |title=Radio review: Ajax – the Jewish club |publisher=The Jewish Chronicle |date=7 February 2013 |accessdate=20 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.rnw.org/archive/ajax-jewish-club-spite-itself |title=Ajax: a Jewish club in spite of itself |publisher=RNW Media ([[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]) |accessdate=20 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/5live/entries/6ed72010-f201-3e7f-b2d2-c6f2a8dbb30a |author=Legard, Jonathan |title=BBC Blogs – The 5 live blog – Ajax – The Jewish club |publisher=BBC.co.uk |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=20 July 2016 }} ==Quotes== * "Every trainer talks about movement, about running a lot. I say don't run so much. Football is a game you play with your brain. You have to be in the right place at the right moment, not too early, not too late." * "In my teams, the goalie is the first attacker, and the striker the first defender." * "Every disadvantage has its advantage." * "If you can't win, make sure you don't lose." * "Quality without results is pointless. Results without quality is boring."{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/messi10stats/status/713002758203310080 |title=Leo Messi: ‘Johan Cruyff: "Quality without results is pointless. Results without quality is boring." ’ |publisher=[[Twitter|Twitter.com]] |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016}} * "Winning is an important thing, but to have your own style, to have people copy you, to admire you, that is the greatest gift." ==Illness, death and tributes== {{Quote box|width=33%|quote=He has enriched and personified our football. He was an icon of the Netherlands. Johan Cruijff belonged to all of us.|source=—King [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands]] pays tribute following Cruyff's death.{{cite news|title=Reacties op het overlijden van Johan Cruijff|newspaper=NRC |language=Dutch|date=24 March 2016 |url=http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2016/03/24/live-johan-cruijff-68-overleden|accessdate=24 March 2016}}}} {{quote|Football has lost a man who did more to make the [[beautiful game]] beautiful than anyone in history.|Former English international [[Gary Lineker]]{{cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/garylineker/status/712990086506397697 |title=Gary Lineker: ‘Sad to hear that Johan Cruyff has died. Football has lost a man who did more to make the beautiful game beautiful than anyone in history.’ |publisher=[[Twitter|Twitter.com]] |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=10 July 2016}}}} Cruyff had always been a heavy smoker from his boyhood until he underwent an emergency bypass operation in 1991. After giving up smoking following the surgery, he took to sucking lollipops when watching games. He featured in a Catalan health department advert, saying, "Football has given me everything in life, tobacco almost took it all away."{{cite news|title=Johan Cruyff: Netherlands great diagnosed with lung cancer|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34602348|work=BBC News|date=22 October 2015}}[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/oct/22/johan-cruyff-barcelona-ajax-holland-lung-cancer Johan Cruyff diagnosed with lung cancer], ''The Guardian'' (London); accessed 24 October 2015. After more heart trouble in 1997, he vowed never to coach again (until 2009), though he remained a vocal football critic and analyst.{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10216592/johan-cryuff-dies-of-cancer-at-age-of-68 |author=Vinnell, Paul |title=Johan Cruyff dies of cancer at age of 68 |publisher=SkySports.com |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }} In October 2015 he was diagnosed with [[lung cancer]].{{cite news|last1=De Menezes|first1=Jack|title=Johan Cruyff: Barcelona, Ajax and Netherlands legend diagnosed with lung cancer|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/johan-cruyff-barcelona-ajax-and-netherlands-legend-diagnosed-with-lung-cancer-a6703906.html|accessdate=22 October 2015|work=The Independent|date=22 October 2015}} After the news broke, tributes poured in for the former Ajax and Netherlands legend, with all [[Eredivisie]] games featuring a round of applause on 14 minutes, Cruyff's former shirt number. Ahead of their league game against [[SD Eibar|Eibar]] at the [[Camp Nou]] (25 October 2015), Barcelona players showed their support for Cruyff by wearing orange T-shirts bearing the words 'Ànims Johan' (Catalan for 'Get well soon Johan'). Writing in his weekly ''[[De Telegraaf]]'' column, Cruyff admitted, "Often the media are an additional tax, but the last week that has been different. The way in which a reply is posted via a variety of media in my situation, was emotional and heartwarming. I am extremely proud of the appreciation shown by all responses." On his condition, Cruyff added, "Meanwhile, we have to wait. It's really annoying that it has been leaked so quickly, because the only thing I know now is that I have lung cancer. No more. Because the investigation is ongoing."{{cite web|url=http://www.football-oranje.com/cruyff-emotional-after-tributes/ |author=Bell, Michael |title=Cruyff "Emotional" after tributes |publisher=Football-Oranje.com |date=26 October 2015 |accessdate=26 July 2016 }} In mid February 2016, he stated that he had been responding well to [[chemotherapy]] and was "winning" his cancer battle.{{cite news|title=Johan Cruyff says he feels '2–0 up' in match against lung cancer|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35568780|accessdate=24 March 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 February 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/462/netherlands/2016/02/13/20302722/cruyff-feels-2-0-up-in-cancer-battle |author=Wright, Joe |title=Cruyff 'feels 2–0 up' in cancer battle |publisher=Goal.com |quote=As Cruyff said in a statement on [https://www.worldofjohancruyff.com/2016/02/medical-treatments/ his official website] (''Cruyff Management – The World of Johan Cruyff''), "After several medical treatments I can say that the results have been very positive, thanks to the excellent work of the doctors, the affection of the people and my positive mentality. Right now, I have the feeling that I am 2–0 up in the first half of a match that has not finished yet. But I am sure that I will end up winning." |date=13 February 2016 |accessdate=23 July 2016 }} On 2 March 2016, he was in attendance on the second day of winter testing at the [[Circuit de Catalunya]] just outside Barcelona and visited Dutch [[Formula One]] driver [[Max Verstappen]]. Cruyff appeared to be in good spirits and it is believed this was the last time he was seen in public.{{cite web|url=http://www.sport-english.com/en/news/barca/cruyff-poses-alongside-verstappen-barcelona-grand-prix-circuit-4944518 |author=Viaplana, Josep |title= Cruyff poses alongside Verstappen at Barcelona Grand Prix circuit |publisher= Sport.es |date=2 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/more-sports/2016/03/02/56d73058ca4741bd4a8b4641.html |author=Lifona, Daniel G. |title=Johan Cruyff visits Verstappen in Montmeló |publisher=Marca.com |date=2 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/johan-cruyffs-last-public-appearance-7622409 |author=Corless, Liam |title=Johan Cruyff's last public appearance came at F1 testing in Catalonia earlier in March |publisher=Mirror.co.uk |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016 }} On the morning of 24 March 2016, in a clinic in Barcelona, Cruyff died at the age of 68, surrounded by his wife, children, and grandchildren.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/24/johan-cruyff-dies-aged-68-holland-football-legend |author=Meagher, Gerard |title=Johan Cruyff, Total Football pioneer, dies at the age of 68 |work=The Guardian |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016 }} His lung cancer had [[metastasis|metastasized]] to his brain and a week before his death he had begun to lose his ability to speak as well as movement on his left side. He was [[cremation|cremated]] in Barcelona within 24 hours{{cite web|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/johan-cruyffs-final-months-remembered-his-ghostwriter-and-dear-friend |author=de Groot, Jaap |title=Johan Cruyff's final months remembered, by his ghostwriter and dear friend |work=FourFourTwo.com |date=24 March 2017 |accessdate=1 November 2017}} following his death. A private ceremony was held, attended only by his wife (Danny), children (Chantal, Susila, and Jordi), and grandchildren.{{cite news|title=Netherlands great Johan Cruyff dies of cancer aged 68|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35892775|work=BBC News|date=24 March 2016}}{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/24/johan-cruyff-dies-aged-68-holland-football-legend|title=Johan Cruyff, Dutch football legend, dies at the age of 68|date=24 March 2016|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=24 March 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/johan-cruyff-organised-death-family-7635098|title=Johan Cruyff "organised" his death to be with family, claims close friend|date=26 March 2016|work=The Daily Mirror}} {{quote|Today football has lost one of its best ever players and ambassadors. revolutionary, a dreamer, a visionary, and an innovator who changed the idea of a game in which strength was the primary consideration to another one based, and focused, on ability and technique, giving birth to what has been called "tiki-taka." He used to say that football should be played with the brain... I met him a few times after he left football, always playing golf, a sport he loved. He would always talk about football in the same way he did when he was playing and coaching—with plenty of passion and excitement. A legend has gone but he has left an important legacy."{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/johan-cruyff-ramon-calderon-barcelona-real-madrid-440545 |author=[[Ramón Calderón|Calderón, Ramón]] |title=Johan Cruyff: Former Real Madrid President Ramon Calderon Pays Tribute To A ‘Visionary’ |work=Newsweek |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=24 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadridnews.com/ramon-calderon-johan-cruyff-was-a-visionary-16903 |author=Collins, Paul |title=Ramon Calderon: Johan Cruyff was a visionary |publisher= Realmadridnews.com |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 July 2016 }} A friendly match between the Netherlands and France was held on the day after Cruyff's death. The play (at the [[Amsterdam Arena]]) was stopped in the 14th minute as players, staff, and supporters gave a minute's applause for Cruyff, who wore the number 14 shirt for his country. [[Mascots]] from both teams took to the pitch wearing Netherlands national team shirts adorned with Cruyff's number 14 on the front, while there were numerous banners in the spectators' stands bearing the simple message, "''Johan Bedankt''" ("Thank you Johan").{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/25/johan-cruyff-tribute-holland-france-halted|title=Johan Cruyff tribute: Holland v France halted in 14th minute to honour legend|date=25 March 2016|work=The Guardian}} Ahead of the [[El Clásico]] against Real Madrid (2 April 2016), Barcelona announced plans for five special tributes to the late club legend: *1.) A [[mosaic]] formed by the 90,000 fans inside Camp Nou carrying the words 'Gràcies Johan' ([[Catalan language|Catalan]] for 'Thank you, Johan') *2.) The words 'Gràcies Johan' would replace the World Club champions badge on the front of the Barcelona players' shirts *3.) Children wearing T-shirts with the words 'Gràcies Johan' would accompany Barça's and Madrid's players on to the pitch at the beginning of the game. The logo of the [[Johan Cruyff Foundation]] would feature on the back of the T-shirts *4.) The presence of all eight living (past and present) [[List of FC Barcelona presidents|Barcelona presidents]]: [[Agustí Montal Galobart]], [[Raimon Carrasco]], [[Josep Lluís Núñez]], [[Joan Gaspart]], [[Enric Reyna]], Joan Laporta, [[Sandro Rosell]] and [[Josep Maria Bartomeu]] *5.) A commemorative video honouring Cruyff's life would be shown on the big screens at Camp Nou stadium.{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/club/news/2015-2016/fc-barcelona-board-reveals-plans-to-honour-johan-cruyff-at-clasico |title= FC Barcelona board reveals plans to honour Johan Cruyff at Clásico |publisher=FCBARCELONA.COM |date=29 March 2016 |accessdate=10 July 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.sport-english.com/en/news/barca/barcelona-reveal-five-clasico-tributes-honour-johan-cruyff-5011883 |title=Barcelona reveal five Clasico tributes in honour of Johan Cruyff |publisher=SPORT.es |date=29 March 2016 |accessdate=10 July 2016 }} An open letter signed by Barcelona's eight current and previous presidents read: "With Cruyff we began to play differently, breaking new ground and innovating. With him, both as a player and coach, we established our own style on the field, what is traditionally known as 'total football,' the Barça style everyone admires. The arrival of Cruyff altered the history of Barça. He contributed decisively to a change of mentality. He got us to keep our heads up and to see that no opponent was invincible, that we could attain what we were aiming for. Cruyff was an icon who explained, better than anyone, that Barça is more than a club. (...) Without Cruyff's unabashed and non-conformist spirit, we quite possibly wouldn't have become the greatest club in the world."{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/club/news/2015-2016/letter-from-the-presidents-of-fc-barcelona-to-johan-cruyff |title=Letter from the presidents of FC Barcelona to Johan Cruyff |publisher=WWW.FCBARCELONA.COM |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=24 September 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/spanish-primera-division/story/2836579/barcelona-and-xavi-thank-johan-cruyff-for-altering-history |author=Garcia, Adriana |title=Barcelona and Xavi thank Johan Cruyff for 'altering history' |publisher=ESPN FC |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2016 }} Former Israeli president and prime minister [[Shimon Peres]] paid tribute to Cruyff as a cultural figure and writing on ''[[Facebook]]'': "Johan was more than just a great soccer player. He was a role model who promoted world peace. He brought the values of education into the game of football and proved that on the field, everyone is equal – Jews, Muslims, and Christians – that running fast and playing well will lead to victory in spite of discrimination and racism. Your work promoting sport and peace gave hope to children and youth around the world."{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.710786 |title=Shimon Peres Pays Tribute to Late Dutch Soccer Anis Ahmed | image = Kazi Anis Ahmed.jpg | caption = | native_name = কাজী আনিস আহমেদ | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1970}} | birth_place = | nationality = Bangladeshi | death_date = | occupation = Businessman, investor | father = Kazi Shahid Ahmed | relatives = [[Kazi Nabil Ahmed]] (Sibling) }}
'''Kazi Anis Ahmed''' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]]: কাজী আনিস আহমেদ) is a [[Bangladeshis|Bangladeshi]] businessman, investor and publisher who serves as the Director and Chief Strategist of Gemcon Group and CEO of organics, education and retail department of the same group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gemcon.group/bod.php|title=Welcome to Gemcon Group|website=www.gemcon.group|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> He is the co-founder and the Vice-President of the Board of Trustees of [[University of Liberal Arts Bangladesh]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ulab.edu.bd/about-us/board-of-trustees/|title=Board of Trustees - University of Liberal Arts Bangladesh|work=University of Liberal Arts Bangladesh|access-date=2018-05-08|language=en-US}}</ref> and the publisher of the English-language daily newspaper ''[[Dhaka Tribune]]'' and Bengali-language online newspaper ''[[Bangla Tribune]]''<ref name=":0" /> and the literary journal ''Bengal Lights''.
== Early life and education == Kazi Anis Ahmed was born in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]. His father, Kazi Shahid Ahmed, is the founder and chairman of Gemcon Group, and also a writer and novelist in the [[Bengali language]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/feature/writing/2017/09/21/kazi-shahid-ahmeds-new-novel-daate-kata-pencil-unveiled/|title=Kazi Shahid Ahmed’s new novel ‘Daate Kata Pencil’ unveiled {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|website=www.dhakatribune.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> In his early life, Anis Ahmed was educated in Dhaka and later at Brown University, Washington University and New York University.<ref name="thedailystar1" />
==Career==
=== Business === Ahmed is the Director and CEO of Organics, Retail and Education for Gemcon Group in Dhaka, and is the Director of the Kazi and Kazi Tea Estate, Ltd. (KKTE). At Kazi and Kazi Tea Estate, Ahmed has helped establish the guiding organic values and policies that allowed KKTE to emerge as the first successful organic tea estate in Bangladesh. He personally oversaw the international SGS Organic and USDA Organic certification processes. He is the Co-Founder of the Teatulia brand of Kazi and Kazi Tea, which sells in the USA, UK, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia and Kuwait. Teatulia is the only Bangladeshi tea brand to sell in premium stores around the world, including Whole Foods in the US and Harrods in the UK.<ref>[//web.archive.org/web/20120722045117/http://legatum.mit.edu/content/1098 Ahmed, Kazi Anis]</ref>
Ahmed runs [[Kazi Kazi Tea|Kazi & Kazi Tea]] Estate Ltd. with his family. Kazi & Kazi Tea Estate is the first USDA and SGS-certified 100% organic tea garden and cooperative in northern Bangladesh that is the single source for the tea company Teatulia. [[Tetulia Tea Garden|Teatulia tea]] is distributed in Bangladesh, the United Kingdom, the United States, and will soon be available in Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.success.com/article/a-growing-venture|title=A Growing Venture|date=15 November 2012|work=[[Success (magazine)|SUCCESS Magazine]]|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
He is the co-founder of [[University of Liberal Arts Bangladesh]] and the Vice-President of the Board of Trustees of the same university.
=== Publishing === Ahmed is the publisher of the English-language daily newspaper ''[[Dhaka Tribune]]'' and Bengali-language online newspaper ''Bangla Tribune''<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.banglatribune.com/|title=Bangla Tribune - Bangla news, Behind The News|work=banglatribune.com|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> and the literary journal ''Bengal Lights''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/k-anis-ahmeds-novel-the-world-in-my-hands-launched-4818|title=K Anis Ahmed's novel The World In My Hands launched|date=31 December 2013|work=The Daily Star|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140201231320/http://www.thedailystar.net/city/k-anis-ahmeds-novel-the-world-in-my-hands-launched-4818|archivedate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
=== Writings === Apart from his career as a businessman and an investor, Ahmed also occasionally writes particularly in his second language English. His first collection of short stories, Good Night, Mr. Kissinger, was published by The University Press Limited<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/hay-festival/9684981/Hay-Dhaka-2012-The-Assassins-Creed.html|title=Hay Dhaka 2012: The Assassin's Creed|author=Sameer Rahim|date=17 November 2012|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> in Bangladesh and launched at the [[Hay Festival]] in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-shook/englishlanguage-literatur_b_2163510.html|author=David Shook|title=English-Language Literature Finds Its Place in Bangladesh|work=[[HuffPost]]|date=20 November 2012|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>Ahmed's first novel, The World in My Hands, was published by Random House India in December 2013. The book is a political satire that charts the fate of two friends – a newspaper editor and a successful property developer – whose relationship is bitterly tested when they find themselves on opposite sides of a crisis that upends their country's social order.<ref name="thedailystar1">{{cite news |author=Fayeka Zabeen Siddiqua|date=3 January 2014|title=The World in My Hands|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/the-star/the-world-in-my-hands-4988|newspaper=The Daily Star|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140106070123/http://www.thedailystar.net/the-star/the-world-in-my-hands-4988|archivedate=6 January 2014|accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/opinion/mihir-s-sharma-writing-a-country-114011301137_1.html|title=Mihir S Sharma: Writing a country|work=Business Standard|date=13 January 2014|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
==Literary works== *''Good Night, Mr. Kissinger'' (Unnamed Press, 2014) {{ISBN|978-1-939419-04-0}} *''The World in My Hands'' (Random House India, 2013)

{{small|([[Bachelor of Business Administration]])}} | occupation = [[Choreographer]] and [[Social entrepreneur]] | years_active = 2006 - present | home_town = [[Dar es Salam]] | spouse = | title = Founder, [[Managing Director]] and [[chief executive officer|CEO]] of '''Unleashed Africa Company Limited'''. | religion = }} '''Khalila Kellz Mbowe''' is a female [[Tanzania]]n [[choreographer]], creative performance director and [[social entrepreneur]], who is the founder, [[managing director]] and [[chief executive officer]] of ''Unleashed Africa Company Limited'', an enterprise that trains gifted young people in the performing arts, offering education, mentoring, exposure and opportunities to succeed in life.{{cite web|url=http://se-forum.se/portfolio-items/khalila-kellz-mbowe/ |title=About Khalila and Unleashed | publisher=Social Entrepreneurship Forum (SE Forum) | author=SE Forum | location=Stockholm, Sweden |date=2015 |accessdate=14 November 2017}}{{cite web|accessdate=14 November 2017|last=Uliwa | url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/magazine/Khalila-Mbowe-profile/434746-4182134-mgjgjoz/index.html |title=Khalila Mbowe: A go-getter from an early age | date=11 November 2017 | first=Caroline |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] |location=Nairobi}} ==Background and education== She was born in Tanzania circa 1988, and attended "Saint Mary’s Secondary School", in [[Dar es Salaam]] for her high school education. She holds an [[Mass communication|Advanced Diploma in Mass Communication]], obtained from [[Taylor's University]], in [[Singapore]], in 2010. She is currently enrolled in the [[University of the People]],{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/03/education/edlife/where-are-the-graduates-of-university-of-the-people.html?pagewanted=all |title=The Value in a Free Degree: Where Are the Graduates of University of the People? | accessdate=14 November 2017 | date=1 November 2013 | last=Pappano | first=Laura |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |location=New York City}} pursuing a [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] (BBA) degree. ==Career== In 2006, at the age of 18 years, she obtained her first job as a [[copywriter]] at FCB Advertising Agency, a subsidiary of [http://scanad.com/ Lowe Scanad Tanzania Limited]. After working in that capacity for two months, she was promoted to an account executive handling the account of one of Tanzania's leading telecommunications companies. In 2010, after graduating from Taylor's University, she landed a job working for [[Airtel|Airtel Tanzania]], a subsidiary of [[India]]'s [[Bharti Airtel]], working there for one year, from 2013 until 2014. From April 2015 until December 2015, she worked as the Chief Executive Officer of "Buddies Production Company Limited", a television production company from [[Uganda]] that was looking to expand in Tanzania.{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/khalilakellzmbowe/ | author=Khalila Kellz Mbowe | title=Khalila Kellz Mbowe: Unleashed Africa Founder And Managing Director| accessdate=14 November 2017 |publisher=[[Linkedin.com]] |date=14 November 2017}} Since February 2915, she has focused on running UACL, and pursuing her degree in business administration, online. Her company employed 20 people as of November 2017.
