{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} [[File:Sheldon-square.jpg|thumb|Looking down Kingdom Street from the amphitheatre in Sheldon Square, PaddingtonCentral]]
The '''Paddington Waterside''' Partnership is the body coordinating regeneration of the Paddington Special Policy Area around [[Paddington Station]] in [[London]]. The project covers an area almost the size of [[Soho]], creating about {{convert|10000000|sqft|m2}} of space between 1998 and 2018.
It consists of 13 individual projects in the triangle of land between [[Praed Street]], Westbourne Terrace and the A40 [[Westway (London)|Westway]], most notably PaddingtonCentral<!-- no space --> and [[Paddington Basin]]. In 2000, the ''Independent'' described it as "the largest central London redevelopment scheme since the Second World War".<ref>{{citation | title=Paddington project given green light | first=Saeed | last=Shah | date=18 October 2000 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/paddington-project-given-green-light-635682.html | location=London | work=The Independent}}</ref>
==History== [[File:One-three-kingdom-street.jpg|thumb|One and Three Kingdom Street from the south.]] The Paddington Arm of the [[Grand Junction Canal]] opened on 10 July 1801,<ref>{{citation | title=The Union magazine, and imperial register, Volume 2 | publisher =J. Walker | year=1801 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JWcAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA67 | page=67}}</ref> linking Paddington to the Bull's Bridge junction near the future site of [[Heathrow Airport]]. The Grand Junction (now part of the [[Grand Union Canal]]) was the final link in a chain of canals that reduced the distance from London to Birmingham from {{convert|269.5|mi|km|0}} in 1789 to {{convert|138.5|mi|km|0}} in 1805;<ref>{{citation | title=Transport in the industrial revolution | first1=Derek Howard | last1= Aldcroft | first2=Michael J. | last2=Freeman | publisher = Manchester University Press | year=1983 | isbn=978-0-7190-0839-9 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tX27AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA108 | page=108}}</ref> terminating the canal at Paddington gave easy access to main roads into London and the level route meant no [[lock (water transport)|locks]] were needed on its {{convert|13.5|mi|km|0|adj=on}} length. In contrast the [[Regent's Canal]] needed 12 locks for the {{convert|86|ft|m|adj=on}} descent from Paddington to the Thames at Limehouse.
The canal was an instant success, with warehouses and housing springing up around it.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Victoria history of the county of Middlesex | year=1911 | first=William | last=Page | volume=2 | publisher=Constable | location=London | url=https://archive.org/details/middlesexhistory02univuoft | page=122}}</ref> Canal traffic increased further when the Regent's Canal linked Paddington to the [[Port of London]] in 1820, but Paddington Basin was "practically killed" as a port<ref>{{cite book | title=London's Coats of Arms and the Stories They Tell | first=Richard | last=Crosley | year=1928 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-zqSQ9K1gN4C&pg=PA164 | page=164}}</ref> as business was lost to wharves such as [[City Road Basin]] that were closer to the docks and the [[City of London]]. Paddington regained importance as a transport interchange with the arrival of the railway in 1838.
Canal traffic transferred to the railways during the nineteenth century and fell away completely after World War II; the closure of the [[Regent's Canal Dock]] in 1969 marked the [[coup de grâce]]. A similar switch from rail to road [[History of rail transport in Great Britain 1948–1994|in the second half of the twentieth century]] left the Paddington goods yards redundant by the early 1980s. The land became derelict, with no public access to the canal land until 1987.<ref name=McGhie>{{cite news | title=The new arrivals at Paddington | first=Caroline | last=McGhie | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/4814516/The-new-arrivals-at-Paddington.html | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=13 May 2001 | accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref> The Paddington Special Policy Area was designated in 1988.<ref name=factsheet>{{cite web | title=Paddington Special Policy Area Factsheet | url=http://www3.westminster.gov.uk/docstores/publications_store/Paddington_Area_Factsheet_May_2009.pdf | publisher=Planning & City Development Department, City of Westminster | date=May 2009 | accessdate=29 October 2010 | format=pdf}}</ref>
The Paddington Regeneration Partnership, later the Paddington Waterside Partnership, was formed in 1998 to coordinate the regeneration of the area,<ref>{{cite web | title=Paddington Waterside Partnership | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/ | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | year=2008 | accessdate=29 October 2010}} (Official website)</ref> now designated as the Paddington Special Policy Area. This followed the establishment of the King's Cross Partnership in 1996<ref>{{cite web | title=King's Cross Canal Action Plan | url=http://www.britishwaterways.co.uk/media/documents/Kings_Cross_Canal_Action_Plan.pdf | format=pdf | publisher=British Waterways | accessdate=29 October 2010 | page=6 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215173351/http://britishwaterways.co.uk/media/documents/Kings_Cross_Canal_Action_Plan.pdf | archivedate=15 December 2010 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> to develop a similar mix of railway and canal land around [[London King's Cross railway station|King's Cross station]], a project that became known as [[King's Cross Central]]. The first plans for Paddington envisaged {{convert|10000000|sqft|m2}} of new space,<ref>{{cite web | title=Discover Paddington Waterside | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/content/Discover%20Paddington.pdf | format=pdf | date=April 2004 | accessdate=2 November 2010 | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719023347/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/content/Discover%20Paddington.pdf | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> more than the original [[Canary Wharf]] development,<ref name=McGhie /> in an area the size of Soho.<ref name=McGhie /> This compares with the {{convert|505000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of [[30 St Mary Axe]] (the "Gherkin")<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.knightfrank.co.uk/commercial/property-asset-management/documents/Troph-Office-Management-Case-Studies-2009.pdf | format=pdf | publisher=Knight Frank LLP | title=Trophy Office Management | year=2009 | accessdate=2 November 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110705074516/http://www.knightfrank.co.uk/commercial/property-asset-management/documents/Troph-Office-Management-Case-Studies-2009.pdf | archivedate=5 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> and {{convert|1238000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of the skyscraper at [[One Canada Square]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.canarywharf.co.uk/mainFrm1.asp?strSelectedSubmenu=Buildings&strSelectedArea=Estate | title=One Canada Square Building Profile | year=2007 | accessdate=2 November 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040225125058/http://www.canarywharf.co.uk/mainFrm1.asp?strSelectedSubmenu=Buildings&strSelectedArea=Estate | archivedate=25 February 2004 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Outline planning permission for the western part of Paddington Basin was granted on 23 April 2001.<ref name=factsheet />
==Projects== ===PaddingtonCentral=== <!-- the developers put no space between Paddington and Central, although secondary sources often insert one --> [[File:Paddington-central.jpg|thumb|upright|Two Kingdom Street from the north]] Bishop's Bridge station, the original London passenger terminus of the [[Great Western Railway]] was on this site west of [[Bishop's Bridge]] Road. After Paddington was built, it was used for the railway's [[goods shed]]s until the 1980s. It is now a [[mixed-use development]], with offices, flats and retail units. Phase I is Sheldon Square which is named after Sir Joseph Sheldon, a Lord Mayor of London who in 1678 rebuilt what became the church of [[List of churches in the Diocese of London#Deanery of Westminster Paddington|St Mary's]] on Paddington Green.<ref>{{citation | editor=C R Elrington |first1=T F T | last1=Baker | first2=Diane K | last2=Bolton | first3=Patricia E C |last3=Croot | year=1989 | pages=252–259 | title=Paddington: Churches | series=A History of the County of Middlesex, Hampstead, Paddington | volume=9 | accessdate=18 October 2010 | url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=22674}}</ref> Sheldon Square has {{convert|630000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of built space<ref name=PaddingtonCentral>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/paddingtoncentral/default.aspx | title=PaddingtonCentral | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=18 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719022905/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/paddingtoncentral/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> built around a grass [[amphitheatre]] which features live music in summer. The biggest structures are two office blocks of {{convert|193000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} and {{convert|145000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} let to companies such as [[Prudential plc|Prudential]] and [[Kingfisher plc|Kingfisher]]; there are 219 flats and {{convert|95000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail space.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> Sheldon Square was designed by Sidell Gibson and developed as a joint venture between Development Securities, [[Insight Investment Management]] and [[Aviva Investors]].<ref name=PaddingtonCentral />
The second phase of development lies to the west, along Kingdom Street. One Kingdom Street is a {{convert|260000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} office building completed in February 2008 and occupied by [[Misys]], [[Statoil]], [[MWB Group Holdings|MWB]] and [[Vodafone]].<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> It was designed by [[Sheppard Robson]] and developed by Development Securities, Aviva Investors and [[Union Investment]].<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> Two Kingdom Street was due for completion in spring 2010 with [[AstraZeneca]] as the first tenant and has {{convert|235000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of office space with {{convert|25000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of residential accommodation.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> It was designed by [[Kohn Pedersen Fox]] and developed by Development Securities, Aviva Investors and Quinlan Private.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> The Novotel London Paddington is a distinctive 206 bedroom hotel at Three Kingdom Street.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> The hotel was designed by Dexter Moren Associates and Kohn Pedersen Fox and opened in September 2008.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral /> It is a joint venture between Development Securities and Aviva Investors.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral />
In January 2010 Westminster Council granted detailed planning permission for the final phase of the development, Four and Five Kingdom Street.<ref>{{cite web | title=The Redevelopment of Paddington Central is set to be completed | url=http://www.westminster.gov.uk/press-releases/2010-01/the-redevelopment-of-paddington-central-is-set-to/ | publisher=City of Westminster | date=11 January 2010 | accessdate=29 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319004738/http://www.westminster.gov.uk/press-releases/2010-01/the-redevelopment-of-paddington-central-is-set-to/ | archivedate=19 March 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> They will provide {{convert|140000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} and {{convert|210000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of office space respectively.<ref name=PaddingtonCentral />
===Stone Wharf=== British Waterways intends to encourage activity on and around the canal north of the Westway up to [[Maida Vale|Little Venice]], with floating galleries, cafés and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/stone-wharf/default.aspx | title=Stone Wharf | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=18 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719022915/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/stone-wharf/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===55-65 North Wharf Road and Telstar=== Derwent London is employing Fletcher Priest as the architect for two sites off [[Bishop's Bridge]] Road, either side of the railway station.<ref name=Derwent>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/north-wharf/default.aspx | title=55-65 North Wharf Road / Telstar | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=18 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719022927/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/north-wharf/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Planning permission was granted in January 2008 for two buildings at 55–65 North Wharf Road, a {{convert|240000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} office block and a block of 100 flats east of the station.<ref name=Derwent /> An eight-storey office block of {{convert|105000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} has been built at 2 Eastbourne Terrace and is the London headquarters of the [[Rio Tinto Group]].<ref name=Derwent /> It stands on the site of Telstar House, a 1960s office block by [[Richard Seifert]] that suffered a major fire on 29 July 2003.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.firetactics.com/TELSTAR%20HOUSE.htm | title=LONDON FIREFIGHTERS BATTLE AGAINST FIVE FLOORS OF FIRE IN HIGH-RISE BLAZE! | last=Assistant Divisional Officer Steve Dudeney | publisher=Paul Grimwood FIFireE (fire2000.com) | accessdate=2 November 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614130635/http://www.firetactics.com/TELSTAR%20HOUSE.htm | archivedate=14 June 2011 | df=dmy-all }} Has some impressive photos of the fire at Telstar House.</ref>
===10-50 Eastbourne Terrace=== Further down Eastbourne Terrace, [[Land Securities]] have refurbished numbers 10, 20 and 30.<ref name=Landsecs>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/eastbourne-terrace/default.aspx | title=10-50 Eastbourne Terrace | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=18 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719022939/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/eastbourne-terrace/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2009 they sold numbers 40 and 50,<ref name=Landsecs/> {{convert|146000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail and office space.<ref name=AMDB>{{citation | title=AMDB unit buys 60% in UK property firm | date=24 September 2009 | journal=The Star | location=Petaling Jaya, Malaysia | url=http://biz.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/9/24/business/4772051&sec=business}}</ref> Westlink Global Investment Ltd, 60% owned by AMDB Bhd of Malaysia, paid £50.5m for a net rental yield of 8.65% based on the 94% occupancy at the time.<ref name=AMDB />
===Triangle Site=== The construction of the [[Crossrail]] station to the west of Paddington Station means that the existing taxi rank has been moved north of the station and opened in spring 2011.<ref name=Triangle>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/triangle/default.aspx | title=Triangle Site / Crossrail | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=18 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719022953/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/triangle/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> A new entrance for the mainline station and a new ticket hall for the Hammersmith and City line has been constructed next to the canal.<ref name=Triangle />
===Paddington Station=== {{main|London Paddington station}} [[Nicholas Grimshaw]] oversaw a £65m facelift of the mainline station that added {{convert|50000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail and catering space.<ref name=station>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/paddington-station/default.aspx | title=Paddington Station | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=18 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110719023004/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/paddington-station/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The roof of Span 4 is currently being replaced in a £34m refurbishment due for completion by the end of 2010.<ref name=station /> Paddington will be an important hub for the [[Crossrail]] service, providing links to the mainline railway and the London Underground.<ref name=station /> The Crossrail station will be built between 2009 and 2015,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theyworkforyou.com/debate/?id=2005-07-19.1136.2|title=Orders of the Day — Crossrail Bill |date=19 July 2005 |accessdate=23 March 2007 |work=TheyWorkForYou.com}}</ref> with services due to start in 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.railwaygazette.com/news_view/article/2007/10/7798/london_crossrail_gets_the_go_ahead.html | title=London Crossrail gets the go-ahead | date=5 October 2007 | work=[[Railway Gazette International]]| location=London}}</ref>
=== Paddington Basin and Merchant Square === [[File:PaddBasin.jpg|thumb|Paddington Basin]] {{main|Paddington Basin}} Most of the land north of the canal basin is being developed under the banner of Merchant Square by European Land and Property as part of a joint venture between Simon and David Reuben (the [[Reuben brothers]]) and the Jarvis family. In all, the development around Paddington Basin will create {{convert|2000000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of offices, homes, shops and leisure facilities,<ref name=Basin>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/paddington-basin/default.aspx | title=Paddington Basin / Merchant Square | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=29 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719023011/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/paddington-basin/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> with the western end being developed first. Paddington Walk is a block of 232 flats designed by Munkenbeck & Marshall that completed in August 2005.<ref name=Basin /> The Point (224,000 sq ft) and Waterside (240,000 sq ft) are office blocks designed by [[Terry Farrell and Partners]] and the [[Richard Rogers Partnership]] respectively.<ref name=Basin />
The original plan for the eastern end envisaged a commercial development focused around the Grand Union Basin and included the [[Winding hole|Winding]] building and the Grand Union building.<ref name=Basin /> The Richard Rogers Partnership originally designed the latter as three towers of 24, 32 and 40 floors rising to 164m, but the planners imposed a height limit of {{convert|100|m|ft}}.<ref name=Rogers>{{cite web | title=Grand Union Building | url=http://www.richardrogers.co.uk/render.aspx?siteID=1&navIDs=1,4,23,804 | publisher=Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners | year=2010 | accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref> The revised scheme comprised six linked blocks of 30 storeys totalling {{convert|860000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of mixed-use space,<ref name=Rogers /> but the project was discarded when it looked like the site would be needed by the Health Campus (see below).<ref name=merchant>{{cite news | url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/construction_and_property/article729515.ece | title=Developers to submit £700m Paddington Basin plans |work=[[The Times|Business Times]] |date=11 February 2006 | first= Jenny| last=Davey | accessdate=29 October 2010}} (Subscription required for access)</ref> [[File:CurlingBridgeClip.jpg|thumb|The Rolling Bridge in Paddington Basin curls up to let boats through.]] The Health Campus scheme collapsed in 2005 and in February 2006 the Paddington Development Corporation - now European Land and Property Ltd - submitted a new planning application.<ref name=merchant /> Branded as Merchant Square, this proposed {{convert|1800000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of mixed-use space spanning 6 buildings, including 554 residential units and 58% commercial space.<ref name=factsheet /> Planning permission was granted on 1 March 2007.<ref name=factsheet /> A revised planning application was subsequently submitted and was approved on 19 May 2011.<ref name=Reuben>{{cite web | url=http://www.reubenbrothers.com/revised-merchant-square-plan-gets-approval/ | title=20 May 2011 Media Release | publisher=Reuben Brothers | accessdate=7 July 2014}}</ref> 4 Merchant Square, a 16-storey block of 196 flats, designed by Tryfon Kalyvides Partnership, is now complete;<ref name=CoStar>{{cite web | url=http://www.costar.co.uk/en/assets/news/2013/July/Three-merchant-square-tops-out/ | title=Three Merchant Square tops out |publisher=CoStar Co. |date=3 July 2013 | first= James| last=Buckley | accessdate=7 July 2014}}</ref> 5 Merchant Square (formerly Carmine) is a 14-storey office block of {{convert|255000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} designed by [[Michel Mossessian|mossessian & partners]]<ref name=waterside>{{Cite web | title=Merchant Square | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/Merchant%20Square | year=2014 | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=7 July 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140709121211/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/Merchant%20Square | archivedate=9 July 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> and part-occupied by [[Marks & Spencer]], which also occupies the Waterside Building.<ref name=Partners>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/node/315 | title=Marks & Spencer | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=7 July 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714135414/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/node/315 | archivedate=14 July 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
3 Merchant Square, a 21-storey development of 159 luxury apartments and 42 standard apartments, is due for completion in summer 2014.<ref name=EG>{{cite news |work=Estates Gazette |title=Bank on Success |date=12 January 2013 |first= Emily |last=Wright}}</ref> 1 Merchant Square will be a residential tower of 42 storeys designed by [[Robin Partington]] Architects, which will be the tallest building in the City of Westminster, containing just over 200 residential units, a 90-room boutique hotel and a sky bar.<ref name=Standard>{{cite news | url=http://www.homesandproperty.co.uk/property-news/new-homes/london-becoming-vertical-metropolis |work=[[London Evening Standard]] | title=London is becoming a vertical metropolis | date=6 November 2012 | first= David| last=Spittles | accessdate=7 July 2014}}</ref> 2 Merchant Square will be a 16-storey office building providing {{convert|162000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of Grade A space with {{convert|4400|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail space.<ref name=Merchant>{{cite web | url=http://www.merchantsquare.co.uk/the-buildings/2-merchant-square/ | title=2 Merchant Square | publisher=European Land and Property Ltd | accessdate=7 July 2014}} (Official website)</ref> 6 Merchant Square will offer 119 apartments over 15 floors.<ref name=MerchantSq>{{cite web | url=http://www.merchantsquare.co.uk/the-buildings/6-merchant-square/ | title=6 Merchant Square | publisher=European Land and Property Ltd | accessdate=7 July 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702110355/http://www.merchantsquare.co.uk/the-buildings/6-merchant-square/ | archivedate=2 July 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A large square by the canal is planned for Merchant Square, along with business and retail barges moored alongside.<ref name=Basin /> The basin is known for its ingenious pedestrian bridges, such as [[The Rolling Bridge]] and the Fan Bridge, which has been operational since autumn 2014 and opens with the motion of a Japanese hand fan.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/travel/4146/the-fan-bridge-paddingtons-new-landmark.html |title=The 'Fan Bridge': Paddington's new landmark |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=16 May 2013 | first= John| last=O'Cealleigh | accessdate=7 July 2014}}</ref>
===North Wharf Gardens=== [[File:North Wharf Gardens Site 1.png|thumbnail|View down Hermitage Street of North Wharf Gardens Site 1]] Sandwiched between the Westway and the canal basin, the 1.5-hectare site of the former North Westminster Community School was omitted from the Paddington Special Policy Area as it was expected to remain in use for education.<ref name=schoolplanning2010>{{cite web | title=Adopted Planning Brief for the North Westminster Community School, North Wharf Road, W2 | url=http://www3.westminster.gov.uk/docstores/publications_store/NWCS_Adopted_Planning_brief_with_appendices_March2010.pdf | publisher=City of Westminster | date=17 March 2010 | accessdate=29 October 2010 | format=pdf}}</ref>{{rp|p.13}} The decision to build the [[Paddington Academy]] and [[Westminster Academy (London)|Westminster Academy]] left the site available for redevelopment when the [[City of Westminster College]] moved to a new campus at the end of 2010. The planning brief proposed that "around 80% of gross internal area delivered on the site should be allocated for residential use, with public open space, and supporting active uses that provide local employment."<ref name=schoolplanning2010 />{{rp|pp.7–8}}
In April 2012 [[Westminster City Council]] sold the site to Amwaj Property Limited, of [[Bahrain]], which commissioned London-based [[Assael Architecture]] to design a residentially-oriented [[mixed-use]] development, the first phase of which was scheduled for completion in 2015 at an estimated cost of £71 million.<ref>[http://www.assael.co.uk/content/north-wharf-gardens-paddington New neighbourhood in Paddington Basin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105073235/http://www.assael.co.uk/content/north-wharf-gardens-paddington |date=5 November 2013 }} Assael official website. Accessed 23 November 2013</ref>
===Paddington Health Campus and St Mary's Hospital=== [[File:StMarysOldSection.jpg|right|thumb|[[St Mary's Hospital, London|St Mary's Hospital]]]] {{main|St Mary's Hospital, London}} St Mary's is a major teaching hospital with a long tradition of biomedical research, from the first synthesis of [[heroin]] to the discovery of [[penicillin]]. It is housed in buildings dating back to 1845 between Praed Street and Paddington Basin. In October 2000, the London Regional Office of the NHS approved a plan for a Paddington Health Campus that would replace three run-down hospitals - St Marys, the [[Royal Brompton Hospital|Royal Brompton]] and [[Harefield Hospital|Harefield]].<ref name=nao>{{cite web | title=Department of Health - The Paddington Health Campus scheme | url=http://www.nao.org.uk/publications/0506/department_of_health_-_the_pad.aspx | publisher=National Audit Office | date= 19 May 2006 | accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref> The initial cost was estimated at £411m at 2005 prices with completion in 2006,<ref name=nao /> to be financed by [[private finance initiative|PFI]],<ref name=bbc>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/4994254.stm | title='Super-hospital' failure slammed | publisher=BBC News | date=19 May 2006 | accessdate=29 October 2010}}</ref> but it became apparent that the scheme was too big for the original St Mary's site.<ref name=nao /> Various locations north of the canal basin were investigated but the scheme was finally abandoned in May 2005 after costs had spiralled to £894m and the completion date put back to 2013.<ref name=nao /> £15m was spent on the project, leading [[Richard Bacon (politician)|a member]] of the Commons [[Public Accounts Committee (United Kingdom)|Public Accounts Committee]] to describe it as "an object lesson in how not to build hospitals....a shambles of the first order",<ref name=bbc /> and [[Steve Webb|a colleague]] called it "incompetence on a massive scale".<ref name=bbc />
The land north of the canal that had been earmarked for the Health Campus became the Merchant Square development in Paddington Basin (see above).<ref name=merchant/> The planning application was formally withdrawn in May 2008<ref name=factsheet /> but St Mary's remains part of the Paddington Waterside Partnership.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/st-marys-hospital/default.aspx | title=St Mary's Hospital/Imperial College | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=29 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719023223/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/st-marys-hospital/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The only recent development work has been a £15m upgrade of the QEQM Wing.<ref name=factsheet />
===Hilton London Paddington=== {{main|Hilton London Paddington}} [[File:Hilton London Paddington 1.jpg|thumb|Hilton London Paddington]] The Great Western Royal Hotel on Praed Street was built as the station hotel in 1854.<ref name=Hilton>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/hilton-london-paddington/default.aspx | title=Hilton London Paddington | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=29 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719023238/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/hilton-london-paddington/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Muirgold Limited gave it a £60m refurbishment in 2002 and it was rebranded as the [[Hilton Hotels & Resorts|Hilton]] London Paddington.<ref name=Hilton />
===Sorting Office=== The Royal Mail closed their sorting office in Praed Street in March 2010 and moved the counter service to West End Quay.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/sorting-office/default.aspx | title=Sorting Office Site | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=29 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719023256/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/sorting-office/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> A commercial development is envisaged for the site, along with a new ticket hall for the [[Bakerloo line]] and better access to the mainline station.<ref name=factsheet />
===West End Quay=== Rialto Homes and WestCity built three blocks of flats at the east end of the canal basin that were completed in 2003.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/westend-quay/default.aspx | title=West End Quay | publisher=Paddington Waterside Partnership | accessdate=29 October 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719023308/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/the-developments/westend-quay/default.aspx | archivedate=19 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> West End Quay comprises 468 flats and {{convert|29000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail space, designed by [[Broadway Malyan]].
===Hilton London Metropole=== {{main|Hilton London Metropole}} The Metropole is a landmark hotel with 1058 bedrooms on the Edgware Road,<ref name=factsheet /> next to the Marylebone [[flyover (overpass)|flyover]]. Originally built in 1968, it was extended in 1986 and a conference centre was added in 1998-2000, making it the biggest convention hotel in Britain.<ref name=factsheet /> Its {{convert|91|m|ft|adj=on}} tower was the tallest building in the area for many years.

[[Santa Clara University]] | term_start = 1988 | term_end = 2008 | predecessor = [[William J. Rewak]]. S.J. | successor = [[Michael Engh]], S.J. | birth_date = {{birth date|1938|9|16}} | birth_place = [[Boulder Creek, California]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|7|12|1938|9|16}} | death_place = [[Los Gatos, California]] | alma_mater = [[Santa Clara University]] [[University of Southern California]] | residence = [[Santa Clara, California]] | religion = Roman Catholic | website = [http://www.scu.edu/president/ www.scu.edu/president] }} '''The Rev. Paul Leo Locatelli, S.J.''' (September 16, 1938 – July 12, 2010) was an [[United States|American]] [[Jesuit]] [[priest]], [[academic]] and [[certified public accountant]]. Locatelli served as the president of [[Santa Clara University]] from 1988 until 2008 before becoming [[chancellor]] of Santa Clara in 2008. He also held the post of Secretary of Higher Education for the [[Society of Jesus]] in [[Rome]]. ==Biography== ===Early life=== Locatelli grew up on a [[ranch]] in the town of [[Boulder Creek, California]], in the [[Santa Cruz Mountains]], the second of three sons.{{cite news |first=Julia Prodis|last=Sulek|title=The Rev. Paul Locatelli, key leader at Santa Clara University, dies at 71|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/california/ci_15503218|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |publisher=|date=July 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 17, 2011|deadurl=no}} The family grew their own walnuts and grapes for [[winemaking]]. His family had come to [[Boulder Creek (California)|Boulder Creek]] from [[Italy]] in the 1890s. His father ran Locatelli Brothers Lumber, where Locatelli worked.{{cite news |first=Charles|last=McChesney|title=Passing: Paul Leo Locatelli, chancellor and former president of Santa Clara University, dies at 71 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/14/local/la-me-passings-20100714|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=|date=2010-07-14 |accessdate=2010-07-23}} His mother's family had immigrated from [[Italy]] to [[Oakland]], California, where they opened and operated the Colombo Bakery. Locatelli was the first member of his family to attend college. He received a [[bachelor's degree]] in business at the University of Santa Clara, now [[Santa Clara University]] in 1960. Classmates at Santa Clara included CIA director [[Leon Panetta]], who remained friends with Locatelli, and former [[Oakland A's]] owner [[Stephen Schott]]. Locatelli obtained a [[doctorate]] in [[business]] from the [[University of Southern California]]'s [[USC Marshall School of Business|Marshall School of Business]]. He enlisted in the [[United States Army]] and decided to enter the Jesuits after leaving the armed services. Locatelli entered the former [[Jesuit School of Theology at Berkeley]]. He was ordained a Jesuit priest in 1974. ===Santa Clara University=== Locatelli began teaching at Santa Clara University as a professor of [[accounting]] in 1974, the same year in which he was ordained a Jesuit priest. Within a few years, he was voted outstanding teacher of the year. He rose from Dean of the School of Business, to Academic Vice-President. Locatelli was named the 27th President of [[Santa Clara University]] in 1988 after 14 years at the university.{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Paul Locatelli, S.J. 1938-2010|url=http://www.scu.edu/news/?b=208&c=7447|work=[[Santa Clara University]] press release |publisher=|date=2010-07-12 |accessdate=2010-07-23}} During Locatelli's tenure as president, academics, admissions standards and endowment funding increased substantially. Under Locatelli's presidency, Santa Clara University fully renovated or constructed nineteen new campus buildings, as well as a sports center. This is the equivalent of two-thirds of all campus facilities. A prolific fundraiser, Locatelli raised millions for the construction spree which included new academic buildings, a [[business school]] building, [[residence halls]], a swim center, a tennis center, and the School of Arts and Science. He also raised funds for [[scholarships]] at Santa Clara. Locatelli phased out Santa Clara's [[fraternity]] and [[sorority]] houses, which lessened the influence of the Greek system on student life. Controversially, Locatelli eliminated the school's Division II [[American football|football]] program in 1993. Locatelli spearheaded the effort to reroute [[California State Route 82|The Alameda (California State Route 82)]], which had previously run through the center of Santa Clara University's campus. Locatelli also had a new entrance road, lined with [[palm trees]], built which leads to the [[Mission Santa Clara de Asís]], a 1777 [[Spain|Spanish]] mission which is now the centerpiece of Santa Clara's campus. Locatelli and Santa Clara University became involved with the [[Salvadoran Civil War]] during the late 1980s and early 1990s. He offered Santa Clara as a refuge to the lone surviving Jesuit of the 1989 massacre at the [[Universidad Centroamericana]], in which six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter were killed by the [[Salvadoran Army]]. (The surviving Jesuit priest had been out of El Salvador at the time of the killings). Father Locatelli also implemented a program where Santa Clara students volunteered and worked at a women's center and urban schools in [[El Salvador]]. Under President Locatelli's guidance, Santa Clara's [[Financial endowment|endowment]] at Santa Clara grew from $77 million in 1988 to approximately $700 million in 2008. Through the [[Ignatian Center for Jesuit Education]], the University has expanded its ability to connect students to communities in [[Silicon Valley]] and throughout the world. Locatelli was known affectionately by the students at SCU through a variety of nicknames; such as; "Papa Lōc", "Big Poppa P", "P. Loc", and the "Big P". On March 1, 2008, Locatelli announced his intention to resign during the 2008–09 academic year, after 20 years as university president, due to his additional responsibilities as Secretary of Higher Education of the [[Society of Jesus]] in [[Rome]], a post he had held since January 2007, coordinating the [[Jesuits]] 150 universities worldwide, to promote cooperation among Jesuit higher education institutions.{{cite news |first=Liz|last=O'Brien|title=University president resigns to take on expanded role in Rome |url=http://media.www.thesantaclara.com/media/storage/paper946/news/2008/04/03/News/University.President.Resigns.To.Take.On.Expanded.Role.In.Rome-3300634.shtml|work=[[The Santa Clara]] |publisher=|date=2008-04-03 |accessdate=2010-07-23}} He was subsequently promoted to chancellor of the university in November 2008 by new [[Santa Clara University]] President Michael Engh, S.J.{{cite news |first=Charles|last=McChesney|title=Chancellor's Office press release |url=http://www.scu.edu/chancellor/|work=[[Santa Clara University]] |publisher=|date=|accessdate=2010-07-23}} ===Recognitions=== On January 16, 2002 he was awarded the [[Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice]] from [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California|San Jose]] Bishop [[Patrick Joseph McGrath]].{{cite news |first=|last=|title=SCU president honored with 'Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice' Award|url=http://www.scu.edu/news/releases/release.cfm?c=4575|work=[[Santa Clara University]] |publisher=|date=2002-01-16 |accessdate=2010-07-23}} Father Locatelli was awarded the Spirit of [[Silicon Valley]] Lifetime Achievement Award from the [[Silicon Valley]] Leadership Group. He was also a recipient of the David Packard Award in 2009. ===Death=== Locatelli was diagnosed with [[pancreatic cancer]] in May 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.scu.edu/news/?b=208&c=7447 |title=University Press Release |publisher=Santa Clara University |accessdate=2010-07-12}} At the time Father Locatelli took ill, he was preparing for the fiftieth anniversary celebration and reunion of his classmates in the class of 1960 at [[Santa Clara University]], and had already sent out invitations, including one to [[Leon Panetta]]. He was moved to the hospice at Regis Jesuit Infirmary in [[Los Gatos]] on July 8, 2010. He died from [[pancreatic cancer]] on July 12, 2010, at the age of 71. Locatelli was survived by his brothers, Albert and Harry. [[CIA]] Director, former Congressman and [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Leon Panetta]], a 1960 Santa Clara classmate of Locatelli's, stated after Father Locatelli's death that, "What Paul told you was always the truth. He didn't play games. You knew that what he said was what he believed. I don't think there is any question that he (Father Locatelli) will go down as one of the greatest presidents in [[Santa Clara, California|Santa Clara]] history." ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.scu.edu/president/locatelli/index.cfm Office of the President, Santa Clara University] *[http://www.scu.edu/president/publiccommentary/index.cfm Official speeches and letters] *[http://www.scu.edu/news/releases/release.cfm?month=1004&story=locatelli Fr. Locatelli re-appointed for fourth term] *[http://www.scu.edu/news/?b=208&c=7447 Santa Clara University Press Release on Father Locatelli's death] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Locatelli, Paul}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Presidents of Santa Clara University]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:American Jesuits]] [[Category:Santa Clara University alumni]] [[Category:Marshall School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Loyola Marymount University faculty]] [[Category:People from Santa Clara, California]] [[Category:People from Boulder Creek, California]] [[Category:Deaths from pancreatic cancer]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in California]] [[Category:Recipients of the Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice]] [[Category:Catholics from California]]

'''Reyn (Rhein) Altin Johannes Lumenta''' (February 26, 1933 in [[Surabaya]] – September 28, 2003 in [[Jakarta]]) (or R.A.J. Lumenta) was the [[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[CEO]] of [[Garuda Indonesia]], the Indonesian National Airline, in the period of 1984-1988, replacing [[Wiweko Soepono]]. Born in [[Surabaya]], [[East Java]], from a [[Manado]] ethnic family of [[Sulawesi]], Lumenta grew up in Indonesia before continuing his education in the [[Netherlands]]. He graduated in “Vliegtuigbouw” from [[Hogere Technische School]] “Technicum” in [[Rotterdam]] in 1956. Having strong relation with Wagey and Saroinsong family clans.
==Career== [[File:Reyn Altin Johannes Lumenta signing official papers.jpg|thumb|Reyn Altin Johannes Lumenta signing official papers]] Lumenta started his career in Garuda Indonesia as an [[Airframe]] and [[System Engineer]] (1957-1958). A year later he was promoted to be Head of Maintenance for Garuda’s [[aircraft]] and held various [[management|Director]] Positions afterwards until 1975 when he became [[Company Secretary]].<ref>[http://www.kompas.com/kompas-cetak/0309/30/metro/591360.htm Kompas newspaper (2003), September 30, “Lumenta Meninggalkan Citra Baru Garuda” (Lumenta Left Garuda It’s New Image)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050128051909/http://www.kompas.com/kompas-cetak/0309/30/metro/591360.htm |date=2005-01-28 }}</ref>
Lumenta was CEO of [[Merpati Nusantara Airlines]], a subsidiary of Garuda Indonesia, in the period of 1979-1983. He managed to convince the government to finance a major modernisation of Merpati, saving the company from debts and possible bankruptcy.<ref>[http://www.angkasa-online.com/12/05/utama/utama2.htm Yusuf, D.N. (2002), Kisah Merpati yang Tersisih, Angkasa, no. 5, February 2002] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819235734/http://www.angkasa-online.com/12/05/utama/utama2.htm |date=2007-08-19 }}</ref> Lumenta then returned to Garuda to become President and CEO in November 1984.
==President of Garuda Indonesia==
As President of the airline, Lumenta led a number of bold reforms in the organisation. On his arrival Garuda was in debts of around US$914 million. Under his leadership the company experienced increased popularity and profits.<ref>[http://www.pdat.co.id/ “Reyn Altin Johannes Lumenta”, Apa dan Siapa (What and Who), Pusat Data dan Analisa (Centre of Data and Analysis), Tempo Indonesia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115153622/http://www.pdat.co.id/ |date=2013-01-15 }}</ref>
In 1985 he created a controversy by hiring foreign brand consultants [[Landor Associates]] to create a new logo and colour scheme for Garuda Indonesia, a project that cost the company millions of US dollars. This move was later on applauded as vital for the reputation and [[corporate identity]] of Garuda Indonesia as the national airline.
Lumenta also increased flights frequency and destinations, reduced ticket prices and collaborated with Merpati, introducing flexible tickets valid for both Indonesian airlines.
Lumenta was also known for his solidarity and generosity to committed employees; he increased staff basic salaries by almost ten folds and improved staff reward and welfare systems.<ref>[http://www.pdat.co.id/ “Reyn Altin Johannes Lumenta”, Apa dan Siapa (What and Who), Pusat Data dan Analisa (Centre of Data and Analysis), Tempo Indonesia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115153622/http://www.pdat.co.id/ |date=2013-01-15 }}</ref>
==Other achievements== Lumenta received “Bunga Seroja” award (1976) (see [[Indonesian invasion of East Timor]]) from HANKAM, the Indonesian Ministry of Security and Defense<ref>http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/indonesia/hankam.htm</ref> for his contribution in the mass transportation of aids and volunteers to [[East Timor]].
Lumenta was a [[BMW]] motorcycle enthusiast, having toured [[Europe]], [[South East Asia]] and [[Indonesia]] with his blue BMW [[touring motorcycle]]. Lumenta established Ikatan Motor Besar Indonesia (IMBI), an Association of Big Motorcycles in Indonesia in 1976.<ref>[http://www.cci.co.id/ceremony/imbi.php Card CONNECTION Indonesia<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016083847/http://cci.co.id/ceremony/imbi.php |date=2007-10-16 }}</ref>
Together with 15 other individuals, in July 1968 Lumenta participated in the establishment of Organisation of Amateur Radio Indonesia (ORARI),<ref>http://www.orari.net</ref> a local member of the [[International Amateur Radio Union]] (IARU). His code name was YB0BY.<ref>[http://buletin.orari.net “From the Editor: Rhein Altin Johannes Lumenta, YBOBY”, Yusuf, A., Farianto, D., Electronic Bulletin ORARI, October 2003, 5th Edition, issue III]</ref><ref>Lumenta, R.A.J. (1986), Building a New Image, Flight International, vol. 130, no. 4022, pp. 29-31, Reed Business Information ltd</ref>
==Personal== His other hobbies included black-and-white [[photography]], [[painting]] and writing, both in English and [[Indonesian language]]. Several of his books and journal articles<ref>Lumenta, R.A.J. (1986), Building a New Image, Flight International, vol. 130, no. 4022, pp. 29-31, Reed Business Information ltd</ref> were published, including Aerodinamika ([[Aerodynamics]]) (1985), Mixtures (1982-1984); an 11-series mini book on Radio Amateur, Bermotor (Motorcycling) (1988); about his motorcycle journey across [[Sumatra]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Thailand]]. His final book [[Medan]] – [[Padang, Indonesia|Padang]] 1.450 (1992) was about his motorcycle trips around [[North Sumatra]] and [[West Sumatra]] in the same year.<ref>[http://www.kompas.com/kompas-cetak/0309/30/metro/591360.htm Kompas newspaper (2003), September 30, “Lumenta Meninggalkan Citra Baru Garuda” (Lumenta Left Garuda It’s New Image)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050128051909/http://www.kompas.com/kompas-cetak/0309/30/metro/591360.htm |date=2005-01-28 }}</ref>
Lumenta was a charismatic individual. As an executive, he was rarely suited, and was widely remembered wearing a navy blue jacket, almost always with a test pen in his pocket.
He died on 28 September 2003 and was buried on October 1 2003 in [[Joglo]] cemetery, [[West Jakarta]]. Lumenta married a few times and left his last wife and several children; Altin, Johan, Ronald, Alice, Joan, Rita, Lucy, and Lucky.

Eduardo }} '''Roberto Sahade''' (born May 29, 1976) is a Brazilian business man, founder of GMR Energia group, a family corporation, with investments in power generation in Latin America, mainly Brazil, Chile and Perú. Of Lebanese descent, he is the son of Moukbel Roberto Sahade, Brazilian entrepreneur in construction and real estate development sectors, and Ana Maria Spina Sahade, dentist. Graduated as civil engineer at Fundação Armando Alváres Penteado – FAAP, in 1998, and obtained his MBA from IBMEC-SP, in 2001. Has also done postgraduate studies at Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, in 2007, and at the Stanford Graduate School of Business, in 2011 and 2017, both in the United States, and Insead, Fontainebleau Campus, in 2009, in France. Currently, is in charge of GMR Energia (2004), holding company with investments in CPFL Renováveis, in Brazil, and LAP – Latin America Power, in Chile and Peru.{{Ref|BTG_Pactual|1}}{{Ref|Economia|2}} ==Career== Before graduating as a civil engineer, had already joined the family business activities. After founding the GMR group, started the expansion of the business in real estate, 1998, and in renewable power generation, 2004. In 2007 created ERSA, currently CPFL Renováveis, publicly traded company on [[Bovespa]], in partnership with Pátria Investimentos, Eton Park, Bradesco and DEG (KFW), and moreover, joined BTG Pactual. This company today is the largest renewable power generation in Latin America, with small [[Hydropower|hydro]], wind, [[biomass]] and solar technologies. Was in charge until the end of 2011. This same year, 2011, founded LAP – Latin America Power, a renewable power company with operations in Chile and Peru, corporation capitalized by the former partners BTG Pactual and Pátria/Blackstone. Was in charge until the June 2017.{{cite web |url=http://clipping.interclipnet.com.br/interclipping1/site/interna.php?secao=SaladeImprensa¬icia=1039 |title=BTG e Pátria são parceiros em energia (Valor Econômico - SP) |date=May 11, 2015 |work=INTERCLIPNET |language=portugués |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518102640/http://clipping.interclipnet.com.br/interclipping1/site/interna.php?secao=SaladeImprensa¬icia=1039|archivedate=2015-05-18}}{{cite web |url=http://www.economiaynegocios.cl/noticias/noticias.asp?id=99901 |title=Grupo brasileño invertirá en Chile US$ 2 mil mills. en energía |date=Aug 28, 2012}}{{cite web |url=https://exame.abril.com.br/mercados/oferta-da-cpfl-renovaveis-pode-chegar-a-r-1-2-bi/ |title=Oferta da CPFL Renováveis pode chegar a R$ 1,4 bi |date=Jun 27, 2013}}{{cite web |url=https://gestion.pe/impresa/brasilena-lap-holding-amplia-proyectos-hidroelectricos-peru-2052229/ |title=Brasileña LAP Holding amplía proyectos hidroelectricos en Perú |date=Nov 21, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://economia.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,cpfl-negocia-fusao-no-setor-de-energias-renovaveis,63144e/ |title=CPFL negocia fusão no setor de energias renováveis |date=Apr 16, 2011}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *http://www.economiaynegocios.cl/noticias/noticias.asp?id=194885 *https://www.law360.com/articles/767344 *https://gestion.pe/impresa/lap-evalua-invertir-proyectos-energia-2011988 *https://gestion.pe/impresa/lap-pondra-operar-dos-minicentrales-este-ano-2091543 *https://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/cpfl-renovaveis-incorpora-dobreve-energia-e-eleva-capacidade-em-18-5/ {{DEFAULTSORT:Sahade, Roberto}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Santos, São Paulo]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]]

'''Rosario Messina''', ([[Aci Castello]], December 1942 – [[Meda (Italy)|Meda]], March 9, 2011), was an Italian entrepreneur, who in 1978 founded the Italian company [[Flou (Company)|Flou]], an avant-garde furniture manufacturer.
== Biography ==
'''Rosario Messina''' was born in 1942 in the [[Sicily|Sicilian]] city of [[Aci Castello]] in 1942. His father – a farmer – died when he was a young man, leaving him the responsibility of the family. He was the eldest of five children and in 1958, he began working for the [[La Rinascente]] department store in [[Catania]], first as an apprentice, then as a salesperson and finally as head of department.
Simultaneously, he attended evening courses in book-keeping and qualified in record time, managing to complete five academic years in one.
Following his experience with La Rinascente, he worked in the local branch of [[Zanussi]]-Rex, the most important Italian manufacturer of electrical appliances at that time.
In the early [[Seventies]], he was asked to work in the furniture-design sector: he joined the company C&B (now B&B Italia) as an account officer for [[Sicily]] and [[Calabria]]. He then moved to the north of the country as the company's sales manager. In 1976, he started working with Cinova, another leading sofa manufacturing company. He was appointed as the sales manager, responsible for general management.
His professional turning point appeared when the soft furnishings company, [[Bassetti]], assigned him a difficult task: he was asked to launch 'the [[duvet]]', a product to replace the traditional [[blanket]] for beds.
It was a difficult undertaking, and made more complex by the opposition from the furniture dealers – the elective distribution channel – who opposed commercializing a low cost product distributed through other channels. Messina had a [[Eureka (word)|Eureka]] moment and intuitively felt that 'bed with the duvet' as opposed to duvet alone would be an overwhelming success.
This ingenious idea led to the foundation of the company [[Flou (Company)|Flou]] in 1978 and the presentation of the bed 'Nathalie' designed by [[Vico Magistretti]], an article that unquestionably was the prototype of a new design direction: the modern textile bed.
Flou was a true pioneer in the 'culture of sleep' and rapidly became a leader in the world of furnishings, making an important contribution to enhancing the image of [[Italian design]] in the world.<ref name="flou">{{cite web|url=http://www.flou.it/#/azienda/fondatore|title=Flou|publisher=flou.it|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref>
=== Official appointments ===
Between 1994 and 1998, Rosario Messina was President of the Gruppo Mobili Assarredo. From 1998, he was President of Assarredo, the trade association of Federlegno-Arredo that groups together the Italian furniture and furnishing industries. He was a member of the steering committee of the Council of Federlegno-Arredo, and was appointed to the same role with the industrial confederation [[Confindustria]] [[Monza e Brianza]].
In 1999 he was appointed to the most prestigious position as President of Cosmit, the organizing body for [[Milan Furniture Fair]].<ref name="ilsole24ore">{{cite web|url=http://www.casa24.ilsole24ore.com/art/arredamento-casa/2011-03-10/addio-rosario-messina-padre-140909.php?uuid=AaoSz0ED|title=Addio a Rosario Messina, il padre del Salone del mobile|publisher=casa24.ilsole24ore.com|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref> This is the world's most important furniture exhibition and under his Presidency, the [[Milan Furniture Fair]] (and the collateral exhibitions of Euroluce (Lighting), Eurocucina (Kitchens), Salone del Bagno [Bathrooms], Salone del Complemento d'Arredo (Furnishing Accessories), Salone dell'Ufficio (Office), Salone Satellite (Collateral events) progressed from being a simple trade show to a spectacular event, with the promotion of important cultural events that consolidated Milan as the unchallengeable 'Design capital'. The Salon was transformed into a meeting place for questions and answers as well as being a platform for 360° proposals in all areas of design culture and innovation.
The last edition under his management took place in 2011: a total of 321,320 people visited the event (up 7% on 2010 and 2% on 2009) and the 'Satellite Salon' that was actively promoted by Messina; this spin-off initiative started quietly and today is the most prestigious stage for showcasing up-and-coming designers and architects from the specialist educational aspects around the world.
In June 2008, during the annual general meeting, Rosario Messina was elected President of Federlegno-Arredo, the organization of [[Confindustria]] that represents 2,300 companies in 12 associations (Assarredo [Furnishings], Assobagno [Bathrooms], Assoimballaggi [Packaging], Assolegno [Wood and Timber], Assoluce [Lighting], Assopannelli [Panels], Assufficio [Office], Edilegno [Timber houses], Fedecomlegno [The Italian National Timber Association], Asal Assoallestimenti [Stands and Layouts], Aippl [Wooden flooring and laying], Apil [Lighting]); these represent the entire section of timber-furnishings: from the raw materials to the finished product.
He was a councillor on the steering committee of the foundation 'Center for the development of Italo-Russian trade relations".
On October 30, 2008, the then president of Confundustria, [[Emma Marcegaglia]], appointed him as a delegate of the industrial confederation Confindustria and according to the constitution, he automatically held the position of Vice President of CFI (The Italian industrial confederation).
=== Prizes, awards and commendations ===
*1996 "Industrialist of the Year" Awarded by the Group of [[Monza e Brianza]] Journalists during a ceremony hosted in the historical Palazzo Antona Traversi in [[Meda (Italy)]] *1997 "Official Commander of the Italian Republic"<ref name="quirinale">{{cite web|url=http://www.quirinale.it/elementi/Onorificenze.aspx?pag=0&qIdOnorificenza=&cognome=messina&nome=rosario&daAnno=1800&aAnno=2014&luogoNascita=aci%20castello&testo=&ordinamento=2|title=Le onorificenze della Repubblica italiana|publisher=quirinale.it|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref> *1999 President of Cosmit – The organizing committee for the [[Milan Furniture Fair]] and the collateral events *2000 "[[Made in Italy]] Awards" – New York *2002 "26th Silver Jug" The city of Giarre, in [[Sicily]]. An award presented to Sicilians distinguished on the international stage. *2002 "Gold Medal for Industrial Merit" presented by the Industrial Association of [[Monza e Brianza]] *2002 "Paul Harris, Rotary Award for Entrepreneurship" ''Reason: "Paul Harris 2002, the top award of the Rotary presented in recognition of a man who with commitment and determination led Flou to the leading position in the furnishing industry".'' *2002 "Entrepreneur of the Year" – The Ernst & Young Award<ref name="ey">{{cite web|url=http://www.ey.com/IT/it/About-us/Entrepreneurship/Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year/EOY---Jury---Messina|title=Ernst &Young >About us>EOY – La Giuria – Messina – EY – Italia|publisher=ey.com|accessdate=March 12, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313000951/http://www.ey.com/IT/it/About-us/Entrepreneurship/Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year/EOY---Jury---Messina|archivedate=March 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''Reason: "For the "Innovation" Category, Rosario Messina was recognized for the most creative and innovative vision that marked a turning point in corporate living, for the revolutionary vision of the domestic environment and the transformation of the bedroom into a space to be enjoyed to the full, with modern original ideas, giving rise to a new culture for living and sleeping. The bed covers can be completely removed and replaced, and the innovative and highly comprehensive range of bedroom accessories identify Flou on the world stage. They kick-started a powerful innovative drive in the distribution of the sector, influencing the frequency of visits to the stores and affecting the methods of interaction with the clients".'' *2003 "Piazza Mercanti", An Award presented to Rosario Messina by the Milan Chamber of Commerce [Camera Commercio Industria Artigianato e Agricoltura di Milano], recognizing him as "An Entrepreneur distinguished for the innovations of process and product in his company". *2004 The prestigious Compasso D'oro Award for his career presented by ADI, The Industrial Design Association – [[Triennale di Milano]]. *2004 Commander of the Order of Merit of the Italian Public (Commendatore dell'Ordine al merito della Repubblica Italiana) – an honor from the Italian President of the Republic *2005 "Honorary Citizen of the City of [[Meda (Italy)|Meda]]" *2006 The Ambrogino d'oro Award – City Council of Milan – Cosmit presented the prize to its President Rosario Messina. *2007 8th edition of the National (Italy) Prize "Catania: Talenti e Dintorni" [Catania: Talents and Accessories] Fashion & Industry *2008 He was President of Federlegno-Arredo *2008 He was nominated "Grand Officers of the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic [Grande Ufficiale dell'Ordine al Merito della Repubblica Italiana] *2009 The President of the Italy, [[Giorgio Napolitano]] conferred the title of 'Knight for Labor' [[Cavaliere del Lavoro]]<ref name="quirinale2">{{cite web|url=http://www.quirinale.it/elementi/DettaglioOnorificenze.aspx?decorato=309341|title=Presidenza della Repubblica|publisher=quirinale.it|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref>
== The "Rosario Messina" Foundation for Further Education ==
On December 13, 2013, with a Decree issued by the General Council of the [[Lombardy]] Regional Government for Education, Training and Employment [Direzione Generale Istruzione, Formazione e Lavoro] approved and funded the project for the constitution of the new 'Rosario Messina Foundation for Further Education', and the definition of the course of study "Superior Technique for processes, products, communication and marketing for the Timber-Furnishing sectors" (Tecnico Superiore di processo, prodotto, comunicazione e marketing per il settore LegnoArredo).<ref name="federlegnoarredo">{{cite web|url=http://www.federlegnoarredo.it/it/federazione/progetti/polo-formativo-legno-arredo/al-via-la-fondazione-rosario-messina|title=Al via la Fondazione "Rosario Messina"|publisher=federlegnoarredo.it|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref>

[[Edward Clarke Cabot]] (b. 1818)

Stephen Cabot (b. 1826)
Walter Channing Cabot (b. 1829)[http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00484 "Cabot, Elizabeth Rogers Mason, 1834-1920. Diaries, 1859-1906: A Finding Aid".] Harvard University Library. July 1985. Retrieved August 13, 2011.
Louis Cabot (b. 1837) | parents = Samuel Cabot and Sally Barrett | relatives = [[Cabot family]] | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Samuel Cabot Jr.''' (1784-1863) was an American businessman in the [[Old China Trade|early-nineteenth-century China Trade]], a member of the wealthy and prominent [[Cabot family]]. ==Life== Samuel Cabot Jr. was born in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in 1784, the son of Samuel Cabot and Sally Barrett. In 1806, after a couple of years familiarizing himself with the East Indies trade, he set up business in [[Philadelphia]], in partnership with Samuel Hazard. In 1808 he returned to Boston and married Eliza Perkins, a daughter of [[Thomas Handasyd Perkins]]. Together, they had seven sons, including [[Edward Clarke Cabot]] (b. 1818), later an architect and artist; [[James Elliot Cabot]] (b. 1821), who became a philosopher and author; and [[Samuel Cabot III]], a surgeon and ornithologist. After marrying Eliza, Samuel then went into business with his brother Joseph and with John W. Perit, taking charge of the Philadelphia-based partnership's Boston office.{{cite web|title=Cabot, Samuel |work= Merchant Biographies|accessdate=6 March 2015 |url=http://www.cap.amdigital.co.uk/FurtherResources/MerchantBiographies/Cabot| publisher = [[Adam Matthew Digital]] |subscription=yes}} He entered the China Trade in 1817, in yet another family partnership, with his Perkins in-laws. He retired from business in 1838, one of the richest merchants in New England. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cabot, Samuel}} [[Category:1784 births]] [[Category:1863 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Cabot family]]

'''Samvel Karapetyan''' (born July 31, 1965) is an [[Armenians in Russia|Armenian-born Russian]] billionaire businessman, the owner of the real estate company Tashir Group.
==Biography== Karapetyan graduated from the [[State Engineering University of Armenia|Yerevan Polytechnic Institute]] in 1986. He moved to Russia in the 1990s and in 1997, he became the president of the [[Kaluga]]-based Kalugaglavsnab OAO, which provides logistics services. In 1999, he established the Tashir Group.<ref name="vedomosti"/>
==Personal life== He is married and has three children (two sons and a daughter).<ref name="civilnet"/>
His brother, Karen ([[:hy:Կարեն Սարգսի Կարապետյան|arm]]), is a politician from the [[Republican Party of Armenia]] and a member of the [[National Assembly (Armenia)|National Assembly]].
In 2011, Armenian President awarded Karapetyan with the [[Mesrop Mashtots Medal]] "for significant contribution to the promotion of national interests, long term and fruitful pro-Armenian activities, dedication to the development and advancement of the Republic of Armenia and provided services."<ref>http://www.president.am/en/domestic-visits/item/2011/09/20/news-310/</ref>
In November 2017, he was appointed the president of the football club [[FC Ararat Moscow]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=FC Ararat Moscow|url=https://vk.com/fcararatmsk?w=wall-147003260_17301|script-title=ru:Президентом ФК ”Арарат” избран Самвел Карапетян|date=17 November 2017|language=Russian}}</ref>
==Wealth== According to ''[[Forbes]]'', his net worth in February 2015 was $4.0 billion.<ref name=Forbes/> In March 2013 Karapetyan became the richest ethnic Armenian in the world, overtaking Armenian-American businessman [[Kirk Kerkorian]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Russian-Armenian beats U.S.-Armenian on latest Forbes billionaire list|url=http://www.armenianow.com/news/44117/armenian_samvel_karapetyan_kirk_kerkorian_billionaire_forbes_list|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=[[ArmeniaNow]]|date=5 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=World’s richest Armenians according to Forbes; Kerkorian no longer leads list|url=http://tert.am/en/news/2013/03/05/forbes-richest-armenians/|accessdate=29 April 2013|newspaper=[[Tert.am]]|date=5 March 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="vedomosti">{{cite web|title=Самвел Карапетян Биография|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/persons/22108/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BB%20%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%BD|website=[[Vedomosti]]|accessdate=17 February 2015|language=ru}}</ref>

'''Shakir al Khafaji''' (born 1955) is a [[Detroit]]-based [[Iraqi American|Iraqi-American]] businessman. He immigrated to the [[United States]] in 1975. He graduated with a B.S. degree in architecture from [[Lawrence Tech University]] in 1980. He received an M.S. in Urban Planning in 1982 from Wayne State University, Detroit, MI.
Mr. al Khafaji is a senior executive, with nearly four decades of business experience. He is Chairman of Veritas Automotive and Machinery, LLC, with an office in Southfield, Michigan. He has deep knowledge of Iraqi culture and society. He was born into a merchant family in Baghdad, and attended schools with many of the governmental leaders in the Middle East. Over the years, Mr. al Khafaji has engaged in an extensive number of business activities, including commercial trade with Iraq and the Middle East. As a result of his unique position, he has been able to play a role in the development and implementation of U.S. policy with respect to Iraq for over twenty years. He continues to maintain close relationships with business and political leaders in that region.
He was chairman of the 17th conference of Iraqi expatriates.
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added under references heading by script-assisted edit--> * Dawson Bell and Tamara Audi, Detroit Free Press, April 24, 2004, "Role of Detroit area man questioned in U.N. scandal" * Lionel Barber, Claudio Gatti and Mark Turner, [[Financial Times]], April 13, 2004, [http://www.mail-archive.com/sam11@erols.com/msg00286.html "Money questions surround former UN weapons inspector's film: Arms expert's documentary was backed by financier who profited from the controversial oil-for-food programme for Iraq"] * Robert L. Pollock, [[Wall Street Journal]], March 15, 2004, [http://www.opinionjournal.com/editorial/feature.html?id=110004822 "Saddam's Useful Idiots"] * [http://www.lib.umich.edu/govdocs/pdf/duelfer1_eab.pdf Duelfer Report Annex B]

'''Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP) Entrepreneurship Corner (ECorner)''' (Formerly Educators Corner) is a free online archive of entrepreneurship resources for teaching and learning. The purpose of the project is to support and encourage faculty around the world who teach entrepreneurship to future scientists, engineers, managers, and others. The site has been developed by a team of educators, entrepreneurs, engineers, and designers at the Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP). The project has been financially supported by Stanford University and a number of sponsors. Other collaborators in its creation include the Stanford Center for Professional Development and Stanford Video.<ref>http://ecorner.stanford.edu/about.html, STVP Entrepreneurship Corner</ref>
==Website content== The design of the archive is based on feedback from entrepreneurship educators regarding the challenges faced when teaching entrepreneurship. Resources include video clips, podcasts, syllabi, books, conferences, and listings of entrepreneurship programs.
==Partners== The STVP Entrepreneurship Corner is partnering with London Business School, the Strascheg Center for Entrepreneurship in Munich, and the Centre for Scientific Enterprise Limited (CSEL) in developing shared resources and content.
==About STVP== The Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP) is the entrepreneurship education and research center located within the School of Engineering at Stanford University. The center is hosted by the department of Management Science and Engineering. The purpose of the center is to accelerate high-technology entrepreneurship research and education for engineers and scientists worldwide. STVP supports academic research on high-technology entrepreneurship and teaches a wide range of courses to science and engineering students on campus. Outreach programs include annual conferences, campus-wide collaboration, and dissemination of teaching content through the Entrepreneurship Corner website.
== Speakers == Speakers include [[Guy Kawasaki]] ([[The Art of the Start]] Author), [[Mark Zuckerberg]] ([[Facebook]] founder) and [[Larry Page]] ([[Google]] Co-founder). There are also speakers from companies including [[Mozilla]], [[Hewlett Packard]], [[Electronic Arts]] and [[Tesla Motors]].<ref>http://ecorner.stanford.edu/speakersAuthors.html STVP Entrepreneurship Corner Speakers</ref>
==See also == * [[List of educational video websites]]

'''Taavi Kotka''' (born 21 January 1979) is an IT visionary and previously the [[Chief information officer]] of the [[Estonian Government]] known for leading [[E-residency of Estonia|e-residency]] program. Between years 2005-2012, Kotka was the CEO of Nortal (then named Webmedia), one of the largest software development companies in the Baltic states. Taavi Kotka (alongside [[Ruth Annus]], and [[Siim Sikkut]]) proposed "10 million e-residents by 2025" on idea contest by [[Estonian Development Foundation]] in 2014.<ref>Indrek Kald [http://www.aripaev.ee/uudised/2014/06/12/arengufondi-ideekonkursil-kolm-voitjat Arengufondi ideekonkursil kolm võitjat"] Äripäev, 12 June 2014 (in Estonian) (Accessed on February 6, 2015)</ref><ref>[http://uudised.err.ee/v/eesti/4455dc8a-824c-434a-92c3-27af94202806 "10 miljoni eestlase" idee pääses Arengufondi konkursi kolme võitja sekka] ERR, 12 June 2014 (in Estonian) (Accessed on February 6, 2015)</ref>
In April 2015, the [[Vice President of European Commission]], [[Andrus Ansip]], assigned Taavi Kotka to be his Special Adviser on [[Digital Single Market]] issues and [[e-Governance]]<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/civil_service/docs/special_advisers/2015/kotka_decl_honour_en.pdf</ref>.
==Biography==
Kotka started his career as a programmer, rising to be a Managing Director of the largest software development company in the region – Webmedia (now [[Nortal]]), one of largest software development companies in [[Baltic states]].<ref>http://www.hackerparadise.org/blog/2015/06/17/welcome-to-e-stonia/</ref><ref>http://www.director.ee/taavi-kotka-huvasti-webmedia/</ref>. As an engineer, he has been the brainpower behind many [[Estonia]]n e-government innovative initiatives like [[e-residency]] (digital citizenship), data embassies, country in the cloud, no-legacy policy, VAT fraud detection etc<ref>http://incorporate.ee/news/estonian-government-cio-among-100-most-important-technology-leaders-of-the-world</ref>. He is also a special advisor to [[European Commission]] vice-president [[Andrus Ansip]] on European Digital Single Market <ref>http://ec.europa.eu/civil_service/docs/special_advisers/2015/kotka_decl_honour_en.pdf</ref>.
==Education== Master of Science of Engineering (focus: [[Information and communications technology|ICT]]) and PhD Studies in [[Tallinn University of Technology]]. He was the president of the [[Estonian Association of Information Technology and Telecommunications]] (ITL) and he was elected as an Entrepreneur of the year in 2011<ref>http://www.ey.com/GL/en/About-us/Entrepreneurship/Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year/World-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year---Speakers</ref>.
==Awards==
*In 2015, [[Computerworld]] awarded Kotka with the One of the Most Important Technology Leaders title <ref>http://incorporate.ee/news/estonian-government-cio-among-100-most-important-technology-leaders-of-the-world</ref> *In 2014, Estonian Association of Information and Telecommunications awarded him with the Man of The Year title <ref>http://www.ituudised.ee/uudised/2015/03/24/taavi-kotka-palvis-aasta-tegija-tiitli</ref> *In 2014, ICT Spring awarded Taavi Kotka with the European CIO of the Year 2014 title <ref>http://www.itone.lu/actualites/5th-european-ict-awards</ref> *In 2011, [[Ernst & Young]] awarded him with the Entrepreneur of the Year title <ref>http://www.ey.com/GL/en/About-us/Entrepreneurship/Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year/World-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year---Speakers</ref>
==Honours==
* White Star Orden assigned by the President of Estonia, [[Toomas Hendrik Ilves]], 2016 <ref>https://vp2006-2016.president.ee/en/media/press-releases/11991-estonia-to-acknowledged-99-people-with-national-decorations-on-the-eve-of-independence-day/index.html</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
